choices: The soldiers refuse the girl entry
The girl is admitted to the city
The girl proves to be a diversion for an attack
Enough about the girl.  More about the faelan!
1.content:
As with many stories, this one begins on a dark stormy night. The rain had been lashing down in torrents for some time now and the guards on the gates of the city walls were getting more and more edgy. Anyone with the slightest intelligence knew that the country was threatened by the advancing armies of Cardac to the North. And, on a bitterly cold evening such as this, it was easy to imagine foul things going on outside the relative safety of the city walls.

Through the pounding of the rain came a slow rhythm of another sort. The thundering hooves of an approaching animal, presumably with rider. But was the intention to aim for safety or attack?

Slowly, and with caution, six guards made their way to the barrier. Although they would appear within touching distance to the visitor, the invisible field would protect them until they managed to seek identification. Few were travelling at present, all needed to be checked, and a show of numbers, even if unnecessary, was always good.

The rider had approached and was dismounting. Through the rain it was difficult to distinguish features, although the animal currently appeared far more interesting than its rider. It was a faelan, the best description of which would be similar in shape to a horse, with wings. These creatures were notoriously quick and close to impossible to train, although this one seemed happily at its rider's command. To own such an animal was a sign of wealth, for to buy even an untrained specimen would cost more than a guard could earn in a lifetime.

The rider stepped forward and, closely watched by the guards, was revealed to be as unthreatening as a young girl, perhaps twenty or so.

"Halt. What business do you have here?"

"I come in peace. I am seeking refuge within the city and to help however I can in the upcoming struggle."
1.title: An introduction

choices: Hide - it could be the enemy
Meet the other person and see if they can help you
Attack them and steal their papers
11.content:
"We have no room for strangers here at present."

And with that, the guards moved from view. A lesser individual may have given up at that, but the girl was not such an individual.

"It is dark and dangerous out here. You would leave me to fend for myself?" she asked, as politely as she could.

"Sorry. Orders are orders and no strangers are to pass through here," came the negative reply.

A small murmur of sympathy went around some of the guards. They would not be swayed but it was evident that they did feel some compassion for anyone stuck alone outside on a night like this.

The girl moved silently away into the night. She was sure that she could have used her powers to gain access through the gates, but she would rather her access to the city was through traditional means, to avoid arousing suspicion. Besides which there were twenty seven gates in total, not all of which may deny admission. She wondered however, if the guards had any idea how easy it would have been for her to gain access. Once she had controlled the mind of the leader, she could have done whatever she wanted. It was very tedious trying to be good, when you know that within your powers you have the ability to control others.

Riding away from the walls to alleviate suspicion, she could softly hear the sound of approaching hooves. It was another rider.
11.title: Outcast

111.content:
Deciding caution was probably best at present Dauphin tried to hide herself behind the trees. It was a dark night and on her own she could be easily hidden, but the faelan was slightly harder to escape notice. The rider was going quite slowly, but as long as they remained still she hoped to remain unseen. Her eyes remained glued on the path however, waiting to see who or indeed what was making its way towards the city.

The sight that met her eyes was not a pleasant one. It would be hard to describe the creature approaching as man or beast. It was a simbilliant - one who had once been human, but who by the powers of Cardac now lived entirely for evil. A creature with the power of twenty men, but barely any brain left, with one purpose left in life - to serve its master. Not somebody you would want an encounter with on a lonely path after dark, and certainly not someone with an honourable purpose for making towards the city walls.
111.title: Evil abroad

choices: Go back to warn the city
Keep the poison for your own purposes
1111.content:
Dauphin strained her ears and eyes for other riders and hearing none, decided that the simbillant must be a scout... or perhaps a diversion.

Nevertheless, she bent and retrieved a small throwing knife from her boot. Safe behind the thick trunk of a tree she took aim and... thwack! The rider suddenly had an ivory handle sticking out of his throat. With a surprised gurgle, the rider swayed and fell to the ground. His steed was well trained and simply paused beside its fallen master. Soundlessly creeping over the grass, Dauphin knelt caustiously at the creature's side and felt for a pulse. None.

She stood and approached the animal, still standing patiently, with soft words. It eyed her suspiciously but with a soothing mental caress it kept still. She searched the bags, finding several large bottles of a swirling green mixture that made the blood run from her face. That creature hadn't been a scout! He had been heading towards the city to kill the inhabitants! No doubt, he had been planning to put the poison in the water supply.

She called to her steed and swung up on its back.
1111.title: This path ain't big enough for the two of us

11111.content:
Even as she turned, she noticed other creatures around her, moving from the trees to surround and trap her. They were on foot, but those feet were strangely deformed, splayed and taloned toes at the end of double knee-ed legs. Aside from this, they appeared human, their bodies covered in armour, their hands grasping sharply bladed weapons.

"Surely you don't think that we would send a single agent, do you girl?" asked the biggest creature, a good head taller than its companions and wearing a plume in its helm. "Now hand that vial over to us, and maybe you won't suffer too much."

Dauphin made a quick count. Ten of them, and each a battle hardened veteran, if she was any judge. She probably wouldn't be able to survive if she tried to fight her way free, but then she knew that she couldn't trust them with her life; all her life she'd been told stories of their duplicity and cruelty, as a child they had served as bogeymen to scare her into obedience.

Now those self-same bogeymen were made flesh, and their fingers were flexing over the grip of their glaives. No way to stall them - she had to decide now.
11111.title: Surrounded

111111.content:
Well, there was no other choice, thought Dauphin, she took one footstep forward toward the leader, raising her hand holding the bottle... and... suddenly the bottle disappear from her hand. The last thing explainable she saw was pieces of glass and liquid wetting her hands, several explosions boomed around her, blood sprayed everywhere, cut-off heads fell on and around her....

She couldn't do anything except scream and scream, until everything stopped suddenly, it became too quiet, no sound except the dripping of monster's entrails.

A funny voice said, "Is every thing okay? Sister?"

A tall man, with a bushy beard wearing a teri-belt holding all kinds of weapons she knew, was standing infront of her, his face barely showing between his beard and long hair. He continued with a frown, "Ooooh! Listen lady, it's your choice from now, okay, I helped you from these monsters here because you looked like you can't even fight a cat, now, do you need my help or are you just going to stand there silently? They called me short tempered Brachio...."
111111.title: Not your view of a hero!

choices: She inserts the fork in his butt!
1111111.content:
"Very well," he said, "that's more comfortable to me, but I cannot leave you alone like this, so please accept this from me."

He gave her a pitchfork!

"Use it carefully... and next time, if I saw you handling a dangerous thing like that to enemies, I'll make sure that I blow your head up before I do with the battle... have fun..."

He turned... and walked away...

"But sir," said Dauphin.

His answer was a long loud fart!!!!!! Dauphin felt angry....
1111111.title: Go away

choices: One of the attackers is still alive but mortally wounded
Someone else is on the path
11111112.content:
Dauphin knew that he wasn't worth the bother. True, he had saved her life, but she was by nature a loner and associating with any other, especially one as bad natured as him, would simply be asking for trouble. Hers was a difficult path and therefore it was one that she walked alone. Such was the way of her world.

"You're all I have left now," she muttered softly to Abraar, her faelan. "I wish I did not have to ask as much of you as I do, but we must journey on. We are not welcome in this city so we must find another stronghold to seek refuge in for now."

Abraar whinied softly, understanding every word his mistress had spoken and showing his support for the move. It was far better to keep on the road than standing anout in weather such as this: who knew when the storm might get better or worse.

At that moment, both rider and horse heard a noise. Frozen, Dauphin tried to determine the source.
11111112.title: All that is left

111111121.content:
Dauphin could hear the rustling and gurgling sound coming from one of the attackers. With one quick leap she was on the man, dagger drawn. As she rolled him over she could tell the wounds were mortal.

"Finsh me," the man gasped.

"No. It's not that easy poor soul: first I want to know where Thamor is?"

"Never, you wretched wench," the assassin gasped as blood spewed out of his mouth.

"If that's the way you want it," Dauphin said, as she stuck her gloved thumb in one of the man's wounds.

"AAAGGHHHH.... AAAGGGHHHH... Oh,ughh, please stop, I do not know, please believe me."

She could tell the man was a simple grunt, so
Dauphin brought her dagger up and with one swift well practiced move, sent the assassin to his god.
111111121.title: Grizzly work of it

choices: They realised they don't have money
1111112.content:
Dauphin bowed her head slowly....

"I guess that means you accept?"

"......"

"Besides, if they got the bottle, I was gonna kill you first."

Dauphin shivered.

He said, "Don't worry, young lady, I won't do it now... but you are supposed to be stronger than that, and refuse.... Now, let's get going.... Where were you going anyway?"

She said, wondering what kind of a hero is this, "North."

The strange man took a small knife like object and threw it at her, "And you gonna need this."

Dauphin couldn't hold the knife, so she injured herself, so he shook his head in emotion and said, "What a pity," and started walking....

"Wait a minute!" she screamed, "I need to do something about this cut, I might catch a disease, the knife is dirty, and, and all these dead bodies around here and the flies. Hey.... Sir!!"

He continued walking with no response, so she ran after him calling, "Sir please," he stopped and turned at her suddenly,

"AARGGHHH! Why can't you just wait for some time?
My home is nearby and we are gonna pass it anyway to go north, my wife knows these things, she might help you, she studied medicine before the war. You just calm down! Sheeesh! You are worse than my own daughter!"

After she heard that, she felt more comfortable, calmed down and walked silently....

She looked at the man beside her... weird person.... Maybe he is 40 years old.... Maybe.... And why all those types of weapons?

She accompanied her thoughts with the act, she said, "Excuse me sir, if you don't mind my curiosity, why are you walking around carrying all these weapons, while your home and family are nearby?"

"I do mind!"

"Ok, sorry."

They walked for some time, till they found a small hut, with a smell that makes your saliva drip.

The guy said, "Hey, how do you know! Care for a meal? They serve some new types of food in this hut, it's called pizza! Wanna try some? I'm hungry...."

It was the first time for her to see him smiling so she said, "Ok," but before they entered, something happened....
1111112.title: A grumpy fellow

111112.content:
Gripping the vial in her fist, Dauphin raised her arm and threw the vial to the ground stomping on it once, hearing the glass give and crunch under her heel. No turning back now. She had to stand and fight, or die trying.

The lead creature snarled and drew the wickedly curved blade at his side. "Burn you! You will pay for your stupidity!" The blade lowered and became level with her head, staring directly down the blade were the hate-filled eyes of the monster. Dauphin had time to imagine that she actually saw flames within those eyes before he bellowed and they fell on her like an avalanche.

Instantly her mind opened up and the familiar feeling of vertigo washed over her as she soared through the levels of Raav. She blinked. Everything became sharper, more detailed. Colors, smells, all of it was richer and more beautiful on this level of concentration.

One of the monsters was practically on top of her, its glaive raised high overhead. Using the unnatural speed granted to her, she side stepped and drew her blade in a single, smooth motion. Time seemed to slow down to Dauphin. She saw the creature bring its weapon down onto the head of another that was coming from behind her at the same time her blade opened a large gap in its belly, spilling its intestines. There was a moist crunch as the glaive tore through the skull, and both creatures toppled to the ground together.

A glaive came stabbing towards her from the side. Dauphin pivoted on her heel and spun again, rolling up the shaft of the weapon. She lashed out with her sword and spun away quickly, not needing look to know that the arm holding the weapon was severed at the shoulder. Parrying another stab, Dauphin allowed herself to rise a few more levels of Raav. She could see a delight in the creatures' eyes as she backed away, parrying and dodging their attacks. They thought she was retreating. Dauphin couldn't help but grin.

Her veins felt both frozen and searing hot in turns. The energy from the higher levels of Raav was coursing through her body now, and it was almost too much for her to handle. She channeled some of that energy into her sword, the blade becoming sheathed in a pale blue flame, and attacked with every ounce of skill she had.

The three creatures in front of her paused in their assault after seeing the flames ignite on her blade, and that's when Dauphin struck. The first one toppled over headless, the head itself landed about a yard from the body. The second began to turn but fell as the tendons behind its knees were severed. It had time enough to look shocked before Dauphin's blade pierced its heart from behind.

The third managed to get away and regroup with the others. Dauphin stood her ground, left foot slightly in front of her, balanced on the balls of her feet. She dragged her blade along the ground in front of her, the fallen leaves and grass combusting from the blue flames, to mark a burning semi circle around her. Dauphin raised her eyes and leveled them at the leader.
111112.title: Smashing the vial

choices: She gets on Sheriza to escape
1111121.content:
Dauphin's eyes, now glowing faintly from the elevated Raav, rose to meet the gaze of the leader. "Your last chance," she growled, making a supreme effort to reason through the violent rage that was consuming her. "Throw down your weapons and I might just show you some mercy."

The leader took measure of her, smiling derisively at the set expression on her face. He barked a command to his remaining subordinates in the guttural language of Cardac. "Khal vit Khalak," he said, gesturing to either side of Dauphin's semicircle.

This creature was no fool. He had taken Dauphin's measure and was ready to counter her deadly skill by making good use of his numerical advantage.

Two of the creatures began edging to Dauphin's left side, two more were flanking to her right. Dauphin knew that the creatures would not be reasoned with. Raising her fingers to her mouth, Dauphin blew a shrill whistle.

In a blur of motion the simbilliants were attacking, this time with the discipline of a well trained fighting force. The leader, in a position of relative safety, was directing their movements. She felt a Glaive bite into shoulder from behind even as she scored a blow against one of the creatures before her. But she was confident. The calculating leader had failed to account for the faelan.

Sheriza came in a flash. Before they knew what had hit them, the winged steed had trampled two more of her assailants.
1111121.title: Sheriza

choices: Go back and try and enter through another gate
Attempt to fly over the walls unnoticed
11111211.content:
Continuing the fight would waste valuable time and sap Dauphin's energy. She knew now, more than ever, just how important it was for to her to get to see the King: the forces of Cardac were everywhere.

As her steed rose into the sky, leaving Dauphin's earth bound assailants behind, she breathed a sigh of relief. Everything always seemed safer whilst up in the air.
11111211.title: Escape

111112111.content:
It would have been so very, very easy to fly over the city walls. Unfortunately Dauphin knew that meeting the King would come down to the matter of trust and she would not be trusted if she entered the city in an illicit manner. She would have to go back and try the gates again.

This time she had something more to offer them. The head of a simbilant, grasped tightly in the fingers of her right hand.
111112111.title: Try, try, try again

11111212.content:
The creatures began to panic, all too aware that now the odds were most definitely against them. Their leader desperately cried out to them to stay, bellowing such oaths that Dauphin was glad she didn't speak the tongue of Cardac.

For all his threats, they were beaten, fleeing into the trees and leaving their sergeant to face the woman and her faelan alone.

Dauphin smiled a litle smile, hoping to cover the fact that she was feeling pretty weak from the blow to her shoulder. Her sole remaining enemy was large, and in her present condition he might actually present a few problems. If possible, she'd prefer it if he were to run with the rest of his squad.

He was made of sterner stuff, however. He screamed a war cry as he charged heedlessly towards her, all his previous calm lost in mindless battle-lust. He fought with two curved scimitars, and it took all of her considerable skill to avoid being decapitated by his strikes.

Then she returned with attacks of her own, and he was hard pressed to fend her off. This was where he would learn what it truly meant to be a warrior. How long had he fought for, she wondered? She knew that they trained them young in Cardac, but she had been fighting all of her life, and her experiences were not drill practices. She had learned through life or death encounters every day since her birth, and no jumped up little soldier boy could beat her. He attacked more hastily and with less skill as the fight went on, doubtless seeing his death in the very near future. When her blade tore across the muscles of his right arm, tipping him to the ground, it semed as if this would indeed come to pass.

Dauphin levelled her bloodied sword at him where he lay. He dropped his second weapon, and looked up at her. There was fear in his eyes, and he was defenceless. She could let him go. But this was war, and there could be no prisoners taken. After what his kind had put her through over the years, did he really deserve mercy?
11111212.title: A one sided duel

choices: Try and disguise yourself as a simbilant
111112121.content:
"Tell me your base and I shall spare you," panted Dauphin, breathless after the exertions of the fight.

"My masters would kill me."

"Is death by their hands any different than death by mine?"

"Yes. My kind truly understands pain."

Dauphin knew he was right. The torture skills of the simbilants were renowned. Nonetheless she had to continue down this track. "So one of those told me," she said, waving her hand towards the fallen. "Look, I'm just one person and a girl at that. You should be grateful to send me to my disposal."

"Due west of here. By the shadow of the hanging rock, we meet twenty minutes from hence."

His eyes clouded over and before Dauphin could react he had thrust himself upwards, piercing himself on the sharp blade of her sword. In many ways it was an honourable death, for it saved both of them from responsbility. Him from betrayal, her from a fallen man's blood on her hands. Soiled as they were already.

"You were a fool, but a brave one," Dauphin muttered. "I would have kept my word and let you walk free."

Twenty minutes was no time. She would never be able to convince anyone of her story and rally support by then.
111112121.title: Honour or death

choices: Find nothing, follow where the others fled
111112122.content:
No. It was a simple as this: if she spared him, he would kill again. He was the enemy so Dauphin could have no mercy. Her blade sliced through his neck, almost beheading him with the intensity of her decision.

Now she had killed an unarmed man, Dauphin knew she had to be equally ruthless with all further decisions. Teeth clenched she set about searching the corpses for clues.
111112122.title: A time of war

1111121221.content:
Lifting the heavy arm of yet another of the fallen, Dauphin fought back her nausea. It was easy to kill, for in many ways it was self defence. It was much harder however to stay with the dead, surrounded by the smell of blood and unseeing eyes staring accusingly on.

She found the ball in the pocket of one of the first to fall, and therefore almost the last to be inspected. It was a cool globe, a mottled gold in complexion, but Dauphin knew instinctively what this was. Standing well back, in case of a booby trap, she tapped a small indented section with the tip of her sword. The globe split open, as it was designed to do, and a holographic map appeared.

Dauphin knew this was a dangerous toy. Unlike normal maps which merely showed the terrain, these also showed the presence of others upon it. Her eyes sought out her current location, found it and discovered the red mark that represented life. Looking elsewhere she could see other specks, not to mention large clusters: in the city, on the paths, in the woods.... Any of these could be legitimate travellers, but any of these could also be the enemy. There was no way to tell, but it was a useful toy nonetheless.

Dauphin had two options now. To use the map to discover the weak points in the city walls, the less defended places where she could better gain access. Or to seek out any other malignant life lurking outside the city walls. Those on the path were much more likely to be legitimate than groups, or even individuals, travelling through the woods.
1111121221.title: A map but more

11111212211.content:
Dauphin knew she had to gain entry to the city and make for the palace to warn them of the imminent danger that approached. The discovery of the globe was just the change in luck she needed, for she would make for the city and use the globe to find a way in.

She whistled for Abraar, and the two of them set off at a gallop, Abraar with his wings tucked as not to draw attention.

As the two reached the outskirts of the city Dauphin dismounted, and used the globe again. once it was opened she looked closer at the city and the outlying wall and towers,

"There" she said to no one in particular, while pointing to the holographic image of a section of wall right below a tower, where she could make out two luminous beings making their way through the wall as if there was a door where Dauphin knew there wasn't.

Dauphin gathered her things and made for the secret passage, but before she did this she turned and whispered in Abraar's ear, at wihch he untucked his wings, got up speed and jumped into the air. Dauphin wanted Abraar to circle the city from above while she entered, through the passage. She knew it was better for her if nobody knew of Abraar in case she had to make a run for it, he would be a whistle away. Dauphin felt along the wall until she came to a thick growth of ivy, which she stuck her hands through and so she could tell where to enter.

Once through Dauphin followed the cobblestone pathway that seemed to continue up a grade. Dauphin knew all paths and alleys led upwards to the center of the city and the palace, but first she had to make a decision.
11111212211.title: Through the wall

choices: Bring the heads to the town and ask entry again
Leave the area and try to find another place to go
1111122.content: Dauphin pointed her flaming sword at each of them in turn and shot a fireball from the end of the sword. With this distracting them she took her sword and did a backswing, cleanly severing the heads of all three.
1111122.title: They are gone

choices: Set out in search of the enemy on the faelan
Set out in search of the enemy on foot
11112.content:
Dauphin knew that merely turning up at the city with the posion bottles would probably result in the guards turning her away again. They would only have her word as to what the poison had been intended for.

However, if she managed to find the other simbilants and use the poison on them it would be a different story. One could not have made it this far alone - there had to be others, and they did not deserve to live. A harsh attitude but sadly the one that had kept her alive for so long in these dangerous times.

Her steed was getting tired however. Maybe it would be best to leave it and proceed on foot, although the faelan certainly gave her a greater advantage of speed.
11112.title: A deadly game

111121.content:
Deciding to search for the rest of the simbillants that had been following her and put an end to her enemy for good, Dauphin swung onto the back of her faelan and took to the air.

Unfortunately, the simillant had been expecting this. Her steed's feet had no more left the ground than the sound of a magical explosion ricocheted off of the surrounding trees. It took Dauphin a moment to realize that the explosion had been centered on her faelan, the unknowing target of a tracking spell. Her last thought as Cardac's unyeilding black fires consumed both herself and the beast was of the city over the ridge.

Without her, it was defenseless.
111121.title: Shot from the Sky

111122.content:
But you can't find them.

So back to the base?
111122.title: Back to the base

choices: Dauphin runs into an armed column heading for the city
1111222.content:
Dauphin cursed her own stupidity. Besides the faelan, she had another perfectly good steed - the horse that had belonged to the poisoner. It might very well be able to lead her back the way it had come as well.

The creature allowed her to mount easily. She turned it to face back the way it had come, coaxed it into motion and hoped it would lead her the rest of the way. She was not disappointed.
1111222.title: More than one steed

choices: Try to beat them to the city and warn the people
11112221.content:
Dauphin heard the approaching force long before they could possibly hear her. They moved without speaking, but the occasional clink of armour and rhythm of hooves was unmistakable. This was not a few weary travellers but part of an approaching army!

From her position behind a row of trees, Dauphin observed in horror. Simbilants and humans moved together and although they wore no national colours their intention was clear. These were no soldiers returning home, but part of an invading force.

She was just one woman, they were thousands.
11112221.title: Evil is abroad

choices: An arrow suddenly thuds into the man's chest
The man suddenly sense the invaders
111122211.content:
The guards laughed again. "An army? On its way here and less than a days' march away? You really are desperate to get inside, aren't you miss?"

Dauphin sighed again. It had been an exhausting ride back to the city gates, and she had struggled to form her report into a coherent argument, even with her fatigue catching up with her. Now the fools thought that she was telling lies!

"Don't you see!" she said, trying one last time, "If you do nothing, they'll cast this city down like it had never been! Cardac has no time for negotiation or surrender, it merely destroys that which gets in its way and moves on!"

"I know a lot more on the subject than you, young missy," the guard captain interjected, jabbing a finger at her. "I served in the front lines during the last war, saw horrors there you couldn't imagine. Picked up a sixth sense there as well, somehow. Fight them bastards long enough and you can learn to sense 'em, know when they're abroad. And I can tell you for a fact -"
111122211.title: Not Taken Seriously

choices: Follow him and see where he leads you
Don't follow the man, go into the city and find Macorizt.
1112.content:
She watched as the man and the beast walked by. Her interest in the man and what he was up to intrigued her. Her blood thirst ran wild as she fought back the urge to kill the man by emptying him of blood. Being a vampire was not what you called easy, and even her Blood-hunger knew what was good and what was not. His was not, AIDS ran through his veins which was what caused her to stay far away from him, even if he did have extreme power he couldn't stop the spread of the virus. She moved from tree to tree sounding as silent as a cat on the prowl. When he stopped at the entrance of the city the two guards came to view, she felt her blood drain. His fingers clicked and what was done was done. The two guards fell to the floor. Dead.

She passed the idea of drinking them clean when she remembered what she was here for. The man leaped over the gate with agility that was beyond human ability. She moved foward, and stared in disbelief. Even magic of the sort was not as powerful as she had seen this man accomplish. She looked at the two body guards laying limp on the floor. She regretted not doing anything to save them but what could she do? His power seemed stronger than hers she not only sensed it, she felt it.

Could it be that he had been turned? Could it be that he was like her?

"That's impossible, I'm the only-" She stopped in midsentence. It could be possible.

She sighed deeply. If he is, then he knows of the one that turned him. Following him now seemed more dangerous then she thought.
1112.title: Two Of A Kind

choices: She stands there, awaiting his demise
11121.content:
As she entered the gates she noticed all the carnage around her. Not only the guards but it seemed that this man wanted everyone dead. She took small steps but kept him in her sights. If he was like her, she needed him. If he wasn't, and was something else totally, she would need to determine the best way to get rid of him before he destroyed all that she knew. Her hunger grew stronger and, with little pity for the fallen soldiers, she grabbed the first one she saw, slowly sunk in her fangs and drank his already cold blood. The taste was horrid but her hunger pains simmered a little. She would require one more feed in order to maintain the strength to inquire about this "beast" she was tracking.

With that she saw a small woman lying there, her head cocked to one side; she could see the emptiness in her eyes. She was happy once... the blacksmith's daughter who had fallen in love with the very same guard that felt sympathy for Dauphin. When she finished feeding on this poor woman, she spotted his movement in the corner of her eye.... He had seen her and was moving in....
11121.title: The sad woman...

choices: Fly just far enough away to escape notice
111211.content:
Dauphin braced herself for a fight. Winsome, her faelan, sensed her readiness and braced himself as well.

A chill swept down her spine. Fear or the wind, she was uncertain which, and both were to be expected on such a night, especially when faced with such an enemy as this.

The simbilliant's approach was slow but purposeful. It had emptied the city in minutes, but now it seemed to have all the time in the world. As the huge form stepped ever closer it smiled. Dauphin steeled herself for battle, readied several potent spells and charms, flashed her deadly canines, tensed her powerful body. Winsome folded back his wings and prepared to charge.

But then doubt crept in. That she could kill the simbilliant she had no doubt, but the need did not seem to exist. The city was dead, and her own purpose here had been to gain entrance and spy out the defenses, not to truly render aid. Killing the simbilliant would alert the master of Cardac to her presence, and if she was no friend to the city, she was certainly no friend to Cardac either, and their power was not something she wanted aimed directly at her. At least, not yet.

"Come, Winsome," she whispered in the faelan's ear, "This battle is not ours."

To her surprise, Winsome relaxed instantly. Faelans were nearly sentient, after all. Perhaps he as well had realized the waste of energy such a fight would be.

She leapt lightly onto Winsome's strong back, settling instantly into a safe, comfortable position behind his wings. With a whistle of triumph that might pass for a horse's whinny, Winsome sprang into the night sky.

Behind her, the simbilliant screamed in fury. It was not intelligent enough to report what it had seen to the armies of Cardac. They would certainly know someone had escaped, but they would never know who, nor how.
111211.title: A Battle for Another Day

choices: The building is intact and empty
The building is a complete ruin inside
1112111.content:
Leaving the screaming simbilliant behind, she guided Winsome to seek out an abandoned castle they had passed on the way to the city. The walls, parapets,and towers had seemed mostly intact, but the gate and gate tower had been destroyed in whatever battle had emptied the castle. She hadn't gone inside, so she did not if there would be any shelter that could afford protection from the elements for the night, but it would not hurt to check.

Winsome landed in the empty courtyard. Even now, days later, she could feel the essence of the brigand and murderer she was seeking. He had passed here three, maybe four days prior. As she dismounted, Winsome snorted in disgust. The faelan was not impressed with the castle grounds.

Dimly lit by the half-crescent moon, she could just make out the shadows of the courtyard. Ten or fifteen pace to her left, the ruins of the gate and gate tower. To her right, some fifty paces from where Winsome had landed, a building that even in the dark seemed mostly intact. Stone, with empty black where the arrow ports and door had been, she could not be certain if it had been a palace or simply some administrative center, a judgement hall of some sort perhaps. To her front, a bit further, sixty paces or so, a long stone wall with several doors. She assumed it had been a barracks. Nothing behind her had caught her eye as they flew in, but she turned and looked anyway. Twenty paces behind her, piles of rubble and twenty paces beyond that, the castle wall. This had been a small place indeed. It most likely had served a single family, a dozen servants, and fewer than half a hundred soldiers.

She turned to stare across Winsome's back at the stone building. Her knowledge of this area's history was incomplete. No storied war or battle came to mind that might explain the devastated gate and empty ruin. Whatever had happened had not been long ago. A single lifetime or less would be enough to account for the random bits of weed, the lack of trees or brush, and the mostly intact structure. With just a bit of work, she mused, it could be made quite livable once again. She estimated renovations would require a team of three skilled masons, half a dozen carpenters, one or two laborers to carry materials and run errands.

"Come, Winsome, Let us search out this building and see if it will accommodate us for the night.
1112111.title: Fly into the nearby mountains

choices: A stranger arrives in the night
11121111.content:
Inside the walls and roof appeared fit and firm, at least as far as she could tell in the darkness. There were no holes in the ceiling above her to let in starlight. It was hard to see clearly, but the walls appeared to still be paneled. Whether or not those walls were stained with dried blood and hardened battle gore would have to wait until the morning. She was in no mood to investigate closely. The staircase in the back was a faint shift in the shadowed interior, so she moved to check the second floor.

The banister was broken in several places, apparently severed through with some weapon. Something in darkness caught her foot on the third stair and she kicked it aside in annoyance. Probably a skull, or a bit of broken armor.

On the second floor she discovered the roof was half gone. Jagged planks, beams, and tiles, the sharp angle of the break, all implied it had been broken from above. A faelan attack or a dragon could have done such damage. Nothing smelled of old fire or charred wood, so probably not a dragon. Fortunately, it was the back half near the stairwell where the break occurred, which explained the odd shifting shadow that had revealed the staircase. Some faint glimmer of starlight, or perhaps the half-crescent moon, had been enough to shift and twist the shadows.

Dauphin led Winsome under the shelter of the remaining roof. She retrieved a blanket from her saddle bag.

"Time to sleep, Winsome."

The faelan tilted its head to stare at her out of one eye. It gave a snot and a headshake, reminding her once again of a horse, although there was nothing horselike about the hardened spine, the sloping back, or the furled wings. Nonetheless, Winsome curled up next to the front wall of the building, well under the protection of the remaining roof and far back in the shadows where no one who stumbled across them before dawn would notice. Wrapping her blanket around her shoulders she settled into the curve of the faelan's body, leaning against it for warm and company. Winsome shifted slightly adjusting to her weight, then laid its head against her thigh. If anything disturbed either one, both would instantly know it.
11121111.title: The building is intact and empty

choices: The castle's magic has transformed her permanently
It's a dream, she's not really awake yet
A man appears on the staircase
111211111.content:
Dauphin awoke with the first hint of sunrise. She had dreamed of some place that in her dream she had called, "home," but it was unlike any place she had ever seen. There had been a family around her. Her mother had been tall and willowy, slim and elegant, with a grace to her every movement that spoke of dancing sunlight or sparkling water. Tall, firm but not muscular, her father had carried himself with the air of a scholar, or perhaps a wizard. Two sisters, both younger than she, but as her eyes opened their names vanished.

What an odd dream.

Winsome felt her move and lifted his great head, twisting so he could study her through both eyes. She could have sworn he blinked, but faelan did not blink.

Then she noticed her hands. They were no longer dark and hardened from years of fighting. Soft, cinnamon brown, with carefully trimmed natural nails. Shocked, she stared at them, her mind suddenly blank.

"Winsome?"

The faelan snorted. Clearly Winsome still knew her, even if she did not know herself.

Her arms were covered in heavy travel wool. Dark green in color like something a forest ranger might wear. She still wore breeches rather than skirts, and they were made of the same dark green wool. Around her waist a heavy leather belt with two broad hunting knives.

A second shock, then, catching her completely by surprise. She had no blood hunger. Running her tongue across her teeth revealed a third shock, she had no fangs.

Somehow in the course of the night she had become human. Her hands flew to her head to find her hair cut short and straight. She plucked a few hairs and brought them before her stunned eyes. They were the deep orange-red of the setting sun. At least she was still a woman. That much was a comfort.

"What magic is this? What has become of me?"

Dauphin turned to stare into Winsome's eyes. Then frowned.

"And how is it you still know me?"
111211111.title: Dawn brings a surprise

111212.content:
The beast drew closer until she could see his smoldering red eyes burning in his bone-white face. His body was wreathed in shadow, and his body covered in black-green scales. She could hear the slithering of his thick, scaley tail as it dragged along behind his cloak. The smell of death and corruption hung in a palpable cloud around his monstrous form and she felt herself growing weaker as he began to drink her life away.

"Back!" she cried, thrusting her dagger into his reptilian chest. The creature hissed, a forked tongue flickering out from between his white lips. "He's smelling me!" she thought with a thrill of horror. The dagger grew hot in her hand; the steel began to twist and writhe like a pale worm. With a shriek she dropped it and launched herself onto the monstrosity, sinking her small, sharp teeth into his neck. Black blood filled her mouth, gagging her. The beast gave a roar and clawed her with his nails, renting the soft flesh of her face.

"I'm dying," she thought dimmly.
111212.title: Corruption

choices: Dauphin regains consciousness and finds herself in the watch tower of the city
Dauphin finds herself inside the city, in the middle of a fierce battle
1112121.content:
She was already sinking into oblivion and her vision blurred. Dauphin could see the hazy outline of the monster drawing closer to where she was lying, helpless. She felt the searing pain of the deep slash on her pale face by the venomous claws of her adversary. All she could do was to wait for her doom when she saw the hideous monster raised its huge scaly claws and without warning sunk it deep to her chest and through her heart.

Dauphin opened her eyes, unbelieving that she was still alive. There was not a trace of blood on her body and no pain or even signs of the cuts she had receive from her struggle with the monster.

"Where am I? Is anybody here?"

She felt a little dizzy when she stood up. She noticed that she was in a place with only darkness around her but amazingly she could see herself because of the immaculate light that was surrounding her. She jumped back when all of a sudden a spiraling gold and silver light materialized before her. She had to shield her eyes because the light was so blinding and when she was sure it was safe to look again, she slowly lowered her protective hands from her face, only to see the scaly monster, with its dragon like wings and huge sharp claqs, she had encounterws when... she was confused. She didn't know if it was right to say, "When she was still alive" because she didn't feel like she was dead.

"There must be an explanation! Where am I?! What is the meaning of all this?"

She withdrew when the monster advanced one step towards her.

She could feel a strange feeling inside her. She felt warm and... and light. She thought she saw a spark of blue and green light on her palms and it was guiding her... guiding her to....

The monster launched itself at her, claws menacingly directed to her and it was releasing a blood chilling screech from its throat. At that same instant, her hand brought itself protectively before her in an act of protecting herself and a blinding blue and green light blasted the monster off the ground and hurled it a hundred meters away from her. The impact was so strong that she felt the ground beneath her, if there was any (she wasn't sure), quake that sent her off-balanced.

Her vision blurred but image after image she couldn't decipher flashed before her and voices she recognized as from the head of the city on siege shouted in her head. It had to stop because it was driving her crazy!And, when she thought she couldn't stand the torture any longer, the images stopped flashing and the voices ceased shouting.

"You've passed the test! You didn't fail us Dauphin and now you must go back to where you should be... to the city and to its people who await your return.."
1112121.title: The test

choices: Try asking at one of the many taverns
Wander the streets for a while
11122.content:
Dauphin knew that following the creature would be a waste of her resources - she was tired and the priority was to find Macorizt. However she would keep an eye out for it in the days to come - it was not forgotten....

Mounting her faelan once more Dauphin was able to sail over the city walls with ease. She had tried the official way in, but for now she would have to be unofficial, an intruder. The city was vast: one extra inhabitant was unlikely to go noticed.

Following her instincts Dauphin headed South, towards the city's old quarter. Macorizt had always liked to live with a certain style so it was the natural place to begin.
11122.title: The search for Macorizt

111222.content:
Dauphin wandered the streets for a while. She was still on top of her faelan, and as she rode the cobblestone streets of the city, she received strange looks from the few inhabitants that still walked the streets. Some particularly looked at the creature below Dauphin. Surely these people had seen a faelan before!

Back at her homeland, faelans could be seen practically everywhere, and were not made that big a deal of. Dauphin herself took care of many faelans.
111222.title: Wandering the streets

choices: Dauphin is here to kill him
Dauphin tells him she wishes to defect
1112221.content:
Macorizt opened the door without any bidding. Just as Dauphin had used her senses to find his house, he could use his to sense her coming. It was their way.

"Salutations master."

"You live well, half breed," Dauphin replied, her eyes scanning the well decorated abode. In a time of war it was quite extraordinary.

"I have made my choices. I know which side I am on."

"Cardac's."

"Yes, the man who will win. You know this as clear as I. And yet still you resist."

"I back what is right. Not what is convenient."

"So, why are you here today?"
1112221.title: The enemy

choices: They arrive back at the gates unharmed
112.content:
With the air of confidence of one who is well used to caring for herself the girl progressed along the path. The sound of hooves had stopped - the other rider was obviously equally aware of her presence.

Rounding a bend, Dauphin came face to face with a tall dark haired man, obviously injured, sitting by the path. He was obviously prepared for trouble as his eyes followed Dauphin watchfully although he had no visible weapon to hand.

"Are you alright sir?"

"A girl! What are you doing travelling round at this time of night? A sorceress perhaps."

"A fellow traveller like yourself. But you don't look as well."

"Well you wouldn't look so good if you'd been thrown from a horse."

During this exchange the man appeared to be less suspicious. He probably still didn't trust her, but he had estimated her as a weaker opponent in a fight anyway. If you're expected an armed attacker a young girl is always a relief.

"Can I help you at all?"

"Well, unless you have a spare horse...."

Dauphin spreads her hands to indicate that she only had the one animal.

"Where are you travelling?" she asked.

"The city."

"Then let me help you there."

Dauphin offered her hand to the man. He stood with some difficulty and Dauphin had time to observe that for someone supposedly thrown from a horse his wounds looked suspiciously like those of battle. However, he was clearly injured and in need of help.

Seeing that the man could barely walk, she helped him onto her faelan and led the creature back towards the city. All this going to and fro was beginning to get tiring!
112.title: The path need not be a lonely one

choices: Stay with the captain as he may still need help
Make your own way through the city
1121.content:
With an injured man to watch over and leading a faelan, the girl would have proved quite a sight to anyone watching. It was a pity she had not any old horse, or else she could have let the man ride the animal, but faelans were so notoriously difficult with strangers that it was easier to keep her steed under tight control. In this uncomfortable manner the two of them finally arrived back at the same gates that Dauphin had left some time earlier.

This time however the reactions were slightly warmer. Guards straightened on sight of them, and when identification was asked for in a much more respectful tone and provided the gates were opened.

"Welcome back captain," spoke one of the guards respectfully.

"Well, what are you waiting for girl? If you're coming in I'd be quick about it," said the injured man, pointing into the city.

The guards made no move to stop Dauphin as she moved through the gates,. Her entry had been approved by someone of much higher rank, so in return for lending a helping hand she now had entry to the city
1121.title: A helping hand

11211.content:
It was very quiet in the city. She just followed the captain. He invited her inside his house and told her she could spend the night in the spare room. When she woke up in the morning, she smelled breakfast. She headed for the door. Outside it, she saw the captain again.

"Good morning. I hope you are hungry?" he smiled.

"Yes... I am," she said.

He was wearing another jacket now. It looked as if he was ready to go somewhere.

"Follow me," he said. He took her to the small kitchen. "Enjoy your breakfast. I have to go now, but I'll be back in twenty minutes," he said.

She was very hungry and began to eat. After she had finished her breakfast she heard the door closing and footsteps in the hall. It turned out to be...
11211.title: Breakfast

112111.content: The girl looked into the hallways to see who had just walked into the house. It was the captain, he was now limping, dragging his right foot. She ran to the captain's aid and helped him into the kitchen, she asked him what had happened. He told her that he had gone to a fellow captain's cabin to discuss the future plans, but the town had been invaded!
112111.title: Captain's hurt

choices: Accompany the captain to the garrison and make yourself of use
1121111.content: "We're not safe here any more," the captain decided, taking control despite his wounded state. "I'll have to report for the garrison, but you're probably best trying to get out of here on that steed of yours as fast as you can. The invaders are unlikely to have sealed off all the ways out of town yet... besides, this is likely to just be a temporary thing, we've got an excellent army. I just want to make sure you're safe."
1121111.title: Fight or flee

11211111.content:
"I am trained in the art of war. There may be a use for me, even if it is just helping with the sick and the wounded," Dauphin told him, careful not to make her skills sound too grandiose. To offer something he knew she was capable of was far easier, even if she had to bite her tongue to make herself do so.

"Grab your things then. You have one minute before we must leave," the captain pronounced.

"All I have of value I wear on me now," Dauphin declared, eager to leave.

"Then let's go."

They hurried out of the front door, scanning the streets for danger. Those that dared walk the streets were in a hurry, either towards or away from the action, where the sounds of war carried from the east. Dauphin could see a large plume of smoke rising and could guess that fire was already being used on the city walls. As they were stone it should have no effect on the walls themselves, but if the shields were breached then it could have a devastating impact on the life within. It reminded her so much of what had happened in her own home that a shudder ran involuntarily down her spine.

"Afraid?" The captain missed nothing.

"A little. But it will not turn me from my duty."

Silently, they both headed East.
11211111.title: Under siege

choices: They successfully seal the breach and everything is safe again.
Disaster strikes and the tables are turned!
112111111.content:
The smell of smoke and a terrifying scene greeted them as they finally reaches the action.

A boy yelled at them "Captain! The attackers have been confirmed as-" suddenly he collapsed and they saw the arrow sticking out of his back. A loud war cry confirmed the worst. The attackers had breached the walls. Suddenly the sky was thick with arrows and they would have died had the captain not pulled her behind a wall. "What in the name of! How did they breach the walls?" The captain cursed. A hole in the wall was now flooded with attackers, all heavily armed.

Allies were being pushed back so Dauphin didn't waste a moment. She sprinted into the fray, her sword slowly changing from silver to crimson as she hacked down anyone who got in range. The captain brought out a great sword but it was obvious that he was injured and he couldn't fight well. Even so, his mind wasn't bogged down by his injuries and so he commanded the troops and slowly they pushed back the flow of intruders.
112111111.title: They reach the garrison

112111112.content:
From the shadow of a small alley, the only cover available, Dauphin and the captain surveyed the city street. A barricade had been assembled, hastily thrown together by carts and junk being piled up. The people behind it were no doubt terrified residents rather than enemy soldiers, but it was still a sizeable obstacle.

"Can we go round?" Dauphin asked the Captain, relying on his local knowledge.

"We can... but it'll take us closer to the enemy. I don't know how much of the Eastern Quarter has been breached."

"Well it's that or hope they recognise us as friends and don't try and kill us as we cross the barricade."

"I'd rather die at the sword of an enemy than have to risk harming my own people."

Just then, a large explosion echoed from close by, to the East.
112111112.title: Barricades

1121111121.content:
"I'd rather be in my homeland, before it was taken, sipping tea," Dauphin said ruefully, "But since both options are bad we might as well go for the worst one. Even if we do not get to the garrison we will see battle soon enough and serve our purpose."

"Wish you had stayed in the cellar?"

"Not at all. This isn't even a proper attack yet."

Another great explosion shook the earth around then. The Captain raised a sardonic eyebrow, "Really?"

"Yes, really. If it were the city would be on fire. It's what happened in Levefan."

"You were in Levefan? Through the siege?"

"Yes. It is from there I came when the city fell, with a message to your King. If we live out this day I would ask that you assist me to deliver it still."

They both fell silent as they peeked round a tight corner. The sight that met their eyes was an empty street, but there was an atmosphere that both caught. Something evil, something wrong and out of the ordinary.

Dauphin saw it first.

A darting glance of red in one of the doorways. Just a second's glimpse and then it was gone.

"We are not alone. And it is not human."
1121111121.title: We are not alone

11211111212.content:
The shrill ducked back into the empty house.
It giggled to itself.
*that human is quite observant to have seen me*

The creature glanced again and saw the human had not moved.
*playing a waiting game are we?
If she knows what i am...then she is cautious.
As she should be...*

Dauphin stared at the house.
She did not know what resided in that residence, but it reeked of decay and death.
She did not want to face that thing...not with a wounded captain with her.

The shrill looked again.
*yes....
Doubt yourself...
Come out of hiding....
It is then you will learn the true meaning of fear...*

Dauphins mind raced.
Should she leave...
Should she stay?
She had to make a choice......
11211111212.title: i am patient

112111112121.content:
The shrill kept peeking....
*you want to move...
I can feel it in the air...
You're going to move...*

Dauphin made her choice.
"Captain, whatever that creature is...we can't face it.
we have to move!
We'll double back to the barricade and try to get through there..."
He nodded.

The shrill exited the house.
*well done!
You avoided me...*
A voice echoed from the street.

"What in hell is that thing?"
The shrill turned to see a couple men in the street.
* I am not a thing...
I am a shrill...
A bringer of death!*

The shrill lifted its arms and a dark mist enveloped the two men.
When the mist disappeared, nothing was left save for a large pool of blood.

The shrill walked away.
Shrills never spoke....Shrills never smiled.
They only walked the earth in their blood red clothes...
Bringing death and sadness wherever they went...
112111112121.title: delayed judgement

choices: The house is entered by invaders
1121112.content:
"We must go, now," Dauphin decided, her instincts telling her to move and assess the situation.

"It's too late for that," the captain replied from between teeth clenched with pain. "They are everywhere and I am in no fit state to defend you. I have a small cellar, designed for such occasions. Better we retreat there and hide for now."

Dauphin knew she would never escape on her own. She did not know the area, whilst he did, so she had no choice but to follow down the narrow stone steps into the cellar.
1121112.title: The cellar

choices: Use your mind controlling powers to brainwash him
Duck and run out the door
112112.content:
As Dauphin looked up, her eyes met a man, that could not possibly live on this earth with such a face. It was scarred beyond belief. Chunks of his hair were missing, and the rest was matted and filthy. His nose was all crooked and bent, and he had a diagonal gash for a mouth, which twisted horribly as he spoke the next few words.

"Where is he?" His voice sounded old, and as if it was full of marbles. Dauphin detected fury in his voice, and she drew back.

"I'm afraid I don't know what you mean, sir," Dauphin stammered.

"Don't lie to me woman!" the man shrieked, "I saw you. I saw you last night at the fort gates with him! I saw you, I saw you!"

He seemed furious beyond belief. Dauphin suspected he was talking about the captain, but she decided not to say anything, in case he was after him to kill him or something.

The man seemed to realise this, because he drew out a dagger from his tattered robes, and in a deadly whisper he said, "I know you know where he is. Now tell me!" he said this while brandishing the dagger at her. Dauphin frowned.

"I've already told you, I don't know who you're talking about."

This touched a nerve. The man let a out a loud cry, and he lunged at Dauphin with the dagger.
112112.title: The murderous stranger

1121121.content:
Dauphin sighed, she hated doing this, but there was no other choice.

Suddenly the intruder cried out, dropped his dagger, and stumbled to a chair.

Dauphin got up from her breakfast lazily and walked over to the chair. She looked him straight in the eye, "Who are you?"
1121121.title: Powers

choices: The captain is not encountered and attacked
11211211.content:
Other then his mouth, he was paralyzed and could not move. He took slow deep breaths even though air did not come easy and it hurt to do so.

"Selnok! Selnok," he gasped. "Aid to king Cardac and
a colonel in his army."

Dauphin cocked her head and looked so deeply into his eyes he felt she could see his soul.

"Why are you here?" she inquired.

"To seek revenge."

"Whose?" Dauphin asked.

"My own personal revenge." He wanted to avert his gaze from Dauphin's face but could not.

"Seeking revenge against whom?"

"A Captain, whose face I will recognize as soon as I see it again"

"What else?" she asked the intruder.

"And to seek the location of Cardac's daughter."

"Cardac does not have a daughter", Dauphin snarled at him with as much conviction as she could muster.

"Ah, but indeed he does my sweet," purred the intruder.
A shiver went Dauphin spine. What she had suspected for some time now was true. She did not like it but she would have to learn to live with it.

"Well, I am sorry to say there will be no revenge today sir," Dauphin said. "Up!" the intruder popped to his feet standing straight as a steel rod. "Out!" the intruder went to the door and stepped though it, into the streets of this city he did not know. Nor could he go back or ask directions for Dauphin had rendered him conveniently mute.

She had to find the captain and quickly.
11211211.title: Revelations

112112112.content:
She had set out to look for the Captain and, as she walked across the yard towards the headquarters' lodge, she heard a whompf, then the sound like an electric arc!

She walked closer to the western wall of the city.
"Guard!, Guard!" She yelled to guard standing near top center of the wall. He recognized her from the earlier encounter. "Can I come up for a moment?"

"I would not advise it Miss."

"I might be able to help."

"The stairs at the end on the right."

She rushed to the stairs and took them at a run. She ran over to where the guard was crouching and peered
over the wall. She could smell the scent of ozone. "Do
have anything metal, solid and highly polished? she
asked.

"The door on the guard hut"

"Take two guards with you, remove the door off it hinges and bring up here."

He took off in the direction of the stairs, soliciting
two guards for help as went.

It took them a couple minutes but they returned with the door. They started to make their way back to there Dauphin was crouched. "Grab some cable" she shouted.

As they hit the top the one of the grabbed a length of cable and slung it over his right shoulder.

They made their way across the wall. When they reached Dauphin they leaned the door against the wall.

"Loop the cable though the handle, Dauphin said. "Hurry the wall may go soon."

"Okay take down a little further where they have Zurethan generator aimed and lower it over the wall, concave side out."

They took the door down and slowly lowered it over the
wall. The Zurethan streak reflected right back toward
the generator and seconds later it exploded.
112112112.title: Attack one

choices: "I'm going to need to ask you a few questions."
"I think you had better run, guards will be here soon."
11211212.content:
"I'm… No! I can't…ARGH! WHAT ARE YOU!" The man growled as he leaped from the chair and lunged for Dauphin. She side-stepped him and he landed heavily on the floor. "I asked you a question and I expect it to be answered," Dauphin said, as she grabbed him by the collar and flung him back into the chair.

Suddenly the captain walks in. Dauphin instantly released his mind and turned to look at him. "Do you know who this guy is? He just barged in here demanding to see you," she said. He frowned as he looked at the mans scarred face. "No, I can't remember anyone like this. Anyway, you sir are under arrest for breaking in." the captain said as he shoved the man up to his feet. "You're a demon! A DEMON I SAY!" The scarred man cried, his spittle fling everywhere. Dauphin was mentally struck by that comment. The man didn't know how close he was to the truth.

"And as for you young lady," The captain said.
11211212.title: He fights her powers.

choices: She goes back for the faelan
1121122.content:
The man overbalanced with his wild swing, falling across the table. He was nimbler than he looked, however, as he was already on his feet and pursuing her as Dauphin made a break for the door.

His gnarled hand caught the trailing end of her cloak, and she was forced to relinquish it in order to escape from him.

As she sprinted out into the unfamiliar streets of the city, her thoughts briefly returned to her faelan...
1121122.title: Out and About

11211221.content:
Dauphin didn't see the man as she careened into his chest at high speed. She jumped back, ready to defend herself this time, but saw that it was only the captain.

"Where are you off to in such a rush?" he asked her.

Almost as if to save her the trouble of answering, the dagger-wielding man was behind her again, a scream slicing through the air.

"Oh..." The captain attempted to interpose himself between Dauphin and the attacker.
11211221.title: We Meet Again...

112112211.content:
The captain was clearly an experienced military man, so Dauphin left their defence in his hands. Besides which he sword was upstairs in her room, a mistake she would not make again in a hurry.

Standing as far out of harms way as still to be of assistance, Dauphin watched and hoped for a speedy resolution. She was not to be disappointed.

Panting slightly, the scarred man bellowed, "Give it over and I shall let you both live!"

"Give what over?" Dauphin wondered aloud.

"Why the treasure he stole of course! It's mine!"

Unexplainedly, given the circumstances, the captain began to laugh.
112112211.title: Stolen Treasure

11211222.content:
There was no way Dauphin could leave her faithful steed behind, not after all they had been through together. As she dashed down the street she was aware that the maniac was no longer pursuing her, chosing instead to stay in the house and no doubt wait for the captain's return.

Slowing to a trot Dauphin ran through her memories of the previous evening. She had tied the faelan in a small yard behind the house, as there were no stables. It had been surrounded by high walls, so had seemed reasonably secure, but the kitchen windows looked right out into it. Even if she could scale the walls she would have difficulties in not being spotted, but at least once she had her steed she could fly out. That was one advantage in having transport with wings.

Accepting that a return was inevitable, Dauphin circled around looking for the yard. Discovering what she thought was the right wall she dragged over some nearby crates and hoisted herself over.
11211222.title: Never leave anything behind

112112221.content:
Dauphin vaulted over the wall, landing badly but safely on the other side. Her ankle hurt, but it was walkable on.

Amazingly, Dauphin's arrival seemed to have missed detection and the faelan was alone and unharmed. Unfortunately, Dauphin quickly discovered why. From inside the house she heard a loud crash and glanced over in time to see the deformed man grappling with the captain through the open doorway.
112112221.title: Into the melting pot

choices: Dauphin and the captain win the fight
The deformed man wins the fight
1121122211.content:
Dauphin rushed into the house, her hand on her sword. Yet she did not dare risk drawing it, knowing that in such close confines she could just as easily hit either man. Indeed, there was not very much she could do but keep out of the way for as long as it looked like the captain was winning.

The deformed man had other plans. With a ferocious snarl he lunged for Dauphin.
1121122211.title: Fight for your life

choices: "Well maybe I can help you with that."
"Fine but try not to get into any more trouble."
11211222111.content:
He lunged for Dauphin and caught her off guard. She drew her sword but he grabbed her sword hand and grappled with her for the blade. Unfortunately for him, Dauphin still had a few tricks up her sleeve including her "unique" skill set. She jammed her knee hard into the man's chest and head butted him with brutal force. He stumbled back and she slammed her shoulder into his chest. Suddenly the man pulled out his dagger and stabbed at her. Luckily the captain was back on track and punched the scarred man in the face. He stumbled and then turned to the door and started running away! "ARGH" His cry rang out and Dauphin and the captain rushed out to see what happened. They found a proud faelan standing with an unconcious man laying on the ground.

"So, what are you going to do now?"

"I need to meet the king, I have important news for him."

The captain put on a puzzled look and then said
11211222111.title: Victory!

choices: Dauphin is arrested for the murder of the captain
Dauphin helps in the hunt for justice
1121122212.content:
"He's a captain of the guards, he can handle himself better than I can," Dauphin tried to convince herself, knowing she would only get in the way. Better to fly away and alert the authorities.

Dauphin quickly found the nearest guard station and informed them of the situation. With a group of six guards she rushed back to the house, to discover it empty and covered in blood. Of the deformed man there was no sign, but her own sword was in the kitchen, not in her room where she had left it, drenched in blood.
1121122212.title: Blood, sweat and tears

11211222121.content:
"The deformed man must have vanished with him. Quick, we need to find him!" she declared, noticing that most the guards were staying put within the house.

"All in good time," replied the leader, forcing Dauphin to wait for fifteen minutes.

In due time a messenger came in and report to the guard in charge. Frowning deeply, he turned to Dauphin and pronounced, "No one nearby has seen a deformed man. Or anyone, for that matter, coming and going from this house except for the captain and you."

"But we must find them!"

"I am afraid not. We are placing you under arrest for suspected murder."

And with that the remaining six guards closed in on Dauphin.
11211222121.title: Falsely accused

choices: They report her to the guards as a suspected spy
112112222.content:
Dauphin landed gracefully, but a second later found herself with a sword at her throat. Thoroughly expecting the deformed man, she was surprised to find instead a young girl, probably about the same age as herself. This disorientated her completely until she glanced around and realised her mistake: she was in the neighbouring yard to the one she had been aiming for.

"Father! Quick, there is an intruder here," the girl called out cooly.

"Look, I can explain...."
112112222.title: Mistakes

choices: Dauphin uses her magic to get by
11212.content:
The city was obviously proving to be the destination of choice for any number of refugees. As Dauphin forced her way through the unwashed crowds bustling through the shanty town that had been set up in the space between the main wall and the city proper, she realised why the guards had been so reluctant to let her in. As it was, should the city be attacked the defenders would lose the killing zone they would have had when the attackers broke the walls, and the refugees would lose their lives. It looked like she had one more thing to talk of with the settlement's ruler.

That was, if she ever reached the city's king. She was making slow progress through this sea of humanity's dregs. It would be so much easier if she could part the crowds before her, and she knew that she had the power within her. Of course, such a vulgar use of her abilities would not be without cost.

Then again, she really would like to get to the town sometime in this week.
11212.title: The Huddled Masses

choices: Dauphin stops and speaks to the person
112122.content:
Dauphin decided discretion was for the best, even if the crowds depressed her so. People were dying in the streets from wounds, with only the smallest sign of medical assistance. The sides of the road was literally littered with the dying, desperate for any help.

"Spare some change madam?"

"My son is dying, please help me."

The cries echoed in her ears as Dauphin forced her way on, trying to steel her heart against the horrors surrounding her.

"Hey, I know you!"
112122.title: The masses

choices: Trust his story and ask him to accompany you
1121221.content:
"I doubt it," Dauphin replied listlessly. Her looks had changed so much in the last few days her own parents would not recognised her, if they were both still alive. Nonetheless, she glanced over at the man just in case.

"Avernique?"

"The very same," he grinned at her. "And you're right, it's not you I recognised but the creature of course. Don't see many of those in these times."

"But... how did you escape the siege?"

"I was injured and presumed dead. Ended up here with a whole bunch of other refugees once the city had fallen."
1121221.title: Avernique

11212211.content:
"Are there others?"

"Some. But far too few," Avernique replied, his brown eyes troubled. For a moment he looked younger than his years and curiously vulnerable, lost in a foreign land, a stranger from his homeland. Dauphin, on the other hand, would not dwell on the past for now. It was too painful and wallowing in self pity would achieve nothing at the end of the day.

"I go to the palace. Those there deserve to know our fate, as it may soon be theirs."

"I hate to break this to you, but I've already tried. The guards don't want to know. Sure, they've seen a few of the important and the first refugees, but there are hundreds of us."

"But my news is truly important!"

"That's what everyone is saying."
11212211.title: News can be a bad thing

choices: Keep it in your pocket until you discover more
11212212.content:
"But what of Petroma, Febeous and Teraya? Did they survive?" Dauphin pressed.

"I... I can not tell for sure. Febeous fell, for I was by his side at the time the walls were lost. But the other two were not nearby and their fates are unknown to me," Avernique said, his voice breaking with pains of the past. "I saw friend after friend lie dead. But know this Dauphin I am no coward. When I awoke, dazed and wounded I would have risen and carried on until the death if it had not been for Febeous parting words to me. He told me to give you this, if I saw you in this life or the next."

Avernique held out a small parcel of finest parchment. Dauphin unwrapped it, discovering a tiny silver charm in the shape of a griffin wrapped within. There was no message.

"And this is all he sent?" she asked, confused.

"Yes."

"And you know of no one else out of our friends who is left alive?"

"No one."
11212212.title: A charm

1121222.content:
"I doubt it," Dauphin replied listlessly.

"Of course I do. How could I forget the bitch that murdered my brother?"

As the man lunged for his sword, Dauphin hurried away as fast as she could, aware of his pursuit behind her. Unlike many of the other refugees he seemed able bodied enough.
1121222.title: A murderer?

choices: Oh no! No time to think, have to fight!
11212222.content:
While Dauphin had to push her way throughout the crowd, everyone steered clear of the armed man who was ranting about the person who had killed their brother. Dauphin wasn't heading in any general direction now, instead trying uselessly to escape pursuit. That was how see found herself in a dark alley with no way to go except towards the man.

"I've got you now!" he yelled. "You're going to pay for what you did all those years ago!" he continued.

Dauphin had no idea what he was talking about. She said, "I don't understand, what did I-" But he cut her off. "YOU FORGOT! YOU MONSTER! YOU DESERVE THIS!" He wildly swung his weapon and in the confined space of the alley, his wild raging strikes would beat her because there was no space to dodge, which was a key tactic to her fighting style. She needed to come up with a plan and fast!
11212222.title: Attacked!

choices: Protect yourself and your companion by fighting these thieves
1122.content:
They turned the bend, and Dauphin could feel that something wasn't right. It was very quiet, too quiet. She tightened her grip on the dagger that was hidden beneath her cloak.

"Goin' somewhere?" she turned around to face a man that was short and round. His smile was crooked and his teeth were yellow, just the look of him made bile rise to her throat. He held a pistol in his left hand and if seemed he had followers somewhere behind the trees. She wasn't using her powers it was just the smell of unwashed clothes that reeked. She turned to her companion: his brown eyes looked fierce and determined. Oh no, she thought unhappily, not another fight.
1122.title: Fighting Causes

11221.content:
In rage, Dauphin jumped off her horse and tore one of the bandits' throats open. Blood spewed on to her clothing. She immediately took his mace and threw it to the man she had taken with her.

He jumped off and pummeled a man on the side of his head. His skull cracked then shattered causing a huge gap in his face. He collapesed to the ground. Dauphin immedatly rushed to what seemed to be the leader of the pack.

She swung towards the man. He evaded the swing and countered with his dagger and caught Dauphin across the arm ripping her skin and muscle apart. The pain made her scream. She attacked with the blade tucked close like it was a part of her arm. She swung and the man evaded, he countered cutting parallel to his previous gash. Blood flowed like a river.

Then, the man who she helped slammed his mace in to the leader's back. The force broke his spine in two. Dauphin turned around to find the leader on his knees and walked towards the disabled man. She grabbed his head and removed it from his body.

The leader's followers ran away like frightened puppies.
11221.title: Leaders die sometimes

choices: He takes her to the city
112211.content:
The blood flowing freely from her arm, Dauphin knew that she would not be long for this world unless she got help immediately. Her faelan stood attentively over her, but the man that she had helped was looking at her with a little more doubt in his eyes.

"You just pulled that man's head from his shoulders," he said accusingly. "You're not human."

Dauphin couldn't speak through her pain, but she hoped that her eyes could say enough.
112211.title: Blood and Distrust

choices: The man approaches the city with the girl
The girl awakes in the city
1122111.content:
"I am as human as you are sir," she assured him through gritted teeth. "If I were not do you think I would bleed this much?"

"I am in your debt and as such shall not question you more until your wound has been seen to," the man decided. "Within the city walls you will be cared for, so your wound has time to heal, but be careful for the security there is tight and if you betray my trust in any way it will be your undoing."

Looking at the girl for his response he barely had time to register her swaying before she fell into her arms. The wound was serious and robbing her of consciousness.
1122111.title: Injured but not alone

choices: Explain how Dauphin removed the man's head
The bandits come back for a rematch
11221111.content:
The man put Dauphin back on the faelan and trudged through the mud to the city walls.

"What is your name?" Dauphin said through her enduring pain.

"Akando," was the given reply.

"So what brings you to Willow's Haven?"

"I have a message for one of the soldiers in the city. I was bringing the message when my horse was spooked and threw me."

"Are you married?"

"Why would you wish to know that?"

"I don't know. I guess I am just trying to strike up a conversation."

"I was married." Came the grim reply. "She was killed in a raid made by men who came from the north."

"I'm so sorry!" Dauphin said sympathetically. "Did you have any children?"

"My wife Isabella was seven months pregnant at the time."

Dauphin had never felt more pity for another person then she felt for Akando at that very moment.

"Now it is my turn to ask you a question."

"Ask away." Dauphin replied, for she had nothing to hide.

"How did you pull that man's head off?"
