"Look! There is the city now!" Dauphin exclaimed.
11221111.title: Meet Akando

choices: Akando trusts her, but she is not to be trusted
112211111.content:
"Akando," Dauphin began, "I am from Cardac."

The man drew away from her at the mention of that word, making a protective sign over his chest.

"It was Cardac swine that saw my village burn," he snarled, reaching for his weapon.

"I know, I know the pain that my people have caused." Dauphin coughed, noting the blood brought up. "But I have decided to change my ways before it is too late, save the people of this country from the ravages of my kinsmen."

"And why should I believe you?" Akando sneered. "You savages, with your daemon-gifted strength! I should leave you to bleed! A clean death is too good for the likes of you!"

"I wouldn't blame you if you did. I have done things that I am not proud of, and I probably deserve this fate. But I have news of vital importance that must reach your King. I - huuuk..."

Dauphin collapsed and began spewing. Akando could see that she hadn't long left. While the creatures of Cardac were strong, they were also rather frail.

"You could be an assassin," he suggested.

"Trust. Me."

She locked eyes with him, hoping that he would find some shred of human compassion within himself.
112211111.title: Traitor of Cardac

choices: Dauphin meets Akando at the courtyard
Dauphin decides to explore the city a bit
1122111111.content:
Akando carried the frail Dauphin toward the gates of the city.

"I'll trust you," he whispered, but his words were lost on Dauphin, she had sunken into the world of unconsciousness.

The next morning Dauphin awoke, rather painfully, to the bright golden sun. To her astonishment she found herself in a rather comfortable room. The bed she was lying on felt crisp and clean (something she had grown unaccustomed to), there was a small table to the right of her bed and upon it was a tiny piece of paper. As she took a closer look, scrawled upon it was a little note from Akando. It said, "Meet me in the courtyard at noon, do not worry your faelan is safe with me."

Dauphin slipped out of her bed quietly and took a peek out of the window, "I wonder why Akando wants me at the courtyard, I would much rather explore this city..." she thought.
1122111111.title: To the city

choices: He leads her to the castle.
He leads her to an alley deep in the city.
11221111111.content: "But it might be better to let this wound heal," Dauphin said. Her arm was bandaged but she knew her wound would soon finish healing. Another "gift" from her Cardac heritage.She spent her time thinking about ways of apologizing to Akando about his loss. When it reached noon she walked out and saw his standing in the courtyard. "I think you'd better start explaining yourself," he said. "Fine, I betrayed my country because I've seen too much bloodshed," Dauphin said. Akando laughter and said, "You've seen too much bloodshed? You ripped a grown mans head off and you have the nerve to say you've seen too much bloodshed?" She glared at him and he shut up. "The Cardac army is coming, we have to be prepared! I need to see the king!" She pleaded. Akando was silent for a moment and then said "Follow me."
11221111111.title: Dauphin meets Akando at the courtyard

choices: Mired in self-misery, she falls asleep
11221111112.content:
Willow's Haven was a great deal different from the lands of Cardac, Dauphin eventually concluded.

Despite the unrest abroad in the rest of the country, here all was tranquil. Parents seemed quite happy to let their children run unattended through the streets, as if unaware of or unwilling to acknowledge the terrors that stalked outside the city walls.

The terrors that stalked within it.

Dauphin fought down her distaste for the simple country folk. It was not as she had imagined it. As much as she railed against her father's stifling influence, fleeing from him and his bloodthirsty hordes, she did not fit in here either. Despite herself, she was repulsed by the softness of these people. Not one of them would survive a day in the northlands.

She had hoped that it would be a place of forgiveness, where the sins of her past could be washed clean, but instead she had been assaulted at the very gates by bandits, and forced to kill them to defend herself. The contented expressions of all the passers-by merely forced her to remember how different the expression on her victim's face had been when she had torn his head from his neck...

Fighting her melancholy, she turned from the more used thoroughfares of the city, finding solace in the quieter areas, where she would not be reminded of what she had lost by the happiness of others.

In time, avoiding the comatose drunks and brawling footpads, she found herself truly alone. It was a dead-end alley, filled with the detritus thrown out by a nearby warehouse. Here, she slumped to the ground, alone with her thoughts. As much as she wanted to return to the bed from which she had so foolishly wandered, she could not remember the way.

Instead, she sat herself down and wondered where it had all gone so very wrong.
11221111112.title: Worlds Apart

112211112.content:
They didn't even bother to conceal their approach. The remaining bandits were slighted and they wanted their payback.

"We'll be taking payment for the loss of our friends," the leader, a different man, said raising his sword for emphasis.

"You're not a learned man are you?" Dauphin retorted, trying to hide the pain. "How many more of you want to die tonight?"

"I want the witch for myself." Another man said.

"She's under my protection."
112211112.title: The bandit's payback

choices: Head back towards the city, from another angle
1122112.content:
Unfortunately it was as it had been before. The lesser mortals had an instinctive distrust of those with powers living amongst them. The man had no doubt been brought up in the city, sheltered by stone walls from the ways of the world and the practices that took place in the wild lands beyond. Until now, for no innocence could last forever.

He stormed away leaving Dauphin bleeding. Slowly, she cleared her mind of worries and woes and concentrated entirely on her wound. It was as if time stood still, as flesh melded with flesh until there was not even a scar to indicate a cut had ever been.

It was not so of course. Her mental strength was drained from carrying out the act, even if her physical strength was renewed. She would be less powerful next time, unless she gained rest soon and a chance to regroup her powers.

Dauphin was a mage. This meant she was human, all too much so, unlike some of the other creatures her recent companion had imagined she could be. It was a curse and a blessing to wield magic, especially when distrust ran so deep in her kind's veins.
1122112.title: A curse and a blessing

choices: Dauphin dashes the man aside and mounts up
112212.content:
Dauphin threw her head back, laughing. "That's right, run! Run, you curs! You cannot escape from me!"

Tossing aside the head she had so recently torn from one of the thieves, she made to mount her faelan, to continue her bloodthirsty pursuit, only to find the man she had rescued barring her path.

"What's wrong with you?" he asked. "Are you mad? Are you possessed of a demon?"

She sneered back at him. While she had rescued him in a moment of tenderness, now her blood was up, and she wasn't certain that she wanted to waste any more time with the dark-haired stranger.
112212.title: Bloodlust

choices: Dauphin decides she trusts the warrior
The warrior and the thief reconcile
11222.content:
"Might you have something to give me dear girl, a bauble perhaps," the long toothed peasant sneered his words through the uneven teeth that lined his mouth while his eyes bored holes in her chest.

Dauphin clenched the hidden knife tighter, her sweat making the blackened handle too slippery for a killing grip. She kept her eyes on the yellowed teethed jackal standing before her. Her found warrior, (she decided that the thrown horse excuse didn't jive) was quietly creeping up behind her new vermin friend.

Warrior man had lifted a boulder and was about to smash it on the head of their foe when the louse fell to the ground.

"You killed him?" Dauphin asked puzzled.

"Not exactly, you see I just 'hit' him and he thinks he's dead," Warrior explained patiently although the boulder was still in his hands and the pig robber lay prostrate but clean as a whistle.

Dauphin eyed the stranger she'd helped onto her steed. "How?"

Warrior guy disarmingly asked, "I thought you might ask who (am I) first?"
11222.title: Friend or Foe

choices: Dauphin gains access under her false identity
113.content:
There are some times when a girl has to do whatever is necessary to get her own way. Spotting it was a young gentlewoman, finely dressed and on a beautiful white stallion, Dauphin stepped into the road. She did her best to look as helpless and lost as possible and, as she expected, the other girl stopped.

Knowing that if she tried to start a conversation, she might have regrets about what she was about to do, Dauphin struck immediately. Knocking the girl unconscious was easy, fitting into her long flowing robes less so, but before long Dauphin was changed and ready. She would have to try another gate of course, as the guards at the last gate might recognise her.
113.title: Assumed identity

1131.content:
She showed the papers she had stolen to the guards at the next gate over, and their eyes widened in surprise as they saw the name written thereon. Still, they made no comment as they let her in to the city and she rode into town.

As she passed by on the road, her presence was met with further surprise. Small children playing in the streets darted from the road as she came, young men and women hastily turned away, and the few old people that sat by the side of the road subjected her to raspy incoherent insults. Dauphin began to wonder just what she had gotten into by assuming that woman's identity.

She entered an inn, with the intent to stay the night, when the innkeeper and all the guests fled the establishment on seeing her. Since there was no longer anyone there, she made herself comfortable in one of the deserted rooms, and was soon fast asleep.

She was awoken by the smell of smoke, but as she opened her eyes, the scent vanished. Perplexed, she closed her eyes again, only to be grabbed around the neck by a large fist and lifted into the air.

Her assailant was a large bald man with grey skin. His head was smoking and his eyes were as white as the full moon. "This ends now, Delga," he roared. "Time to make good your end of the bargain."

Dauphin quickly realized that Delga was the name of the woman who she was disguised as. What had she done?
1131.title: A new identity

choices: Attempt to discover who this Delga is
Find your faelan and get out of here
11311.content:
Whoever he thought she was, he had underestimated his opponent's strength. This was not the first time Dauphin had faced extreme danger: she might look small and frail, but living through a war made even the young learn fast. Not giving herself time to think she brought her right arm up, still grasping the small dagger she always slept with under her pillow.

She did not want to kill this man, as she needed to learn more about just who he thought she was. Yet she needed to take control. She sliced across his arm, an easy target, and was releived when he grunted and let go of her head. The respite was not for long though, he had let go so that his focus could now be on her knife arm. The problem of non fatal wounds were that they left your opponent even more murderous towards you.

He lunged for her, using his sheer bulk to attempt to dominate. Dauphin was faster on her feet however and easily dodged the full force of the blow, instead taking a lesser hit. She was armed and he was not and she brought her knife arm around again, feinting at the last moment before wedging it into his shoulder. The wedge had been unintentional, but Dauphin knew it was easier to leave it there than fight over the knife.

"You... are not Delga," the man spat out.

"Taken you that long to figure it out?" Dauphin asked. "Who is she?"

The man was not in the mood for further conversation and lunged once more. His movements were slowed from blood loss however, leaving Dauphin with the much needed chance to swerve round him to her sword. His eyes were on the blade, his body unmoving as she backed out of the room and swiftly from the building. A further fight would have been foolhardy: better to escape while she had the chance.
11311.title: Fighting once more

choices: Kill the guards and take their outfits
Use mind control anyway and gain entry
1132.content:
After obtaining all she needed to enter the city Dauphin once more approached the gates. This time, however, she was met with two different guards holding long spears crossed over the gate.

"Pardon me sirs, but I require entry into the city." Slowly, Dauphin handed one of the guards her papers.

After a moment of gazing over the document, the guard looked up and responded, "This will not suffice, you are not of the right species. It says here that you are Pondorian. But by one look at you, one can clearly see that you are not. How do you explain this?"

Growing impatient, Dauphin reached under her new cloak for her blade. She had lost the desire to manipulate. She was growing thirsty for blood.
1132.title: Nice Try

choices: The guards let the girl inside quickly
She stays and has to fight
12.content:
"Papers."

The girl dug into a pocket and produced the two small cards that held all the information about someone that you could ever need. With the air of someone who travelled quite frequently she approached the small slot in the side of the building and fed the cards in one by one.

Within a couple of seconds, the system had labelled her as harmless. Still, the city did not desperately need many more refugees so the guards prepared to question her further.

"Name?"

"Dauphin..." but before any more words could pass beyond her mouth there was a bright flash of light as the ground a few yards away burst up in flames. An attack!
12.title: You can't get in without a ticket!

choices: The guards give him the girl
121.content:
The girl gasped. "It's an attack!" shouted a guard.

"Let her in quickly!" said the head guard and pressed the button.

With a deep 'zzzzzttt' the field was opened. The girl rushed inside with the faelan in tow, the mount whickering nervously.

"Go on girl, get inside that shelter," pointed a guard, at a low hive shaped structure as the field 'brrrrrd' back up again.

The explosions ceased suddenly and there was a tense silence, punctuated only by the sound of the pouring rain.

Then through the rain came the sound of the thunder of hooves, many hooves this time.

"Riders!" said a guard, as they crouched, gripping their weapons tensely. "Man the catapults" shouted the guard commander, and the ponderous weapons swung up on their pinions, their gunners peering through the driving rain.

Then through the darkness came a rider on a large dark mount. He was large, attired entirely in black armour, his face covered with a black mask bearing the semblance of a skull. A black cape swirled behind him, enshrouding him in an aura of menacing evil. He walked his horse confidently towards the barrier and paused, the mount moving restlessly and tossing its mane. He leant down, "The girl" he said, "We want the girl".
121.title: The Fugitive

choices: The masked rider recommences the attack on the city
1211.content:
Dauphin couldn't believe her ears as the guard captain told the black clad horseman that he was welcome to her.

"Sorry," he told her as he turned his crossbow on her, "but my duty is to the city first and foremost. Way I see it, rather you than us."

The faelan was restrained by several guards and, despite it kicking several to the ground, they managed to tie it down with strong ropes. Dauphin moved to help it, but the captain and several other crossbowmen cut her off and nudged her away.

She had no choice but to comply - she couldn't help her steed if she was peppered with bolts. But she would return, and pay them back for this...

"I will see you again," she hissed to the captain.

The warriors of Cardac moved forward to apprehend her, while their skull masked leader rode closer.

"Thank you for your co-operation. Rest assured, this fugitive will trouble you no more."

The captain, still unnerved by the presence of so many of the enemy, smiled nervously and gripped his crossbow tighter. But he did nothing to help as Cardac's men bound Dauphin by hand and foot with chain.

"The faelan?"

"Oh, the horse beast. By all means, you are free to keep it. Cardac has no need of such things. He has more than enough already, doesn't he, Dauphin?"

He was smiling under that mask, she knew it. But she didn't reply, she wouldn't give him the satisfaction. She was roughly pulled onto the back of a horse, and taken with the rest of the cavalry troop back into the darkness far from the city. There, well out of catapult range, the commander of Cardac turned his steed around to gaze back at the city.

"Really, Dauphin, you could have gone anywhere, and you chose this pit. Your father would have wept."

Again Dauphin didn't reply. The memories were still too fresh.

"Take one last look, Dauphin."
1211.title: Captive of Cardac

12111.content:
The rider stopped and looked at his forces once more.

"Destroy the city," he said, voice cold as ice.

"But they handed me over to you!" Dauphin exclaimed, watching helplessly as the warriors moved back towards the city gates.

"They are weak. I would have respected them more if they had kept you. In showing their weakness they have sealed their doom," the rider responded, carelessly moving away with Dauphin, his captive, left with no choice but to follow.
12111.title: Their weakness is their doom

choices: Ask her to undo your restraints
121112.content:
The journey back to the land of Cardac was a long one, and Dauphin knew that, sooner or later, they would have to stop for the animals' sake at least. Then would be her one small chance of escaping....

"We stop here for the night," instructed the leader, looking over a huddle of deserted farm buildings. With the war the occupants had long gone, moving into the safety of a city.

"Make sure she is properly restrained."

Dauphin was lead into the farmhouse itself and secured in a windowless room. The room was small enough for them not to post a guard inside with her, but there were several outside and she knew there would be regular checks.

Normally this would not have been a problem, as she did still possess some powers. But the guards had made sure they had also attached a small green amulet around her neck. Direct from Cardac its powers were more than enough to negate her weak ones....

"Psssstttttt!!!"

Dauphin could hear the sound, but could not find its speaker.

"The fireplace."

Much to her surprise, in the fireplace there was indeed the head of a small girl hanging down.
121112.title: A Captive Audience

choices: Dauphin hesitates because she doesn't trust the girl.
1211121.content:
Dauphin blinked in surprise and must have had a comical expression on her face because the girl in the fireplace giggled and quickly slapped her hand over her mouth. The slight movement seemed to cause her to lose whatever hold she had on the inside of the fireplace and she tumbled out in a cloud of soot.

"Sorry 'bout that," whispered the girl, standing up and brushing ashes off of her dark green dress. Suddenly she stopped and cocked her head as if listening. Dauphin listened too but heard nothing.

"What is it?" she asked, unable to bear the silence. The girl motioned her to be silent and crept over to the door and put her head against the thick wood. It was only then that Dauphin saw the shape of her ears.

The girl was an Elf! Dauphin had never seen an elf this close up before. Their kind had always lived deep in the forest, keeping to themselves and always avoiding the land around Cardac.

The elf maid finally stood straight and grinned at Dauphin.

"It's okay. They're sleeping," she said, eyes sparkling with mischief.

"What?" Dauphin felt confused and the amulet was beginning to chafe the skin where it touched her neck.

"The guards at the door are asleep. My brother should be here any minute to help us out."

"Well... I hate to break it to you but I'm not going anywhere until these bonds come off."

The elf maid quickly undid the bonds that bound Dauphin's hands behind her back. With relief, Dauphin carefully lifted the amulet of Cardac off her neck and tossed it carelessly in a dark corner of the room.

The elf girl, meanwhile, went back to the fireplace and looked up. After a moment, Dauphin heard a soft slithering sound and the end of a rope appeared.

"Come on," whispered the girl. "The sleep dust doesn't last much longer." She gestured towards the fireplace. "You go first. If they come in I can stall them for a few seconds."
1211121.title: I've got friends in fireplaces

choices: It's the elf-maid, finally caught up
12111211.content:
Bending over slightly, Dauphin grasped the rope and began to climb. Ordinarily, she wouldn't have trusted the girl but she knew that even though Elves were not nesecarily good, they were no friends to the armies of Cardac and that was good enough for Dauphin.

As she got closer to the roof she saw a shadow lean down and hold out a hand. A pair of twinkling blue eyes met hers as she grasped his hand and pulled herself up onto the thatched roof of the farmhouse.

"Come," the shadow breathed close to her ear. "We will speak once we are safe." Dauphin nodded and followed the nimble elf down another rope that let them drop safely to the ground.

The elf grabbed her hand once in the lightless shadows of the house and after a moment, walked quickly forward into the forest. It was a good thing he held hold of her hand because Dauphin could see nearly nothing as the trees blocked out the scant light of the moon.

He stopped suddenly and pulled her quickly behind a tree. She started to ask what was wrong when she heard the soft cry of a bird.
12111211.title: Escape!

choices: They are attacked during the night!
121112111.content:
The silence ticked by slowly. Dauphin reached out with her magic sense to see if whoever following them had malicious intent or not.

Her eyes flew open as the elf-maid walked into a patch of moonlight. "Draell?" she whispered. "What are you standing there for? Let's go!"

"We were waiting for you, Narith. Or should I say O Slow One?" mocked Draell with a thinly concealed laugh.

"Shut up."

The group moved on silently through the trees and Dauphin started to wonder if they would ever stop. Finally they reached a small clearing.

"We will rest here for the night," announced Draell, letting go of Dauphin's hand and striding to the middle of the clearing where a faint patch of moonlight enabled her to see a finely boned face, expresive blue eyes and a quiver of arrows strapped to his back. "This area of the forest is more friendly to us."

It was still too dangerous to light a fire so Dauphin started gather leaves to make a bed under a tree. Narith stopped her, however, with a smile.

"Come," she said, tugging on her hand. "We will sleep in the trees where it's safer."

Dauphin was nowhere near as nimble as the elf girl in climbing up the largest tree in the perimeter of the clearing but she did manage to find a fairly comfortable roost on a thick bough that was a good fifteen feet up from the ground.

Narith found a simlar perch and soon fell right to sleep. Draell stood at the of the tree and watched the ladies settle in for the night, eyes glittering. Quietly, he settled his back against the tree and prepared to face the sleepless night ahead.
121112111.title: Safe at last?

choices: Dauphin flees into the woods to save herself
Dauphin recklessly charges to save the elf
121112112.content:
While the cry that presaged its appearance may have been bird-like, the shadow of the new arrival was anything but avian. The only effect that the minimal light had upon its spindly bulk was to gleam off the metal chains that hung from its lanky limbs. It paced silently closer, its movements making no sound but an involuntary cawing drooled from its unseen mouth.

Dauphin had seen such beasts before, but never up close. The armies of Cardac kept them to watch over their camps at night, for the fiends slept not but after they ate, and the dark ones kept them perpetually starving so that when they came across an interloper they would tear them apart with a frenzied hunger.

The elf moved between her and the monster, but with a dry croak it lashed out, talons opening his chest and dropping him in a heap. Dauphin could barely move when she saw the attacker's face for the first time, its head collapsing open into one massive maw in preparation to feast.

While she did stand horrified, part of her brain was still aware of the fact that it was ignoring her now. If she could only get her feet to obey her, she'd be able to run off while it stripped the flesh from the bones of her rescuer.

But he had gone out of his way to save her - could she just abandon him now? She didn;t know what she could do, and she would risk recapture even if she wasn't killed, but surely she had to at least try?
121112112.title: Dark Beast

choices: They are interrupted by a knock at the door
1211122.content:
"Who are you?" Dauphin whispered, conscious of the men posted around the room.

"Why, I'm Amana of course," her new companion replied, with the simplicity of the very young. She could not be more than eight or nine years old judging by her features and voice.

"And why are you here?"

"It's my house, silly!"

The abandoned buildings were clearly not as deserted as they had seemed. Dauphin drew a deep breath, then asked, "Are there others here? Can you fetch someone who could help me?"

"Just my mamma. But she is sick."

"Could you get away and bring help back."

"All my friends moved when the bad men came."

"How about you help me untie these bonds then?" Dauphin asked.
1211122.title: Amana of course

choices: Agree and attempt to overpower the guards
Say no and wait for another opportunity
12111222.content:
Amana clambered out of the fireplace, dusting soot from her ragged clothes as she did. Within a minute she had undone Dauphin's bonds and even removed the amulet. However there were problems yet to come.

"Of course you can't fit up the fireplace," Amana stated.

"Why not?" Dauphin asked.

"You're too large. I can only just make it."

"Is there any other way out of here?" Dauphin's hopes had already dropped, but she had to ask.

"Well I could always cause a diversion...."
12111222.title: No way out

choices: Dauphin is taken to Cardac by Delphina
12112.content:
It was a long trek back to the land of Cardac, but the riders didn't waste much time. Dauphin lived with the hope that at some point someone would challenge them, as after all this was all enemy country to them, but outside of the cities the people were just not organised enough as groups. With people so self absorbed and disorganised as this Cardac would soon have control of everywhere. Only the lands of Sirael and Asaeraem to the East seemed to be putting up any real resistance, but they had been too far to escape to.

The familiar towers of Cardac's castle loomed before her and Dauphin's heart sank even lower. She was back and this time there would be even less chance of escape. Whatever trust had been placed in her before would now be gone and although she had always been a prisoner now it would be even worse. That was if she got to keep her life, but if they had wanted her dead she would have been killed already...

Entering the castle walls still under armed guards, Dauphin came face to face with the person she hated the most. Her twin sister Delphina - the girl who had everything. Cardac's perfect daughter.
12112.title: Back home

choices: Should Dauphin keep up her act of loyalty?
121121.content:
"Really, Dauphin, you should know better by now. Father is quite angry, though I suppose we should know what to expect from you by now," Delphina's arrogance grated on Dauphin's nerves, but she knew enough to restrain her tongue. The confrontation with her father would be difficult but, if she played her cards right, after a few weeks she could regain enough trust to escape once more.

"Delphina," Dauphin met her sister's gaze resolutely. "How good to see you again."

"Now, now, Dauphin, we both know you don't really mean that. So tell me, what made you betray Cardac this time? Money? Power? Your knight in shining armor?" Delphina smirked.

"I did not betray Cardac," said Dauphin. "I merely... needed a break from the monotony of palace life."

"Oh, is that it? Then you can explain to Father why he uncovered two spies from Sirael who knew all the secret passwords."

Dauphin raised an eyebrow. This she had not known. "I wasn't in Sirael, and that's the truth."

"Like I said, explain it to Father."

As they reached the entrance to the throne room, Delphina gave Dauphin a condescending look. "See you on the other side." She opened the door, pushed Dauphin inside, and left. The door slammed behind Dauphin, and her eyes worked to adjust to the dimly lit throne room.

"Come here, Dauphin," her father spoke softly, but with an unflinching firmness. She could see no guards but knew several were hidden in the shadows and secret entrances, not including the two just outside the chamber door. She complied.

"I've heard reports," her father began, "favorable reports about the status of our army. Certainly you know that Cardac is the strongest country in the known world. Everyone knows it. We are strong because we are loyal. All of Cardac is loyal to its King, to its Father-Prince. Why will you not join our cause?" His eyes were soft and pleading, and Dauphin was almost convinced he really cared about her. It was what she so desperately wanted, and the King knew it, knew how to sway her.

"Father," she said, almost choking. She caught herself. She could not let emotions interfere with her cause. She had to play-act for the sake of regaining her freedom but, unless she separated her heart from this now, she would end up joining Cardac in spite of herself. "Father, I am sorry. I did not betray Cardac. I merely wished to be away for a while. Now I know that my loyalty lies with my country and my family."

The king regarded her skeptically. "I take it Delphina has told you of the spies from Sirael?"

"I was not there."

Her nodded. "I know. My men searched first for you there. They found no evidence that you had ever been there. Still," he paused. "I don't trust you. This is not the first time you have tried to run away, and unless you are telling the truth, it will certainly not be the last. Therefore, I have assigned guards to your chamber for the next few weeks. If you can prove to me in that time that you are loyal, they will be reassigned. If not..." the king's complexion paled, though his countenance remained stern. "You will be executed as a traitor."

"What?!" Dauphin blurted. She had expected the guards, but this, this... she'd had no idea. Her mind spun as she was led away. Would she be able to convince her father of her loyalty? What could she do to accomplish that? She could suddenly think of nothing. Should she try to escape now? If she could find a diversion, she might be able to slip away from the two guards, and she knew the secret passages.

Just then, one of the castle servants hurried by with a large tray of food. She heard a *CRASH* and glanced to see that the servant had fallen. The guards moved to help the poor girl. This was her chance!
121121.title: Confrontation with the King

1211211.content:
Dauphin scurried up the corridor as fast as her skinny legs could carry her. "Hey!" the guards shouted after her. Idiots. She hurried down the servant's stairs and along the narrow passageway at the bottom. She rounded the corner and ran straight into Connell, the masked rider that had found her in the foreign city.

"Going somewhere Dauphin?" he asked her. His mask was off and she could see his blue eyes.

"Oh, I was just going to get something to eat," she mumbled, knowing the lie was pointless. Connell wasn't head guard for nothing.

"Oh, really," he said laughing, in spite of himself.

The other guards came running up the passageway. "Oh, thank goodness you caught her," Darwin said.

Connell's expression changed dramatically, and he scowled at him. "You're really doing a good job looking after her, aren't you? Both of you, get out of my sight. You're obviously not fit for this type of work. Go to Cardac immediately and explain what happened. Tell him I'll look after Dauphin."

The guards left. Connell and Dauphin were alone. "I want to thank you for the careful travelling arrangements you made for me. And for your wonderful treatment of my faelan," Dauphin said sarcastically.

"We'll get him back for you," Connell said.

"You do know I could be executed for trying to run away again, don't you?"

"Yes. I will convince your father otherwise."

"If you're doing this for my sister's sake, then don't even bother. She doesn't care about me."

Connell's expression changed. "You know that's not true. But that's not why I'm helping you."

They are interrupted by...
1211211.title: Connell

choices: Connell escorts both girls back to their father
Dauphin is placed under guard in her room
12112111.content:
"Then why are you helping her?" came the voice of Delphina, stepping up behind Dauphin.

Dauphin realized she was standing closer to Connell than might be considered proper, but stepping away now would only make her look as if she'd been doing something wrong, when she hadn't. Had she?

Connell looked startled to see his fiancee appear so suddenly, but quickly relaxed and smiled warmly. "I only want what's best for my future sister-in-law," he said after a pause.

Dauphin felt strangely disappointed. Had she actually been hoping that arrogant jerk would've said something else if they hadn't been interrupted?

Delphina placed a hand on Dauphin's arm. "You have to stop doing this to Father. I know you don't think he cares, but this hurts him."

Dauphin snatched her arm away. "He cares about me so much he threatened to execute me!"

Connell sighed. "You are not going to be executed. I'll speak with your father."
12112111.title: Uncomfortable conversation

choices: You wouldn't do that to your own sister
121121112.content:
Dauphin sat fuming in her room. It was large and luxurious, but it also had no means of escape. There were guards not just at the door, but beneath the windows and in the rooms to the side, above and below. Connell had truly covered every possible exit, she couldn't even break through a wall to escape.

Dauphin was interrupted from her thoughts by the soft opening of the door. Expecting Connell, she was greeted by the sight of her sister Delphina instead.

"Come to gloat, have you?"

"No, to bring you food."

"We have servants to do that," Dauphin replied coldly. Really, the two of them were nothing alike, except physically of course.

The realisation sent a shudder up her spine. They were very similar. And Delphina was trusted and allowed to roam free. How difficult would it be to overpower her and dress in her clothes?
121121112.title: Sisters

1211211122.content:
Dauphin knew with a sigh that she could not do it. Delphina might be cold and unfeeling but she was still her sister. Besides which she would never have been able to carry off Delphina's snooty airs with the guards.

"What of Duroc?" she asked bitterly.

"He has left. But do not take too much consolation in this. If you are not killed our father will find you another suitable suitor. Those lands we cannot take by force must be united by royal marriage."

"You have been allowed to marry internally."

"Connell is from one of the oldest families in the land. It is a move to placate the people in our father's eyes, nothing more."

"Since when did he ever care about that? He let you be engaged to the man of your choice because he favours you."

"If you behaved you might be favoured. Wait a while, agree that you were wrong and consent to the original marriage. It can still be rearranged, will get you away from here and may indeed be your only chance of avoiding execution," Delphina suggested, although her tone made it sound more like an order.

"A marriage to a prince, thirty years my senior! I would rather be hung."

"That's your choice. Just remember that any future suitors are unlikely to be any better: you are no great catch right now."
1211211122.title: Marriage or death

choices: dauphin leaves the castle and goes into town
dauphin heads to the castle armory
12112111222.content:
Dauphin was becoming agrivated.

" enough sister..i want to see father."

"he has already spoken to you...."
"then tell him it is important....please Delphina."

this took Delphina back. her sister...saying please?
"alright...wait here...not like you have a choice anyway..."

Delphina left and 10 mins later cardac arrived. he looks at his daughter with great suspicion.

"i hear you have something important to discuss."
"yes father. i do not want to sit here and regain my favor slowly. i want to prove that i can be trusted."

"impossible"
"not impossible. give me a task. send me somewhere...challenge me. let me show you i am worthy of your trust."

king cardac stroked his chin on deep thought.

"very well Dauphin. you shall have your chance. tomorrow is the day of national celebration, however, local thugs and gangs ruin the festivities and kidnap locals every year. kill off their leaders...and you will have proven yourself to me."

"thank you father. you will not be disappointed."
"we shall see."
12112111222.title: a task from cardac

choices: Dauphin goes  to her room and bides her time
Dauphin goes to talk to Delphina
1211212.content:
There were too many guards around to run - Dauphin knew she would not get more than a mile outside the castle without being discovered. Oh to have Delphina's freedom!

Just then a thought struck her. Of course! She and Delphina were twins after all, and did not look that dissimilar.... As long as she could manage to adequately forge Delphina's clothes and manner she would have free roam of the kingdom. First she would have to get Delphina out of the way though.... It would be difficult as Delphina was the stronger, but far preferable to a death sentence.

Dauphin knew that Delphina was not entirely heartless and would not purposefully lead to her sister's death. Even if having Dauphin as the family scapegoat helped lead to Delphina's image as the perfect daughter!
1211212.title: Double trouble

choices: You can't do that to your own sister
12112122.content:
Delphina's quarters were in the same wing as Dauphin's, so it was a simple diversion. The guards were not yet stopping her from travelling around the palace just yet, merely watching her every move. She was a princess, even if a prisoner.

"Delphina?" Dauphin asked hesitantly, standing in the ante-chamber. Now she was here, she wasn't quite sure what to do or say.

"Dauphin," her sister replied coolly. "When will you ever learn?"

"It's not that I want to be a bad daughter," Dauphin replied, going with the flow. Her sister was at the opposite side of the chamber still, there was no hope of any move just yet. "But haven't you ever wanted more? There is so much going on in the world at the moment. The war..."

"Is not our concern."

"But they say it's murder! Our own father, matching country against country, killing innocents in the name of power."

"Cease this heresy! Our father is a good man. The war must be right."

"Even our own soldiers aren't saying that in private."

Delphina made a move across the room towards Dauphin, her frustration written clear on her face.
12112122.title: Family battles

choices: A person in a nearby cell strikes up a conversation
121122.content:
The small dark cell was a drastic change from her usual apartments upstairs, but at least she did not have to pretend here. Her father had proved true to form in locking her away and ignoring her but at least he had not killed her... yet.

After searching the walls and floor Dauphin accepted there was little chance of escape. No hidden passage was going to open to freedom, she was trapped here entirely at the will of Cardac. Which meant she wouldn't be getting out anywhere in the near future, unless a miracle came her way.
121122.title: Imprisonment

choices: vern sends a torture master to Dauphins cell
1211221.content:
Dauphin sat in the cold and the silence echoed all around her. the hours ravaged her mind...slipping her slowly into madness...until...

"bring a torch down here! i can't see a blasted thing."

It was the rider who found her and brought her here....his black armor blended in with the darkness perfectly.
"so...Dauphin, still bitter at Cardac for his decision?"

Dauphin lunged forward.
"that armor belongs to me! you have no right to wear it brother."

the knight removes his skull helmet..only to reveal a scarred and war-torn face.
"father chose me for the armor. he explicitly told you that..."

"father is delusional! How many battles have i won for him compared to you? yet he favors you...and gives you the deathseeker armor. i guess being an only son has benefits....huh vern?"

Vern re-applies his helmet.
"that it does sister...for while i lead our homeland into the victorious future, you will stay here..rotting away..forgotten."

the brother ascends the stairs.
"it's not over..you hear me vern? it's not over...i'll get you vern! I WILL GET YOU!"

vern closes the door enveloping her in eternal darkness once again.

"double the guard on this door....if she escapes, i'll have your head."
1211221.title: her other sibling

choices: The riders go away but threaten to return
1212.content:
In the darkness behind the man, at least a hundred other riders were visible. But the only response was the firing of catapults. The dark rider was the main target, but with the luck of one who has the powers of evil on his side he avoided the barrage and removed himself from range.

"This is your last chance to hand over the girl peacefully," he called, his words clearly contrasting with the violence that had just taken place.

"No chance," came the reply.

The armed forces outside awaited the command from their leader. It was clear that they wanted the girl, but in comparison to the forces inside the city they knew they were outmubered for now.
1212.title: Hand her over!

choices: Dauphin is escorted under armed guard to the palace
They hold her whilst they send message to the palace
12121.content:
"Very well then. From this moment on, your land is doomed," and with that the leader vanised leaving his forces to retreat by themselves.

"Now, do you want to tell us what that was all about?" asked the Captain of the guards, turning to face the girl once more. His tone indicated that there would be no avoiding the subject, he deserved an explanation.

"I need to see the King. I have an urgent message for him alone," was the only reply.

"You can just walk into a city and demand to see the King you know."

"I think you'll agree that these are special circumstances," responded Dauphin indicating the retreating riders.
12121.title: Who's the girl?

choices: Go to the commander of the guards
Go and visit the King's mother
121211.content:
The Captain looked at the girl. Much as he hated to admit it, she was right that the King would have to be notified. The last comment had been an all out threat of war, and some explanation about why this ordinary looking young girl would provoke such a reaction was needed.

Taking six of his trusted guards he escorted the girl to the palace. With threat of attack at any time he dared not remove more from the gate. Reaching the gatehouse he requested an audience with the King, or at least one of his advisors.

"The King is out of the city at present. Any matters of urgent business must be addressed to the commander of the guards."

It was a terrible thing to think of a fellow soldier, but the Captain knew that handing the girl over to the Commander would be signing her death warrant. The man would not think twice about handing her over to the enemy if it helped the city as a whole. There was always the other option of course of the King's mother... one of the only people who would tell him what to do and be listened to, although she was notoriously difficult to talk to.
121211.title: The King is away

choices: A girl Dauphin's age rushes into the room
1212111.content:
With sinking heart the captain knew he must report to his commander. News would no doubt have already reached him of the enemy forces at the gates, and he would want a full report anyway. It was his duty as a soldier to do so, and he could not think why he would have thought otherwise.

"Bring the girl," he instructed the others and set off in the direction of the commander's suite of offices.

Dauphin followed obediently. She had no reason for concern as yet, but her positive hopes died as soon as she enetered the office of the man who would decide her fate. For she had seen this man before!

"Yes, Captain?" the commander asked, his clear green eyes coolly inspecting the party before him.

Dauphin let out a small sigh of relief. He had not recognise her as yet, but if he heard the story from the gates he might put two and two together sooner or later.

Suddenly...
1212111.title: The commander

choices: Safina asks to hear their account
Safina takes Dauphin for a private conversation
12121111.content:
The girl that ran in was smaller than Dauphin and blonder, with luscious golden curls framing a heart shaped face. She was dressed finely for this time of night, in pale emerald silks, but there was mud on her hem and her shoes. Nonetheless every man in the room immediately snapped to attention.

"Princess Safina," the captain breathed into her ear, sending Dauphin into the inevitable curtsy.

"There has been an incident at the gates," the Princess said, almost gleefully.

"I am aware of this matter," the commander responded.

"Well? Are you going to tell me why I had to find this out from my maid servant? I am next in line to the throne you know, just because my brother is absent doesn't mean the royal family is kept out of the loop."

"I was to brief you after I had thoroughly gathered the information from these witnesses," the commander replied dismissively.

Safina's eyes flew over the guards and Dauphin.
12121111.title: Princess Safina

121211112.content:
Princess Safina glanced over in the direction of Dauphin, then turned to the Commander and asked, "This is the woman that came in on that faelan?"

"The Captain just brought her in now. I haven't had the time to ask her anything," the Commander replied.

All eyes turned to the Captain.

"Yes, your higness," he replied.

"A faelan is a very rare creature, particularly in this area. Are you from Gaznook?" Safina asked Dauphin.

"My ancestors are from there. But in the late period of the Dreft Dynasty, my great-grandfather moved our family to Fayedian. We've remained there since," Dauphin replied.

She tried to look the princess in the eyes, but kept looking at the necklace pending from Safina's thin, frail neck. The necklace had a gold chain and hanging from it was a phallic-looking object made of diamonds, that rested lightly in the princess' cleavage. The Captain followed Dauphin's eyes to the princess' sweet rack. His thoughts were far cruder. Those milky white babies, lightly sprinkled with freckles helped him through many lonely nights. Very few people have ever been so close to such perfect breasts in their lives. He began to blush.

Safina, almost as if gliding on air, moved swiftly, but not with an awkward swiftness, towards the stranger and took her hand in hers.

"What is your name?" she asked, batting her eyelashes a little.

The Commander loudly coughed, "Dauphin," at the princess.

Safina turned her head to face the commander and, in a deep tone, reminiscent of her father's own voice, said sarcastically to the Commander, "Unless Dauphin suddenly grew a bunch of hair on her face and developed bad gas, you'd better shut the fuck up!"

The Commander bowed his head. A little twitch in his upper lip suggested that if she weren't the princess, but his wife, or some other woman, he'd slap the shit out of that bitch.

Safina turned to Dauphin again. Her face looked innocent and gleeful, like what had happened didn't really happen.

"I heard the guys in Fayedian are SOOO hot! Is that true?" Safina asked as she starting leading Dauphin up to her room.

"Oh, I suppose they're not bad," Dauphin replied, happy to get away from the men. Dauphin wasn't a complete psychic, but she could sense the Captain's perverted thoughts about the two young, gorgeous girls. Mind you, she did not trust this princess either: far too coarse and disrespectful for her hallowed position. She had no choice but to go along with it for now though.

They continued chatting about guys and girly stuff like that until they finally walked into the princess' room. They sat down on pillows on the floor, about two feet apart, facing each other. One servant came in with a big, green glass bong. Another servant came in with a silver tray with big green nuggets of dama, a weed that all the famous artists were smoking at that time, and placed it on a table next to the princess. A third servant walked in with a pitcher of iced tea, a couple of glasses and some sandwiches. All three servants bowed, then promptly left, never turning their backs to the two young women. It was a special rule created just for the princess, because she was paranoid that someone would fart on her. She hated gas.
121211112.title: The Princess and Dauphin

1212111122.content:
"We smoke now. It allows us to see the future," the princess said in the hushed tone of one imparting a great future.

Dauphin remained momentarily silent, although her mind was forming words. "No wonder you're so schizophrenic. Spoilt senseless, all the drugs on hand you could need." Such things were better unsaid however. "I have another suggestion. If your highness will permit me the honour I will read her fortune in the tea leaves."
1212111122.title: Leaves of one kind or another

choices: "Yes!  I can't wait to see what happens!"
"No way!  If you are caught and tortured, the enemy might find out!"
12121111221.content:
"So, like, you can read the future in those tea leaves? You're not a gypsy, are you?"

"No," Dauphin coldly replied, "I'm not."

The Princess took a deep breath from the waterpipe, and coughed. With a little giggle she said, "Sorry. I didn't mean to offend you."

"Listen, Princess," Dauphin was eager to cut to the chase. "This isn't a time for smoking, this isn't a time for laughing, and this isn't a time for questioning me. There are soldiers at your gate, and when I leave they are going to pounce on me. That necklace you are wearing holds much significance. It could be a map or maybe a key. I don't have it figured out yet."

Dauphin pulled a stone from her bag. Weighing in at possibly ten pounds, the dusty old stone was probably the most unclean thing ever to make its way into the Princess's sanctuary, other than the Princess's mouth.

"This comes from the Moon Temple, built by the Northern Bedouins over three thousand years ago."

The Princess was about to ask a question when she noticed the tense look upon Dauphin's face. This wasn't a time for questioning. She let Dauphin continue.

"The fact that this stone made it as far south as Fayedian is almost miraculous. Do you have any idea how it got down there?"

The Princess pondered heavily for a moment. She examined the stone closely. Its shape reminded her of the lid to a jar. Suddenly, a thought occurred to Tt Princess. It manifested itself as a gasp and a sparkle in her eye before she finally exclaimed, "It's a Mamulayan! The Northern Bedouins believed in three major deities. One of them wasn't born yet. My tutor taught me this last year. I thought it was so stupid back then, but my father insisted I learn about it. I have a bowl that should fit this Mamulayan pretty snuggly. If we burn the right combination of tea leaves, the fire at the bottom of the lid will create an image on the ceiling. The image should be a map, right?"

Dauphin replies, "Yes. The map will tell us where we need to bring that necklace."

The Princess saidatter-of-factly, "We already know where it should go. It belongs in the Sun Temple. The Northern Bedouins of the Moon Temple had the major elements to unlock the Sun Temple, and vice versa."

Dauphin looks at her, surprised.

"The Bedouins and the Tangi never knew of each other. It's impossible! The coincidence that one had a Moon Temple, the other a Sun Temple never went unnoticed, but these cultures have nothing in common."

With a big smirk on her face the Princess saido Dauphin, "They have one thing in common. Dama. How do you think the Bedouins of the North ever got a hold of dama when they live among glaciers and fjords? Dama is one of the ingredients, isn't it? That's why my father has never made it impossible for me to get it. All these years, I thought I was outsmarting him, but he knew the whole time. Hewanted me to see this image. But why?"

"Because the universal law is that you can't hurt a Princess," replied Dauphin, "You have to bring your necklace to the Sun Temple yourself. The whole plan is coming together. Your father is very clever. The connection between the two civilisations is the Dama. The old trade route passed through your kingdom. If you follow it, it will bring you to Sun Temple. I don't have a map of the old route though."

"Don't worry," said the Princess, "I think I saw the map hanging from my dealer's living room wall. He's an aristocrat. His family helped put an end to the trafficking."

"We have to seek out his help," said Dauphin, "but first let's see the image!"

The Princess replies...
12121111221.title: The Stone

choices: They are interrupted by the King's arrival
1212112.content:
Dauphin looked around her as the guards escorted her to see the King's mother. The part of the palace they were heading towards looked older, with strong walls walls of rough stone covered in ivy. They were now walking in a garden where vines and fruit trees outnumbered flowers. The footpath crunched beneath their feet.

The voice behind them made her stumble, "What are you doing here? Don't you have a city to guard?" The voice was female, loud and sounded displeased.

"Your Majesty.... The girl says she has a message for the King.... Says her name is Dauphin..." the Captain's voice was shaky.

Dauphin turned around and almost gasped in surprise. She had been expecting an old, witch-like harridan, dressed in scarlet robes. The woman in front of her, however, was hardly older than her own mother! She was wearing a simple, high-necked grey dress, its only adornment being garlands of leaves embroidered in green around the cuffs and hem. Her hair was dark and long. If this was the King's mother, this meant the King was about Dauphin's age.... Of course, her mother had married rather late, so he could be a little older... or maybe even younger. This could make things more complicated... or perhaps simpler. Besides, if this was the current King's mother, it meant that the old King must have died while Dauphin was travelling and she hadn't heard the news.

All thoughts fled as she looked into the dowager Queen's eyes. They were black - the darkest, most intense eyes Dauphin had ever seen on any creature. Her eyes looked right through the girl, and she suddenly realised that she couldn't use her mind powers on this woman if she tried. Yet Dauphin couldn't sense any special powers in the other, only her formidable will. She could almost see this will as a column holding up the whole castle, and even the very sky above the city.

Dauphin released a breath as the King's mother's eyes left hers.

"Well..." the Queen said abruptly, "This girl could be trouble. One way to keep one's peace is not to meddle in the affairs of the other royal Houses, and we have always done that." Another weighing look, "On the other hand, we are also in trouble now. Perhaps she could be of assistance."

"You may go," the King's mother said to the guards, "Leave the girl with me. We will talk. Post the usual guard outside my garden."

When the guards were gone, the woman steered Dauphin towards a gazebo in the garden.

"Perhaps you should tell me what brings you here," she said in her customary brusque manner.
1212112.title: The King's Mother

choices: "Dauphin, Warrior of Tamrath, I permit you to stay in the city to assist"
Dauphin, Warrior of Tamrath, I will not allow you to stay in our city..."
12121121.content:
At once, Dauphin began to tell the King's mother why she had come to the city. "First of all," Dauphin began, "I come from the city of Tamrath, about 20 kilometers east of the Boreram Sea, which is about 15 kilometers from here. In Tamrath, word came saying that your city was in grave danger. My father, who is a part of the Tamrathian council, worried that if someone did not go to help, your city would be destroyed. I know that I am only a girl, but I have been training as a warrior since I was very young. I am the best fighter in Tamrath. I have won awards in contests. I have beaten the best of Tamrath. My father thought it best that I should help save your city. Please your Majesty, I know I can be of service to you."

Dauphin stared in the the queen's black eyes. After a moment of silence, the queen spoke.
12121121.title: Will the Queen Let Her Stay?

choices: She leaves the stable and starts to head for the Inn, when she is interrupted by
She leaves the stable and heads for the Inn...
121211211.content:
"Dauphin, warrior of Tamrath, I permit you to stay in our city to help in any way your commander will see fit. Under one condition: you must stay within the city at all times unless directed by me or the King. If you are hiding anything, or have lied in any way, you wil be executed. I have no patience for folly in my city at this time. Do you understand?"

"Yes, your Majesty, I promise. Thank you for allowing me to assist you and your city."

After this, Dauphin left the Queen's home and went to the stables to take care of the faelan, to make sure he had been properly fed and watered. She found the faelan very comfortable, so she went inside the stall and began stroking the magnificent creature. It had been given to her by the Tathrinian goverment for defeating the top warrior in the city. He was her closest friend, she trusted him with everything she had and he was very loyal to her.

"Tomra," she said, which was the fealan's name. "I can't believe it was so easy to get in here. I just hope the plan works."

She sighed, thnking of her father. Would he be proud of her? He had sent her and told her exactly what to say, how could he not?

"I told her the truth, why would she have any reason to doubt me?" She looked down at Tomra. "And no, I didn't use my powers on her, I considered it but I didn't need to. She gave me the answer I wanted, so what would have been the point of using my powers if it would have been the same outcome either way? And also, I think she could resist, there was something in her eyes, that told me she wasn't like most people."

She stared thoughtfully for a moment, remembering those black eyes. Tomra whinnied and she came back. "Well, perhaps, since you have been taken care of, I should go see to where I'm staying."

She got up, patted Tomra's head and left.
121211211.title: She stays!!

1212112111.content:
"Hello girl" a voice whispered from an alleyway Dauphin had just passed on her way to the inn.

Dauphin spun around, her hand going to her sword. Emerging from the alleyway was a cloaked and hooded figure, holding up its two empty hands.

"Stay your hand, young warrioress. If I wanted you dead, dead you would already be. I merely wanted to talk."

The slender hands pushed back the hood, revealing a beautiful face of pure white features. Framing that angelic face was luxuriously thick raven hair, tied into a braid that disappeared under the hood. There was something about the face, and especially the ears, that gave the hint of some elven blood in the stranger's ancestry. But the most disconcerting thing about the stranger, in Dauphin's opinion, were her eyes. They were dark and seemingly bottomless.

"I'll stay my hand," Dauphin blustered, "if you speak your piece."

The stranger smiled. The smile didn't reach her eyes.

"I'm here to deliver a simple warning. I love this city. I love the royal family that rules it. And, in my own way, I defend it. Defend it to your best, and you will have no greater friend than I. But let your actions reveal even the hint that you will play the city false, and you'll be dead in the blink of an eye."

The stranger faded back into the alleyway. When Dauphin tried to follow her, the stranger had disappeared.

Shaking her head, Dauphin...
1212112111.title: The mysterious stranger

choices: ...went to find him and maybe some food.
...took a bath and retired for the night.
12121121111.content:
Dauphin sighed shaking her head in exasperation. This day just kept getting stranger and stranger. It was time for her to get to bed before someone else threatened her life or made her life difficult. Fingering the hilt of her sword she paused a moment staring down the black alley way before continuing her journey to the inn.

As she traveled throughout the city Dauphin got a feel for the atmosphere. Faint sounds of laughter and conversation floated to her ears and an overall sense of well being was communicated on other levels of her consciousness. Before she knew it she was at the inn.

A small sign outside declared that this was the Wayward’s Rest and a picture of a tall cloaked figure with a quarterstaff and a sack was illustrated under the title. Taking a deep breath Dauphin pushed open the door, fingering the letter in her pocket.

The low murmur of noise abruptly increased as the door swung open, not halting in the least at the sound of an opening door. Closing it shut quickly behind her, the young warrior examined her surroundings, moving throughout the room in a slow controlled walk that came so readily to one with her training.

The inn was a well lit haven from darkness, giving off a feeling of rest and merriment, truly different from the oppressive atmosphere that inflicted her homeland. Then again they still had their artifact, but that was a thought for tomorrow after rest.

Several of the men in the room looked her over as she walked to the bar to speak with the innkeeper. A few even made as if to talk to her or intercept her path. It wasn’t hard at all to work on the minds of normal people. Men who had meant to stop her for a word sat down and resumed whatever activity that had caught their attention before leaving her unimpeded.

The innkeeper looked up from polishing his bar. “How can I help you lass?” he said placing the cloth beneath the tabletop and turning his body to face the warrior.

“I need a room, nothing too fancy but a bath would be nice,” Dauphin said handing over the letter that she had received.

The innkeeper’s eyebrows rose a bit seeing the royal dowager’s own sigil pressed into the wax of the seal and opened it without comment, his eyes scanning the brief message. Looking up he handed the parchment back, his eyes weighing her, before a brief smile touched his lips once more. “I see,” he said simply.

Gesturing for Dauphin to follow, he made his way up the staircase to the left to the third floor and, after walking to nearly the end of the hallway, he opened the door and motioned for the girl to enter first. The room was well furnished if a bit plain and an adjoining room had a large copper bath with piping leading into the walls, leaving her to believe that at least one worry would be taken care of.

Turning to thank the innkeeper she found that the man was already gone and with a shrug she…
12121121111.title: Wayward's Rest

121211212.content:
"Dauphin, warrior of Tamrah, I will not allow you to stay in my city. You will bring destruction. Also, I have heard that Cardac wants you. Why?" Dauphin was shocked. How could she tell her that? Dauphin slowly began.

"Well, your majesty, you see, I'm sort of well known, and it seems Cardac wants me to fight for them. I don't want to of course, but I have no choice. They chased me here. Luckily, Tomra is the fastest faelan in our world, so we beat them, but they're still after me." Dauphin looked up at the queen who was now white with anger.

"So you came her and put my city in mortal danger just because you don't want to fight for them? How dare you! You use my city to protect you and then you lie and say you were sent?! How could you?! I could have you executed for this! Get out, I will not hear another word from you! Out, or I'll call the guards!" The queen screamed.

Dauphin would not leave with that. "No, I can't leave you to fall to them! You don't know why they want me, do you?" the queen stared at her quizzically.

"There is more to me than you know, your highness. I have powers beyond your belief. They don't want me because I'm a fighter, no, they want me for my powers. I would be very useful to them, but I could be useful to you as well. If I stay you could defeat them, If I go, you will be destroyed." Dauphin paced around the queen who now was not only white, but shaking in fear.

"I can't, they will destroy us to have you-"

"They will destroy you if I go, because they will have me!" Dauphin yelled.

"Get out, I have had enough! My decision is final, I will not change my mind." the queen said.

She's weak, Dauphin thought. I could break into her mind and change her desision. But, for some reason, no matter how much she wanted to, she couldn't make herself.

"So be it," she said angrily. And she left the queen's house.

She stormed to the stable and quickly opened the stall and called the faelan out. Tomra walked slowly forwards and looked at Dauphin questioning the sudden departure.

"She said no," was all she said, as she hopped onto his back. They flew for an hour before the faelan swooped down and landed gracefully. She hopped off his back and took out a piece of bread she still had from the journey there. She needn't get anything for Tomra, for he was quite happy eating grass. After eating, they settled down to rest.

"So she said no," Tomra said. He couldn't speak in the city for fear of being over heard. Most people didn't know that faelans could speak.

"Yes, I tried to tell her that with me on Cardac's side they would be destroyed. But she wouldn't listen."

"Did you try using your mind tricks?"

"I thought about it, but I couldn't bring myself to. She would probably resist."

"I see."

"So what should we do? Go home?" Dauphin asked. She had been pondering this while flying and still couldn't come up with anything.
121211212.title: She said no! What now?

12121122.content:
Now the King is exactly the one that the young girl needed to see....

"Yes, who are you and what is the urgency of your visit?"

"I come from your neighboring country. My name is Dauphin and I give you a message... I do not know what it says, just that you alone must read it."

The King glanced over the message without speaking a word, before stating, "I must get in contact with a friend. You can stay here or go with me."
12121122.title: Which way to go!

choices: Find out who the men are
121211221.content:
"Very well then... mother, we will return shortly."

Then the king and Dauphin set out to meet the friend of the King.

"Fair maiden... I know the name you gave is a fake. I demand to know your real name," the king instructed.

Dauphin knew that she was obligated to obey the King. She was also a messenger and did not want to disobey her own instructions. "Your majesty, with all due respect, I was given orders by my lordship never to reliniquish that information, even to you."

The king could see she was sincere and being honest. He admired her loyalty to her nation. He knew he could trust her. The girl was very beautiful to him and was just a little younger than he was. Her golden blond hair gleamed brightly in the moonlight, and her emerald green eyes gazed at him intensely.

"Your majesty, I am afraid."

"Don't be, all will be well soon enough."

All of a sudden three men on horses came rushing towards the royal carriage.

"Your Majesty... they look like bandits... should we take the highroad?" asked the driver.
121211221.title: Riding With the King

She stabs the king, killing him
1212112211.content:
"Woah!" Woah!" The king's guard halted the horses, bringing the carriage to a sudden stop.

"Sire!" One of the off-duty horsemen yelled as he careened beside the carriage. "It is urgent sire. The Haven Stone has been stolen!" A thunder roared in the distance.

"Dear lord." The king said, exalted.

"Our barrier is fading sire. We do not have much time until we are magically defenseless!"

"How in hell did the Haven Stone get stolen?" The king was furious, holding back the urge to smack the horseman in the side of the head.

"It was a faelan sir. The faelan that came in with that girl. It used telekinesis magic to sever the Maiden's aura, and then simply grabbed the stone and fled from the city. Lord, we tried to stop it. But it was just too fast."

"You fools.... We are doomed!" The king turned devilishly towards Dauphin. "And you are the one who brought this hell upon us." The king looked away disgusted. "Guard, bring us to the commander's quarters. It's time to show her some of our 'real' hospitality."
1212112211.title: The Haven Stone

12121122112.content:
Dauphin stabs the king in the chest with her dagger and leaves it protruding from his chest. He collapses to the ground gasping and Dauphin begins laughing maniacily. "You thought it would be that easy?" she smiled at the guards. The first guard lunged with his sword while the second guard ran for help.

Dauphin easily dodges the sword thrust. "You fools..." she laughs one more time and dissapears into the mist... The king is rushed to the safety of the palace and the medical staff tries their best to save him....
12121122112.title: She stabs the king, killing him

choices: Dauphin refuses to go with Danlin
121212.content:
The Captain of the guard studied the girl carefully. Even with her face hidden within the shadow of her hood and by the darkness of the night there was something familiar about her.

"What did you say your name is?"

Her clear grey eyes met and held his. "I am Dauphin."

She got no further as recognition flashed across the soldier's face. Now everything made sense to him, the expensive mount, the plain but elegant cloak, and the girl's bearing. He motioned to one of his men. "Go to the king quickly. Tell him his brother's ward requests an audience at his earliest convenience."

He removed his headpiece and held his hand out to the her. "Dauphin, do you not recognize me?"

Her gaze traveled over his face missing nothing. A gasp of astonishment escaped her. "Danlin?"

The intensity of his blue eyes softened and is features eased into a rare smile. "Yes Dauphin." He paused a moment. "So you do remember"

She placed her hand in his and his fingers closed around it. "But how did you come to be here? You were thought to be dead, murdered by the evil one."

He replaced his headpiece and lowered his voice. "We must not speak of such things in the open. Come with me; we will talk as we stable your faelan."

The animal whickered, sensing his mistress' uncertainty, "But the king?"

She tried to pull back but he held her fast. "My men will know where to find us. Please come with me. You have nothing to fear."
121212.title: A Face From the Past

choices: Stay there and fight for the fort
Retreat into the fort and recruit more men
12122.content:
Even though the guards had made it clear that they did not intend to hand over the girl, the army of dark riders on the other side of the barrier seemed relentless.

With a warlike cry from the leader, the black mass that stretched to the horizon, swarmed up and started shooting bright pink energy balls at the barrier.

"Comet phasers," the guard commander muttered, "they must be mad! They will have to do much better than that to get through the barrier," he said with a slight smile.

Seemingly, the dark riders seemed to think so too, because all of a sudden, they stopped. The guards heard sullen muttering echoing throughout the mass. Slowly, they began to retreat.

"Haha!" the guard laughed, "we will be able to sleep safely tonight." He watched the black mass' retreating back.

"Don't become overconfident, sir," said another guard. "Look!" he added, pointing to the eastern side of the fort.

As the guard commander turned his head, he saw another black mass that seemed to be bigger than the last. The guard sucked in a breath, and he and his fellow guards started to slowly back away from the barrier, as the black mass grew steadily nearer.

The mass, however, stopped a good distance away, and remained still for several minutes.

"What the hell are they doing?!" asked the guard-in-chief. He didn't have to wait long for his answer.

Within minutes, the mass gave out an almighty roar and a massive flourescent green lightning bolt shot out from the centre of the mass and smashed into the barrier.

The barrier began to ripple like water. At this, the guard panicked.

"The barrier can't last for long against those Zurethan streaks! The barrier will be down in a matter of minutes!"

The guard commander realised this too. He was faced with a really perplexing situation.
12122.title: The black mass

121221.content:
It was futile, but the gate had to hold long enough for a message to reach the inner fortress. The captain had despatched the youngest of his lads to run and inform the current watch guard, before drawing his sword and going to meet his destiny.

Six feet tall, in glistening armour decorated with many awards for bravery and swordsmanship, he stood at the head of his troop, his father's blade held two handed. With the sword before him and his men at his back, he would sell his life dearly.

The riders moved through the gate ten seconds later.

The bodies of the captain and his men gurgled as the hooves trampled over them. For all the blood spilt from their bodies, they were still alive...
121221.title: A Minor Obstacle

choices: The old man is pleased to see Dauphin
The old man is angry to see Dauphin
1212211.content:
The girl sloshed through the city streets, her clothes getting ever heavier with the water they were accumulating. Her breath came short and fast, not only from her running but also from fear. Her faelan trotted alongside her, easilly keeping up. It nudged its head gently against Dauphin's arm. The girl flinched then turned around.

"Oh Yakul, I almost forgot about you!" She said laughing nervously. Yakul brayed quietly and Dauphin nodded as if understanding.

In one swift movement she mounted the creature taking off at thrice the speed she was running at. The wind whipped at her hood and sodden hair, slapping it against her lightly tanned skin. But she did not care, so long as she stayed far away from... them.
After a few minutes they had already reached the other side of the city. Dauphin slipped off looking rather battered. She looked around herself at the still standing buildings pondering her next move.

KA-BANG!!!

A sharp green explosion erupted some distance off, taking many innocent lives and homes. Dauphin gritted her teeth then tore herself away from the sight. She jogged forward a few paces and saw what she was looking for, a herbal shop. Signalling Yakul they entered the building, their nostrils immediately filled with assorted herbal scents. It was actually rather pleasant.

A door near the back of the shop opened with a slam and an old man hopped out with the energy of a child. He saw his visitor and his eyes widened.

"You're...!"
1212211.title: Flee!

choices: Tell them the truth about your past
Lie and say you don't know what's going on
121222.content:
"We can't defend them so out numbered!" one guard yelled. The head guard signaled for everyone to retreat and recruit more men. He turned to the girl.

"Who are you?" he asked sternly.

"Dauphin" she replied softly, rubbing down her faelan cooing softly.

"Dauphin" he repeated, "Who are you, really?"

"I-I'm Dauphin," she said again, moving closer to her faelan.

"Then answer me this, Dauphin, why are they after you?" he cocked an eyebrow and searched her eyes for an answer.

Dauphin searched her mind frantically for an answer. She meant no harm, really, it was just her past... it was coming back to haunt her.... Her faelan nudged her lightly and she smiled, "Yes, Rendalin, I know. They should know the truth, but what if they banish me for it?"
121222.title: Questionning

choices: Dauphin is the only person to know Cardac's true plan
Dauphin is thought responsible for the death of one of the Cardac royal family
1212221.content:
"The armies of Cardac are coming." Dauphin began. "They have been growing in size, stockpiling weapons and armour for decades. Now, finally, their king had decreed that they shall conquer this land."

"We know all of that," the guard captain scoffed. "You think we don't hear the rumours, working here at the gates? Refugees have been pouring in here at a steady stream. It always was only a matter of time."

He paused, listening for a moment to the sound of the eldritch energy of the enemy sizzling against the barrier.

"Time is something we have very little of at the moment, girl, so explain quickly!"

Dauphin swallowed nervously. It seemed that there'd be no fooling this man. She couldn't palm him off with vague half-truths. He'd settle for nothing less than the truth in its entirety.

So she told him.
1212221.title: A Dedicated Man

choices: The guards listen to Dauphin's advice
The guards attempt to save the fort by offering Dauphin to the Black Knight
12122211.content:
Suddenly Dauphin's face became stern with determination! Boldly she took in the head guard's steel gray eyes as she sized him up.

"Cardac was King Elderidge's grand wizard, but the king, my father, grew old and Cardac seized the throne. True, Cardac would have attacked you anyway, but since I am the only legal heir to the throne still alive, he planned to force me to marry his son, the black knight who is leading this force to recapture me. Without an heir of King Elderidge to strengthen his claim to the throne, he will always have a weakened position among the nobles of the kingdom he took."

"Now, listen to me, noble guard." Dauphin's clear blue eyes sparkled with intensity. "The Black Knight, Caturuk, has only one Zurethan Intensifier with him at this time. Rally your forces and aim all your catapults and fire power to the center from whence comes the Zurethan flashes. If you can silence it or make Caturuk's men around it retreat, Caturuk will be forced to regroup."
12122211.title: Dauphin's Secret

choices: Caturuk decides to attack bringing catapults to the front
Caturuk pulls out a message written on metal and ties it to an arrow
121222111.content:
The guard captain shouted to all of the other guards, "Aim the catapults towards the Zurethan Intensifier and destroy it."
