Just as the catapults were re-aimed and fired, the Zurethan Intensifier lit up and fired, bringing down the barrier. Even with the barrier down the city was still formidable with the city gates up. The good thing though was that the Zurethan Intensifier was demolished.

The explosion of the Zurethan Intensifier can be felt all the way at the city, even though it is five hundred leagues away. Dauphin spoke to the guard captain, saying, "Don't get comfortable, even with the Zurethan Intensifier gone they are still a tough foe to overcome. Though they usually only attack when they have a clear advantage."
121222111.title: BFG aka Zurethan Intensifier destroyed

choices: Follow what is happening in the city
1212221112.content:
Caturuk pulled out a message written on metal and tied it to an arrow.

Caturuk then had an archer shoot the arrow into the city. Either unintentionally or on purpose the arrow hit one of the guards. "Read that letter, it will tell you everything that you need to know about that girl that you insist on protecting. I will be back in one month for your answer. Be warned: I will get what I want."

Caturuk then gathered his troops and rode off back to their capital city to tell their king what had happened.
1212221112.title: Retreat!!

12122211122.content:
The guard captain removed the arrow from his charge's chest and read the note.

He glared at Dauphin."I should hand you over this moment except your friends have already gone."

"What? Why?" Dauphin said, louder then she should have for the guards were now looking at her and listening.

"Because young lady the note says that you are the daughter of Cardac, not Elderidge. Also, that your betrothal is to Koruk Elderidge's nephew."

"That a lie," Dauphin screamed. But subconsciously she wondered about the real truth of it all. She knew her mother had died at her birth. But even if it were true, Elderidge had always been her father.

Dauphin decided to take a risk. She took a step closer to the guard captain and whispered. "Sir, whether you hand me over to Cardac's men or not, I assure you that he will take this city and march all the way to the sea. However, if it is true that in reality I am Cardac's daughter then I have gifts."

The faelan let out a low chattering laugh. She stroked his muzzle and continued. "Let me use those gifts to help you set plans to defeat Cardac."

The captain of the gaurd stood for a long moment and considered what Dauphin had said.

"Come with me then."
12122211122.title: Surprise and Risk

121222111221.content:
They stabled the faelan and headed to an inn where they would not be overheard and, even if they were, no one there would believe them.

"So, what are these gifts that you have that can help us defeat Cardac?" questionned the Captain, looking at Dauphin, not believing that she had any gifts.

"Well, there is actually an item that uses my gifts. I do not have it with me. We have to find it before Cardac does. My gifts are both divine and arcane. I can use healing spells and minor mage spells. This item intensifies the, let's say, potency of a caster's spell two-hundred fold," said Dauphin.

"So what you are saying is that if Cardac finds this item then he will be unstoppable?" asked the Captain.

"If we don't get it first all tales about an armageddon happening in the future will come true," said Dauphin.
121222111221.title: My gifts to you

choices: The Captain thinks Dauphin is lying and is a spy
121222111222.content:
They stabled the faelan and headed to an inn where they would not be overheard and, even if they were, no one there would believe them.

"So, what are these gifts that you have that can help us defeat Cardac?" questionned the Captain, looking at Dauphin, not believing that she had any gifts.

"Well, there is actually an item that uses my gifts. I do not have it with me. We have to find it before Cardac does. My gifts are both divine and arcane. I can use healing spells and minor mage spells. This item intensifies the, let's say, potency of a caster's spell two-hundred fold," said Dauphin.

"So what you are saying is that if Cardac finds this item then he will be unstoppable?" asked the Captain.

"If we don't get it first, all tales about an armageddon happening in the future will come true," said Dauphin.
121222111222.title: The spy

choices: They place Dauphin outside the walls
She fights them for her life
121222112.content:
"Alternatively we could just give them the girl." Ratera, the second in command spoke timidly, unsure of his superior's wishes. But with voice gaining in strength he continued, "Disputes between nobles of another land is not our problem - we could endanger the entire city."

"Wise words Ratera. But we cannot simply hand her over to the enemy. Eject her from the city, to outside the safety of our walls. If they are to find her... well that is her problem."

"Of course they'll find me. How could they miss me?"

"Silence wretch!" he ordered, waving four of his men to move her by force.
121222112.title: Friends become foes

choices: It is a lord of the city
1212221122.content:
"I would rather die than become the Black Knight's bride," Dauphin stated calmly, drawing her sword. She hated that it had come to this but she had no choice. Better to die by the sword than in captivity.

The four men dispatched to take her outside the city walls were well prepared for resistance. They spaced out, so to catch her from all sides. The first man came in fast but he had underestimated the skill of his opponent. He was in armour, heavy and unwielding, whilst Dauphin had the speed of the unprotected. Her travelling cloak would not protect her from a blade, but nor did it weigh her down.

She dispatched him in seconds, taking on the following three men in the rush that followed. Less than a minute after the fight had begun, all four men were on the ground. To an untrained eye it might look like carnage but Dauphin had been careful. True she had wounded them, some considerably, but every one of the four men lived. They were not her enemies, just obstacles in her path.

As if from afar she heard clapping. Glancing up, Dauphin saw a man standing to one side who had not been there before.
1212221122.title: Four to one

choices: She does as she is told
She does not trust this new stranger
12122211222.content:
"Our finest soldiers, beaten by a girl. Whatever would the king say?" the stranger asked, straightening up from his position of leaning against the pillar.

"My lord Adev, with deepest respect our finest guards are not on wall watch duty. This woman is a danger to the city," the commander informed him, his own hand on his sword. "She must be cast out."

"I have heard her sorry tale." Lord Adev stated, eyes wandering to Dauphin, taking in her bedraggled state but fine weaponty. "It is a matter for the council, not mere defenders of our walls. I will take her with me."

The commander merely bowed, acknowledging the lord's superiority.

"Follow me then," he said to Dauphin.
12122211222.title: Lord Adev

choices: The commander tries to take the box
The commander lets Dauphin keep the box
12122212.content:
Dauphin reached into the faelan's saddlebag and withdrew a heavy lead box big enough to fill both her hands. It was an ugly, misshapen thing, covered with bubbles that resembled warts on a toad's back. It was closed and locked wth a bright silver linchpin.

"This is what they want," Dauphin told the guard commander.

The man scowled and reached for the box. Across the lid and down the sides, bright silver runes burst to light like a blaze of fired naphtha. A loud hum like the residual vibration of a deep bass church bell having been struck filled the room. He jerked his hand away and the runes slowly faded as did the tooth-rattling hum, leaving the box's dark surface unmarked and the room silent except for the crack and sizzle of another bolt thrown against the barrier.

"Don't touch," Dauphin said.

The commander glared at her. "I gathered as much. What in the hell's is it?"

Dauphin sighed, suddenly looking very weary and much older than she'd appeared initially. There were dark circles under her eyes and she looked as though it took all her strength just to keep from dropping the lead box at the commander's feet.

"The heart of their king," she said quietly. "The Mad Conquerer, King Grothag."
12122212.title: The Heart of the Matter

choices: The commander commands his men to attack
The commander and his men retreat
121222122.content:
The commander's eyes widened and he took an involuntary step back. "The Cardacian king is dead?"

Dauphin nodded and turned back to the faelan, who stood quietly as she carefully replaced the box in the saddlebag. "Yes, he's dead. But he does not rest easily."

"How did it happen?" he asked. "How did you come by the box?"

The girl latched the saddlebag strap and leaned heavily against her beast, who turned and pushed her gently with its long, narrow nose in concern.

"It was bought at great cost," she said. Her voice was a whisper the commander barely heard. "A far greater cost than I was willing to pay. But the choice was not mine to make. Now I am merely the messenger."

"Sir!" yelled one of the guardsmen. "The shield is failing!"
121222122.title: The King is Dead

1212221222.content:
"Fall back!" the captain bellowed. "We can't fight them here! Back to the second wall!"

The soldiers withdrew in orderly fashion, but the captain stayed back to talk to Dauphin.

"The name's Briel. Come with me, and I can take you to the city council. They need to be informed of this news."

Dauphin looked up at the man. Could she really trust him? Cardac had not always been an enemy, and many within the city would doubtless blame the war upon her, upon the king's death. Perhaps she should never have come here at all...
1212221222.title: The Second Wall

choices: Dauphin makes it over the barrier
Rendalin is struck by a Zurethan bolt, sending them crashing to the ground
1212222.content:
The barrier suddenly shook as two more green Zurethan bolts slammed into it. The barrier dissipated the energy back and upward into the atmosphere as designed, but the audible crackling noise made it clear that its integrity had been compromised.

The Guard Commander had seen enough. His eyes were filled with uncertainty as the onslaught of the dark riders continued. He took hold of the clasp of Dauphin's riding cloak in his fist and pulled her violently closer, their faces only inches apart.

"Girl or not, I won't have you bring this battle to my gates!" he yelled. The cacophony of Zurethan tearing the barrier down filled the air around them, nearly drowning out his words. "Tell me why I should even try to protect you, and tell me right now, else I throw you back out to them!" His breath was heavy with fear and anxiety on Dauphin's smooth face.

Dauphin didn't know what to do. Just coming here in the first place had cost her dearly, and would cost her more once she found the Oracle masquerading as a simple clerk inside the fort. She had to continue on at any cost, but she was as powerless as a baby without her weapons to resist even simple guards, even with her faelan Rendalin at her side. Yet, if she told them her true mission they would fear her even more than they feared the black riders.

One thing she saw clearly was that the Guard Commander was not going to be receptive to anyone from Cardac, and Cardacian she was. The truth, she knew, would not be taken well by this man. If she revealed that she was of noble Cardacian blood they would throw her out and into the clutches of the Baron's forces who had cornered her here at this guard post. There was only one thing she could do.

Her eyes had been averted downward, in the typical form of a supplicant female that this Dynisian Guard Commander would expect. Her eyes bolted upward to him, tranfixing him in her gaze. She could feel his breath catch for a moment in his throat as she showed him a hint of the true nature of the person he was manhandling.

"I do not know what they want from me, Commander," Dauphin said, barely audible, her eyes like stone, her voice low, even and commanding. "I am sorry to have brought this to your post. Release me and I will take my faelan and be gone. It was wrong of me to have come here; I apologize. You would forgive a foolish girl, would you not?"

The Commander stood, paralyzed, his mouth agape as she held him in her gaze, the rain pouring down over his face. She softened her face then, and smiled, breaking the moment. The Commander's composure quickly came back to him, though he looked befuddled and confused.

The barrier shuddered with an ear-splitting crack as another Zurethan bolt struck home.

The Commander released her, snatching his hand away as if from fire. "Yes... yes, that would be best," he almost whispered. Turning around, he seemed to refill his full frame as he commanded his unit. "Prepare to open the barrier!"

"WHAT?!" yelled most of his contingent, nearly in unison.

The Commander seemed to be in full charge of himself once again as he addressed his troops. "Our guest is leaving... now. The riders will leave with her."

"But sir, you cannot abandon her to them!" protested a catapult gunner.

The Commander turned fiercely on the gunner. "It is not your concern! Would you have her bring down the barrier?" The gunner's mouth moved but appeared unable to obey his command to speak, so he instead meekly turned around and assumed his post.

The Commander turned to Dauphin, though he was conspicuously careful not to look her in the eye. "Mount up, milady, you'll have less than five seconds to be clear of the barrier. You won't want to be in its path when we reestablish it."

Dauphin leapt onto Rendalin, seeming lighter than air as she did so. She caressed his neck. "Get ready, boy."

The barrier shuddered under yet another barrage with a sickening crack, then fell silent as enemy guns paused. "Reload!" came the distant command from the dark rider.

"Open the barrier!" the Commander yelled.

With a loud hum that cut off sharply, the barrier came down, its opaque edge shimmering briefly before falling down like a waterfall abruptly turned off at the source.

The Commander turned on Dauphin. "Go now!" he commanded.

Dauphin nudged Rendalin with her heels, and they were off in an instant, climbing high.

The commands came nearly at the same moment: "Fire!" from the dark rider, and "Barrier up!" from the Commander. The order was not quick enough, however, and two bolts got through. Dauphin felt her stomach tighten as she watched them strike a building in the city, though what the building was she could not tell. It collapsed, and she heard voices screaming. Young voices.

She nudged Rendalin higher and higher. The faelan flew strong, his muscles bulged, a sheen of sweat already appearing on his fine coat.

The dark riders were now aiming their shots at her but with each passing moment she gained more distance and safety. "Just about there, boy," she cooed to Rendalin, patting his neck in sympathy with the animal's terror.

A few seconds later they were clear of fire and high over the city. Dauphin knew that the city's barrier was not a complete dome, it was merely a large wall; the Cardacians never attacked by air so complete encapsulation was not needed. All she had to do was fly far enough away to be out of sight of the dark rider and his small army, then she could go up and over the top and enter the city.

A faelan, ridden by a woman, would cause an immense amount of agitation within the city and it was this that she had hoped to avoid in the first place, but it was inevitable now. The Oracle was the only one who could help her. She would deal with bringing a faelan into the city when the time came.
1212222.title: Through the Barrier.

122.content:
With reflexes that would make the quickest of cats envious the girl spun, her bright eyes flashed as she snatched an energy sword that hung from a belt around her shapely hips. She depressed a button on the equizitily engraved hilt and the blade blazed to life with an orangish yellow glow that illuminated the area some twenty paces around her.

In the glow of her blade she could see the attackers moving towards her. There were perhaps ten of them. They were covered in thick shaggy furs that hid their features but she did not need to see their features to know they were Gromums. Inhuman beasts, raiders that roamed the waste-lands and would kill anything or anyone they came upon, but for them to attack a city was unheard of, their numbers were too few to attempt something like this. Things were far worse here then they seemed.

The guards stood terror-stricken as the obvious leader of the Gromum's stepped forward to face the young girl that stood before him, sword at the ready. A guttural laugh escaped the towering beast's lips as he looked down upon her and then without warning he struck! A huge taloned hand shot out from beneath the folds of his furs aimed at the girl's throat but instead of feeling his razor sharp claws sinking into the soft flesh of her neck there was a burning pain and he jerked back: a severed stump were his hand once was. The beast screamed in pain and rage as green blood pumped from the wound with every beat of its heart. It threw its head back and howled in anger, the folds of its hood fell away to reveal its massive head. Yellow eyes glowed under high jutting brows that were hair covered and wrinkled skinned. Its mouth was filled with rows of needle sharp teeth and its serpents tounge whipped out lashing the air with its forked ends and sickly blue colour. It rushed the girl with all its tremendous strength but she stepped aside easily and the beast's momentum carried it past her.

It turned and attacked again this time bearing a spiked club in its remaining hand. The earth shook as the beast's intended blow missed the girl and struck the ground. Her moves perfectly timed and choreographed as if she danced some sort of ballet of death and it ended as the creature's disembodied head hit the ground with a melon sounding thud, its dead eyes staring into nothingness. The remaining creatures, seeing their leader fallen, fled in terror.

The girl turned to face the guards. She deactivated her sword and then said quietly, "I've come to see the king."
122.title: Spilling of blood

choices: It is one of the guards
1221.content:
If in that moment the girl had proved to be another attacker the gate would have fallen. The guards stood so awe struck that they probably would not have noticed if she had turned on them. However, she did not and the gate opened and the girl was admitted.

With the air of supreme confidence Dauphin strode towards the town. She had no doubt that news of the attack on the walls would reach the castle before her, and if nothing else at least she would make an impression upon the King!

Meanwhile she could hear the sound of footsteps chasing behind her.
1221.title: Inside at last

choices: They encounter another attack on route
12211.content:
Turning, Dauphin faced one of the guards. There was no fear in either of their expressions, as hers was of supreme confidence and his was more of awe than of fear.

"I have been ordered to escort you to the palace," he said with as much confidence as he could muster.

"Lead the way then," Dauphin replied and giving him no chance to speak any more strode purposefully toward the palace, causing the guard to almost have to run to take the lead.
12211.title: On a mission

choices: Dauphin either talks or is dropped
122111.content:
Dauphin and her guard escort walked down the street towards the King's palace, which was a giant castle made entirely of diamond, floating high above the rest of the city on four enormous pillars. Suddenly, an explosion tore a hole in the wall beside them, and a party of fifteen vicious-looking warriors stepped out and charged the surprised duo. The guard reached for his spear, but before he could do anything, a long, thin, heavily-armored warrior, who was obviously the leader, drew a large curved sword and sliced the unfortunate man’s head off. As for Dauphin, before she knew what had happened, two burly warriors had stepped behind her, removed her energy sword and pinned her arms behind her back.

The leader stepped towards her and pressed his sword against her throat. “Make any noise and you’re dead,” he barked. “You’ll come with us now.” He lifted his other arm to reveal an impressive, crossbow-like apparatus strapped to his arm, then fired a large arrow at a mountain cliff on the horizon. All of the men grabbed hold of the rope which was attached to the arrow, and soon they - and Dauphin - were sailing through the clouds towards the mountain. The kingdom grew smaller and smaller to Dauphin as she flew farther from it.

When they had landed on the cliff, the leader tied Dauphin to a tree perilously close to the edge of the cliff, and pointed the blade at her throat. “Now,” he said, “Will you tell us what we wish to know, or must I reveal my more unpleasant ways of getting information?”

“What are you talking about?” asked Dauphin. The man nodded to one of his cohorts, who bashed her across the face with a heavy wooden club.

“You know exactly what I’m talking about!” snarled the leader. “You are in cahoots with the Kammabvars. Lead me to them now!”

Dauphin’s eyes widened. The Unseen Four! They were four mysterious men with great powers, who had long ago quit their respective home countries and wandered the wilderness together, vowing to protect the good and be terrible to the wicked. Although nobody had ever actually seen them, or known how to contact them, it was certain that they existed; their influence had been present in every major war or disaster as long as anyone could ever remember.

“Why do you think I work with them?” asked Dauphin, confused. “I don’t even know them!”

“She’s lying!” barked the leader. “Cut her from the tree!”

A fat man with an axe slashed her bonds. Dauphin looked around in anxiety. There was nothing she detested more than being helpless; if only she had her energy sword, she’d teach these clowns a lesson they’d never forget. But, unfortunately, she didn’t.

The fat man marched her to the edge of the cliff, and made her look down. They were at least three miles high. The ground was so far down it made her dizzy, and she had to shut her eyes to avoid blacking out.

“Tell us or we drop you!” screamed the leader again!
122111.title: The Interrogation

choices: Go back and follow the attackers
1221111.content:
Dauphin would rather die than speak, especially when she knew nothing. She just hoped it didn't come to that, for she had one asset the attackers had not taken into consideration.

"Drop me then."

The leader did not need telling twice. Dauphin felt herself being pushed, then soaring into space. As the air rushed up beneath her she hoped she had been right... kept on hoping till she hit the broad back of her winged faelan at full speed. The impact hurt both of them, but saved her mid air, long before the rocky ground.
1221111.title: Friends in high places

1221112.content:
Dauphin said nothing. She knew nothing of the Unseen Four, and she wouldn’t give these men the pleasure of hearing her admit it. Either way they would kill her.

“Very well,” said the leader. “Throw her over the cliff!”

The fat man moved to do so, but, suddenly, a rock flew out from behind a nearby tree and smacked him in the head, making a sound not unlike that of a bottle bursting. The fat man’s eyes rolled back into his head, he went limp, and he tumbled past Dauphin over the edge of the cliff.

The leader looked around nervously, trying to find out who had attacked them. “Fan out!” He ordered his men. “Find our enemies and kill them!” The warriors grabbed their weapons and prepared to move out, but suddenly, one of them broke into a wide grin. The next minute, all of them were lying on the floor, laughing like maniacs for no obvious reason, laughing so hard that they forgot to breathe and they all passed out.

The leader was now the only one left. He grabbed his long, heavy curved sword and jumped behind Dauphin, pressing the blade against her throat. “Come out or I’LL KILL HER!” he croaked.

Suddenly, his sword began to shimmer, and became two swords. He held on to them as best he could with one hand (he used the other to hold onto Dauphin), but it became more difficult as each one multiplied into two, three, six swords. Finally, it was too much for him, and all the swords fell in a pile at his feet.

Unarmed, and realizing he couldn’t bend down to pick one sword up before his mystery attackers were upon him, he dropped to his knees and pleaded with Dauphin to protect him. Suddenly, Dauphin noticed her energy sword lying on the ground beside one of the comatose knights. She calmly walked over and picked it up, and did the same thing to the leader as he would have done for her: she cut his head off.

“Well done,” said four simultaneous voices, and four unusual people stepped out from behind the tree. Dauphin didn’t need a moment’s thought; she knew, without ever having seen them, that they were the Unseen Four.

One of them was a thin, bald middle aged-man, with a precisely trimmed mustache and goatee, dressed in a suit of raven black. A large gold abacus was slung across his back, with rows and rows of pearls painted red and green. He was… the Numerologist; probability and numbers were his to command. It was he who had caused the swords to multiply.

Another of them wore a black hood, which concealed his face, and in his muscular hand he clutched a mace, which glowed like a red-hot coal. He was… the Warman, the master of all weapons and the strongest man alive. It was he who had thrown the rock with the force to smash a skull.

A third was dressed in a jester’s outfit, complete with the three-pronged hat tipped with bells, and he wore a smiling mask as red as a radish. He was… the Majester, Lord of Laughter, Ruler of Rage, Sovereign of Sadness, Monarch of Madness and undisputed controller of all emotions. It was he who had made all the warriors laugh themselves to sleep.

The final Kammabvar was by far the most mysterious of all. It was a walking tree in the form of a beautiful woman. He skin was rough bark, her eyes were amber, her hands were thick branches covered in sharp twigs, and her hair was a flowing curtain of green leaves that reached her feet. She was Embla the Soul Mirror, most powerful of them all. She had done nothing to save Dauphin; her power was only used in times so dire that the fate of millions was at stake.

“We seek the same goal as you,” said the Numerologist, “It is our goal to ensure that Cardac’s plans of invasion and war are halted. We follow you, Dauphin, from now on. Take us back to the city.”

Once she got over the initial shock that she was actually working with the legendary Kammabvars, Dauphin quickly found a path that led down from the mountain and the five of them descended it.

However, they had not gone far when an enormous brown serpent slithered into their path. It had three eyes and fire poured from its mouth. It saw them from its central eyes and slithered towards them, fangs raised hungrily. With a sinking feeling Dauphin recognized it as a Mountain Death Serpent, one of the most intelligent beasts in the wild. This beast, unlike most, actually knew how to use the various plants and animals of the forest to its advantage. It would not be easy prey.

Drawing her energy blade, she leapt towards it. Then she pointed towards the Unseen Four and shouted...
1221112.title: The Kammabvars to the Rescue

12211122.content:
"Majester, help me!" Dauphin cried.

"Help you...?" questioned Majester. The Kammabvars looked at each other.

"Maybe we ought to..." said Numeroligist.

"Are you sure...?" asked Warman.

The Kammabvars decided...
12211122.title: Odd behavior...

choices: Please forgive my ignorance, dear Monty.  It will never happen again.
122111222.content:
"We will not kill her," said Embla. "I'm sure it's just a misunderstanding." Embla's voice was like the tinkling of a small waterfall.

"Monty, come here," said Majester. Dauphin gazed on in shock, first at Embla's words, then at what Majester was doing. A python makes a very strange mount! "She's sorry she waved that sword in your face, Monty. Right, Dauphin?"
122111222.title: The worlds strangest mount!

choices: She tells of how her land was destroyed by Cardac
She requests the help of the King in revenge
122112.content:
Dauphin had at least expected some problems on getting access to the palace, but it seemed that her reputation had preceeded her. Message had obviously been sent on from the gates.

Dauphin was lead into a small waiting room just inside the palace walls. She was not stupid and realised that if she tried to get any further unaccompanied there would be hundreds of guards to prevent her, so the best thing to do was to wait to gain an audience with someone at least nearer in the chain of command to the King. As she was waiting however, she heard the quiet opening of a secret door in the wall of the room.

"Dauphin."

"Your Majesty," she replied bowing deeply.

"The first moment I heard word from the gates I knew it was you. Even if Dauphin is not your real name," the King replied embracing Dauphin.

"I had no choice but to travel in disguise. The lands are a dangerous place at present."

"And your father? How is he?"

For once the girl who had appeared so strong seemed lost for words, until she finally replied.

"I believe I am the last of my people now. That is why I am here."
122112.title: Old friends

1221121.content:
The king's eyes widened in surprise and he motioned her to sit on one of the couches. Once she was comfortable he took a seat as well. "Please, tell me what happened," he urged.

Dauphin's lower lip began to tremble in an effort to remain composed as she related the story of how her land was destroyed by the Cardac. They had come in swarms under the cover of night, setting light to the city and viciously killing all who lived there. Dauphin had been forced to watch as her home burned to the ground with her family still trapped inside.

While telling of this part Dauphin's composure slipped from her completely. Each word had to be forced out of the anguish that wracked her body. "There were too many," she cried, "I was useless."
1221121.title: Relating the Tale

12211211.content:
Dauphin finally raised her head. A single tear took its course across her smooth cheek. She did not bother to wipe it away. "I wish, sir, to travel north."

The king's eyes widened, and his eyebrows raised. "Good Dauphin, I cannot-"

Dauphin shook her head. "Please. Sir, hear me out. I am the very last of my kind. My people are dead. My tribe has been-" Her voice faltered. "Destroyed. My clan is gone. Let me go to the north."

"Dauphin!" The king practically begged. "What will it do but kill you?"

"If I die, it will be because I have wished it. I want to have my revenge on Cardac. He must die for what he has done to my family. I want him to feel blow for blow and flame for flame of what my father felt!" Anger burned in her eyes.

Silence reigned. "Then let me send one with you."
12211211.title: To the North

choices: Or does the man try to fight?
122112111.content:
Dauphin hesitated, "Very well. If it is truly your wish, I will accept the Escort. But may I choose."

The king nodded, "Of course. But who do you want?"

Dauphin smiled calmly, "I want the man who has been sitting outside the window and listening ever since I came in here."

The king's eyes shot to the window. Silence. "Dauphin, there is no one-"

Dauphin suddenly gave a tremendous leap and flew out the window. The jump jarred every bone in her body, but Dauphin had trained herself well to recover. She drew her sword, and found that her opponent had by then drawn his, too.

A pair of blazing eyes met hers, and she smiled wistfully, "You are an eavesdropper?"

"I have found it to be useful", came the careful reply. His eyes were a golden tone, belonging to a Northerner. He leaped in with his sword, slashing.

Dauphin met his blow, and forced him backward. The man recovered and flipped, landing on a platform above her. Dauphin whirled and ducked under the platform, protecting herself. Instantly, the stranger stopped his movements and all was silent. Dauphin was impressed. He was not foolish.

But this man from the North was not used to the sun, and Dauphin could see his shadow. Putting all her might into the thrust, she stabbed upward. The sword melded through the wooden surface, and connected with the man's leg. He howled in fury and pain, and his sword clattered to the ground.

Dauphin withdrew her sword and climbed onto the platform. He was injured, his right leg nearly useless. His gold eyes burned, but with a seperate light. A light of one who had been defeated, but not broken.

"I want you to accompany me to Cardac."

"Why me?"

"Because you are the only person I have ever met who followed me so excellently."
122112111.title: The Escort

1221121111.content:
"I am Zev Kalen. I am from the Wolf Clan of the North, in Cardac's region. We were strong - we were proud. And I - Zev - I was the best of them all. We were the last of the North bound region who defied Cardac. What is it to be a slave? My people never knew. We would die before we would surrender. And we did. We died in battle. We fought to the last. But I - I was not allowed that glorious portal known as death. I was denied the victory to die in battle, and was taken captive.

Captive? Never I! Never! I plotted and planned, even as they prepared the gallows for my death. There was no honour in the death of a hanging. No Wolf ever hung like an ornament from the noose of such a man as Cardac! My golden eyes that betray my Wolf Clan heritage always burn, but they burned with a different light as I planned.

I might have gone mad in that little cellar that they had prepared for me. We of the Wolf Clan always ran free. And I was stronger than any - lithe and free. They said that I was the Spirit of the Wolf in flesh. I certainly would have gone mad in that tomb - that living tomb - had it not been for the voice that lived next to me.

She was a captive from the south, and she sang her songs of grief for her family. She sang her songs of her tribe. They did not have such clans as we did, apparently. I wondered if the Wolves were the last that remembered the old ways. Perhaps. She told stories to herself, and I listened. She sounded old, but she spoke with clarity. She was wise - and told of the way across the wastelands, haunted by the Gromum, to a city where a wise king ruled.

I listened always. She spoke of her sister - Dauphin. I came to love this girl for her bravery. For the way she had fought Cardac - she had refused to be taken captive. I grew ashamed that she had fought so much better than I. Sometimes, the old woman would drift off to sleep in the midst of her talk of Dauphin, and I would grow desperate to know of what had happened to the girl.

Now, I know. I made it out of the cellar. They could not contain me. Not Zev. I lifted the latch of the old woman's cell. But she might have already been dead. I do not know. I made it through the wastelands. I feasted on the meat of the Gromum, and took their plunderings for my own. I was strong enough to make it. I swore I would find Dauphin.

Now I have found her. She is better than I - but only in some ways. She already has wounded me. But even in this she was wise. She did not make it impossible for me to travel. She made it difficult for me to do any harm.

But it is not wise to have one with you who is stronger. So now what do I do? We have already left the city. I find myself drawn to her. She does not talk more than is needed. She is strong. But she will not reveal her reason for going to Cardac. I wonder why?"
1221121111.title: Zev Kalen of the Wolf Clan

12211211112.content:
Zev looks down at his wounded leg and examines the damage. Talking as if to himself, "I over heard that you are going to the north, and if you can get me patched up I would join with you."

"What makes you think I need your help?" Dauphin asked. "Or want your help for that matter?"

"I did not say you needed my help, but... Cardac's armies are many, and we could inflict more retribution with two than we could alone." Zev stood up slowly testing the strength of his leg.

"I will need healing draughts to mend this, a horse and some supplies." Zev looked back toward the window. "Do you think your friend the King will help?"

Dauphin folded her arms across her chest. "If we go together," then she smiled. "Cardac threatens the entire land, the King will outfit us with whatever we ask."

Zev smiled in return. "Well then, if you would lead me inside to meet your friend, then I can get healed and send for my things. We have much to talk about before we go, and I would like to go over some maps of the area."
12211211112.title: A common foe

choices: Avoid the roads and travel cross country
122112111121.content:
Plans are made, maps are looked at and supplies are furnished. Zev Kalen's leg mends quickly under the watchful eyes of the head priest.

The King opens the doors of his armory to Dauphin and Zev. Both decide to invest in a set of light weight mitheral chain, and other than food Dauphin requires no more. Zev however takes full advantage of the offer by acquiring new boots, a black recurve bow with 3 quivers of arrows, and a razor sharp scimatar.

Before the setting of the sun on the third day the two companions are on their way out of the northern gates. Their two fine mounts are from the King's own stable.

How do you travel?
122112111121.title: Riding North

1221121111212.content:
According to the plans they had drawn up, Dauphin and Zev set out to cross the barren wastelands to the north of the city. The king's road was sure to be watched by hoardes of repulsive Gromums, not to mention the far more dangerous minions of Cardac.

Not even the best planning could keep them from all contact, be it hostile or not. On the second day of their journey, they were slowing their mounts to a walk as the sun reached its zenith. A large hill loomed up to the northwest. They drew even with it, and it lay a mere hundred and fifty metres away.

Dauphin's faelan whickered nervously, and she stroked its neck gently in an effort to calm it. The faelan, however, began to prance, and Zev's gelding picked up on its agitation. Both riders were occupied in regaining control of their mounts, and Dauphin looked up just in time to see a mass of mounted warriors descending from the hill.
1221121111212.title: Hills Bring Surprises

choices: She tells him her true name.
She quickly makes up a name.
12211211112121.content:
Both quickly drew their weapons, expecting a fight to break out immediately. Dauphin dismounted from her weary beast and started approaching the figure.

"Stop," cried Zev in a hushed tone.

Without glancing back, Dauphin replied,"You're injured, but we cannot let him know this. We must have the advantage of numbers at this point." She continued toward him, ready to strike if he showed any sudden movement.

"Name yourself," she called.

The figure laughed a rolling and mocking laugh that filled Dauphin's head. His laughter caused slight anger within her to bubble up, but she did not know why. She studied him the best she could from the distance. His mount was a simple grey horse, but its eyes glowed with a deep amethyst tone, sparkling as would the gem itself. His face she could not see, for he wore a hooded cloak that flapped in the wind as he, too dismounted.

"I said name yourself, stranger," she repeated, "Or I shall come after you and you will regret not saying a word to me." She was no more than a mere ten meters away from him.

His hand went to his hilt, and Dauphin leaped toward him. Their swords met as the figure's hood dropped. They stood face to face.

"My dear girl, you have no reason to fear me," he hissed in her face. She pushed toward him with more force.

"I fear no one." He pulled away and stood still for a moment. Zev watched the entire encounter. They studied one another. She noted the large scars that spread like a river and its tributaries from his left eye down to the right side of his jaw. He noted her fiery green eyes and how tiny she really was, for a human.

"I am Korta Offret. I am of no land and no people. I am what one might call a vagabond, a wanderer of these lands. And your name, my dear girl?"
12211211112121.title: A Fierce Stranger

122112111121212.content:
"Some call me Kiva Yensan. My friend is called Turgeir Jir."

'Turgeir' darted a surprised glance at 'Kiva'. The newcomer noticed the glance and smiled.

"Very well, if that is how you would be known to me. But let none think Korta Offret is a fool. When the time comes, I shall know your true names. As you have introduced your companion, as a show of good faith, I shall introduce mine. This is Zekrim."

He dismounted, and the horse shimmered. A young man with gray hair and amethyst eyes stepped out of the shimmering.

"Tell us where you go, and why," Korta ordered.
122112111121212.title: Kiva Yensan

choices: Korta believes her and they move on
Korta decides she is lying and challenges her
1221121111212122.content:
Not trusting the strangers,Dauphin decided it best to not reveal the true purpose of her journey.
"Me and my companion are travelling toward Zemen,"she replied."We are to go to the great market there."
Zemen was a large village,where tradesmen from all directions went to sell their goods at the market in the village's centre square.
Korta narrowed his eyes and scrutinized her.Dauphin kept her face neutral and eyes steady,but inside she hoped he would believe her.There was something about the man that unsettled her.
1221121111212122.title: Keeping secrets

choices: Ask Korta to stay and tell him the truth
Send him on his way Dauphin doesn't trust him anyway
12211211112121222.content:
Korta huffed, another lie, if you were going there where are your goods to trade?

Dauphin smiled you are very observant for a nomad going no where and from no where. She placed her hand on the hilt of her sword and prepared for a confrontation. Korta saw her place her hand on the hilt and decided not to start something here and now.

Dauphin peered at Korta, before he replied I am just traveling, no destination yet. I was thinking maybe we could join you and your companion. But, with all the lies you have told thus far, I'm not sure I want to be in your company.
12211211112121222.title: Korta decides she is lying and challenges her

choices: Dauphin throws Korta to the ground and knocks him out
122112111121212221.content:
"Korta, I -"

"What, 'Kiva Yensan'? Is there a new variant on your falsehood that you wish to unveil for me?"

"No. I think the time has come to tell you the truth," Dauphin said, feeling Zev's eyes boring into her back. "We ride to Cardac, my companion and I, there to exact vengeance."

For a moment Korta just stared at her, before bursting into uproarious laughter. "That's the best one yet! The two of you - a woman and a cripple - against the might of the world's greatest military and magical power?" Wiping a tear from his eye, he continued. "You're just criers publicising a new mummer play, aren't you? Well, you'll have sold an extra front row seat with your tales this day!"

"Did he call me a cripple?" Zev wondered out loud, before Dauphin stepped up to Korta, seizing the nomad by his collar. "Fine. Don't believe us. Leave us be, but just don't tell another soul about our passing this way."

"With those false names you gave me, I couldn't if I wanted to," Korta smiled.

Dauphin paused. Names had power, that was true; to give hers and Zev's to this man would probably convince him of her story's truth, but did she want to hand that much potential influence to someone she still did not yet trust?
122112111121212221.title: Mummers

122112112.content:
"No, I will have only my life on my shoulders." Dauphin shook her head scrubbing the tears from her cheeks. "I will not accept."

         "I cannot permit that." The King's eyes shone with concern.

         "But it is my life to give!" Dauphin jumped up from the plush couch, "I only ask for your permission out of formality. Nothing is going to bar my way. Nothing."

         The last was but a whispered hiss with all the anger and vehemence Dauphin could control at that moment. The King stared up into her eyes and noted that she told the truth. The sparkle that once lighted her eyes were faded and replaced with a menace he knew couldn't be jostled until she had her vengeance. But would that vengeance be justice or would it be another cycle of violence? Once Cardac was dead would another rise up to hunt Dauphin?

         A sour taste rose up into the King's mouth, "Fine you may go but on a condition."

         "A condition? What condition is this?" Slowly Dauphin took her seat on the couch.

         "You will have an escort." The King raised his hand to forestall any argument, "But they will be volunteers who understand that they may not come back."

         Dauphin frowned in thought at what the King wanted.
122112112.title: Pride

choices: The King tells her he cannot help
The King agrees to mount an attack against the army of Cardac
1221122.content:
Dauphin's face was angry as she said, "Your Majesty. All my people have been slain by the soldiers of Cardac! Men, women and children. I have come here at the risk of my life to beg you to help avenge the blood of my people and your subjects!" Her eyes flashed as she stood, tall, proud and burning with hatred for the Cardacians.

The king looked at her with pity. He said gently, "Dauphin, my dear, my heart aches for the fate of your father and the other noble members of your tribe. But what can be done for them? They are slain. A crusade for vengeance could lose us the city."

"How can you say that?" she cried. "You are our King, our leader and protector. Please, in the name of all that is good, act now to prevent the deaths of any more of your people!"
1221122.title: Request of the King

12211221.content:
"I cannot, Dauphin." The King shook his head trying desperately not to show the anguish it caused him to say that much, "There isn't anything in this world I would want more than to ride forth and free this land from the taint of Cardac. But the cost is too high and the rewards are not there."

         "You speak of this as if you are bargaining for a horse." Dauphin scoffed.

         "Do not speak to me like that again, Dauphin." The King's voice held darker warnings, "You have no right to demand from me and pass judgment on my courses of action if you do not know why I made them."

         Dauphin took a step away from the King, "My apologizes, M'lord."

         Shaking his hand the King dismissed her apology, "It is not your doing. I should hold my temper better. The nights have grown thin and the days have become long and demanding."

         For the first time that night Dauphin noticed the dark circles and wrinkles that were not there months before. Seconds past as the King's eyes lost focus into his own thoughts. Visibly he shook himself realizing where he was.

         "Would you see what keeps me here? Or would you rather move on and trying to find others?" The King turned his tired face to Dauphin.
12211221.title: King's Refusal

122112211.content:
The King led the way through the castle taking stairs and hallways that were in disuse. From the halls they did pass the servants were already waking for the next day's chores and needs. All Dauphin could tell was that they travelled up.

         Abruptly the stairs ended at a wall. In one corner a pole only four feet long sat in a corner covered in spiderwebs. Brushing the fat brown spider from its home the King took the pole and pulled open a overhead door. A wooden ladder creaked down landing next to Dauphin.

         "After you." The King gave a mocking bow.

         Dauphin climbed the ladder with only a light rain following on her head. Outside clouds moved across the sky with the pale light of the sun rising on the east.

         "What am I here to see?" Dauphin turned to face the King who was brushing his hands together.

         Leading her to the western edge the King pointed, "That is the gate you entered in, correct?" Dauphin nodded still not understanding, "But to the north of us is this..."

         Dauphin turned and gasped. Even from the tower of the castle she could make out the black shapes of the Gromum moving in groups of five or six. Dark banners waved in the light wind teasing those trapped in the city. To the east the dying forest of Weslain trailed the edges of the hills that would roll into the Mountains of Tashin. To the west a whole tent city was erected.

         "The city will not last out the year." The King stared out at the Gromum, "Already we are trying to move the refugees to further countries."

         A single tear ran down Dauphin's cheek.

         "You see Dauphin some choices are already made for you. This is mine." The King faintly lifted his right hand to point towards the Gromum. "What will you do now?"
122112211.title: Sunrise on the Fields

choices: Dauphin takes Rendle to the King
Dauphin turns Rendle away, taking the stone for herself.
12212.content:
Dauphin rested her hand on her swordhilt, just in case, then suddenly slipped behind a barrel. The footsteps faltered, and she heard a high-pitched squeal of surprise.

"Lady?" A small boy wandered into view, his bare feet blue against the cold flagstones.

Dauphin, again patting her swordhilt, stepped out behind the child. "Who are you?"

The boy spun around, clasping something in his hands. "Lady! Oh my, they said you were going to the king, and I, I, need to talk to him too!"

Incredulous, but pleased by the young fellow's pluck, Dauphin pressed, "You never told me your name."

"I haven't got one, Lady..."

"Don't be ridiculus, everybody has a name!"

"I don't."

"All right, what do people call you?"

"Rendle, but it's not my name."

"All right, young Rendle, what's that in your hands?"

The scared young one opened his hand, revealing a glowing purple orb: the Silken Stone!
12212.title: Rendle and the Silken Stone

choices: Dauphin and Rendle head towards the castle
Rendle takes Dauphin to his home first
122121.content:
"I wouldn't go around showing that to people if I were you. The next person might kill you for it," Dauphin told the boy.

"I'm not frightened," Rendle replied.

"Well you should be. There's a lot of evil people about at the moment," Dauphin retorted, looking at the boy. He might act courageous, but he was still just a child and if he was going to get to the King he'd need someone to look after him and keep him out of trouble.

"You'd better come with me", she told him, moving in the direction of the castle.

"So how are we going to get to speak to the King?" Rendle asked.

"I wish I knew. But we'll think of something!"
122121.title: Dauphin and Rendle

1221211.content:
"Lets see the castle first and decide how to get to the King later shall we?" Dauphin suggested, turning towards the castle.

Rendle ran after her in an attempt at keeping up with her longer legs. From the gates to the castle was a suprisingly short walk, a probable cause for the worry over an attack. There was another wall around the castle and more guards within. These wouldn't be as easy to get past.

"Who goes there?" a guard shouted at them.

"My name is Dauphin and this is Rendle. We are here to see the king," Dauphin replied, aware of how stupid it sounded. But how else did you gain an audience with royalty?
1221211.title: To the Castle wall

choices: Converse with whoever this man is
Demand to speak with the king
12212111.content:
The guards, realising that she couldn't get past the outer wall unless she was allowed to, let her pass with her young companion following behind her. They approached a screen and another slot for their ID cards. Dauphin placed her cards in and the screen which was previously blue, turned green and the great stone slab of a door moved out of their way. Inside the next chamber was a young man who was sitting on a throne in the middle of the room.

"Are you the king?" Dauphin asked as she knelt before the man.

"No... but I'm as close to the king as you'll ever get," he replied coolly.
12212111.title: The King?

choices: Rendle hands the prince the Stone
122121111.content:
Daphin rose to her feet feeling slightly ridiculous kneeling. "If you're not the king then who are you?"

         An eyebrow rose in surprise at her tone of voice, but Daphine didn't care. She decided the moment she saw him she wouldn't be influenced by his good looks. She would ignore the muscular figure under the layers of silk and brocade. She ignored the flow of his chestnut hair hair and piercing eyes as he called over a guard and whispered something beyond her hearing.

         Daphin looked to her side to find Rendle clasping his hands close to his heart. His stance was firm and she knew he waited for her next move.

         Daphin looked back to find the chaired man admiring her form. His smoldering looks began to irritate her. She resolved to be taken seriously. Placing her hand upon the hilt of her sword she asked, "If you do me the dishonor of ignoring my question then let's settle the matter with swords."

         With both eyebrows disappearing into the man's chestnut curls, Daphin realized she may have gone beyond the sense of good reason. The guards remaining in the chamber drew their swords and Rendle took a step or two back.

         "Of course I would prefer the answer to my question, who are you sir?" Daphin's hand was resting upon the hilt of her sword and she was not going to budge. She stared at the man seated before her preparing to accept either outcome.

         After a moment or two the man unlocked with her gaze and calmly stated with a smile of amusement. "But of course. I am James, heir to the throne. You may refer to me as prince."
122121111.title: Around every corner lays a surprise.

choices: James takes Dauphin into the back room
He allows Dauphin to leave the castle
1221211112.content:
"My prince!" Rendle cries out, kneeling immediately. "I had no idea. Forgive me for my ignorance." He hands the Stone to the prince.

"And HER?" Prince James points his thumb at Dauphin.

"Oh, I don't know where she came from, my prince," Rendle said indifferently. "Do with her what you wish. Of course, milord, how could I stop you anyway?"

Prince James stared at Dauphin thoughtfully. He COULD have some fun with the wench... or maybe he should release her.
1221211112.title: What to do, what to do...

choices: The man takes you straight to the king
It's a trick - he kills the boy and takes the stone for himself
122121112.content:
"Look, we're here to see the king, and we're not leaving until we do," Dauphin told the stranger sternly.

"And I'm here to make sure that nobody without the utmost important information about the outside will see the king!" The man barked back.

"We have something His Majesty would like to see," Dauphin replied, motioning for Rendel to come forward. The boy slid up cautiously, and for a split second, revealed his treasure. The gatekeeper looked at it with astonished eyes.

"Okay," he said finally. "You can come in. But don't overstay your welcome, and the minute His Majesty tells you to leave, you leave, or we'll have you thrown in the dungeon for treason."

"Fair enough," Dauphin said. "Let's go see."
122121112.title: The Reason

choices: "What matters is I have it." Dauphin answers.
"She said it was the only way you would know for sure she had sent me."
1221211121.content:
The King, a thin worried looking young man, watched them approach his throne warily.

Dauphin stopped a respectful distance back and bowed deeply, signaling for Rendle to follow suit.

"You're the girl from the gate. The one involved in the battle," the King stammered, "But who's the boy?"

Dauphin met the King's gray eyes steadily, "A friend," she said smoothly.

His eyes narrowed as they slid between her and the boy. "How do I know I can trust you?" he demanded.
"Because I have this," she answered, pulling the golden amulet from beneath her tunic.

The king stood slowly, and took a few tentative steps forward, his hand reaching out as if drawn to the pendent.

"The Eye of Soulton," he whispered hoarsely. "Where did you get it?"
1221211121.title: The Eye Of Soulton

choices: Dauphin starts building the outer defenses.
12212111212.content:
The king sank back in his chair.
" So she lives....thank the stars. I feared the worst."

Dauphin advanced another step.
"You know her?"

"of course child...eslora was my finest advisor...and my closest friend. That pendant you wear was a gift from me....on the day she left. I had thought it..and her...long gone."

"No your majesty. She has sent me here to aid in your war against the forces that march against you. I will do everything in my power to aid you!"
Dauphin kneels before the king.

The king sees her kneel and smiles.
" I would be foolish to turn down your aid...go to the gates. I will give you command over our outer defenses. Make sure our people are safe and victory is insured for us."

"Of course...your majesty." Dauphin grabs the boys hand and exits the throne room.
12212111212.title: it was a gift....

choices: Dauphin attacks Mordon in a rage
Dauphin lets the guards attack Mordon
1221211122.content:
As Dauphin and Rendel pass the mysterious guard, dauphin can't help but feel a wave of concern and fear.

At that moment, the guard unsheaths his blade and stabs the boy in the heart, causing him to drop the stone.
"Rendel!" she cries whirling around.

The guard throws off his disguise to reveal himself as one of Cardac's elite: Mordon the hunter.
"Stupid boy, waving this around like sweetened candy."

Dauphin stands and activates her blade.
"Give that back."

"Excuse me?"
"You heard me Mordon. Give that back..and I will let you leave here alive!"

Mordon shrugs and places the gem in his pocket.
"NOW MORDON!!!"

Mordon sighs as Dauphin glares at him.
"You know....shouting at me does nothing. If you want it....then take it!"

Guards...alerted by the shouting have surrounded Dauphin and Mordon.

Dauphin smiles slightly.
"I guess you need convincing.....fine then."
1221211122.title: cardac's hunter

choices: The king meets with Dauphin...and asks her a favor
12212111221.content:
Mordon and Dauphin were surrounded by the guards.
No way out for either of them...except in death.

Dauphin activated her sword and it hummed to life.
"That boy was innocent..."
Mordon laughed.
"No-one in this world is innocent Dauphin. You of all people should know that.
You pretend to act all high and righteous...but deep down, you're just like me..."

Dauphin shook her head.
" I'm not the same person Mordon....
I'll show you i'm not..."

She lunged at him with the blade...he sidesteps and moves away.
"So..how does it feel?
Being the hunted instead of the hunter?"
Mordon growled.
"You mock me Dauphin...
I shall make you pay!"

In blind rage, he runs at her.
She sidesteps this time and cuts into his torso.
Bleeding, he falls to the ground.
Dauphin walks to Mordon.

"The stone...."
Handing it to her, he says...
"The others know the stone is here...
They will come....and when they learn of me, they will hunt you...
They will never give up until you are dead..."

Dauphin walks to the throne room as the guards haul the dead bodies to the graveyard.
12212111221.title: the hunter becomes the hunted

122121112211.content:
Dauphin entered the throne room.
Gold sparkled on the walls and the ceiling.
The entire room seemed to glow.

As she approached the throne, she got to see the king sitting solemnly on his throne.
He stood as she got close.
His royal garb and cloak were torn and stained.
His eyes were sunken in and sullen looking.
His body looked frail and weak...no wonder no-one got to see him.

Dauphin kneeled before the king.
"Stand Dauphin of Cardac.
What do you want of us?"

Dauphin stood and faced the king.
" I am no longer a citizen or warrior of Cardac.
I was hoping to find shelter here before moving on."

The king eyed her suspiciously.
"Why do i not believe you?"
Dauphin shrugged.
"Believe what you will....
I will take my leave of here soon enough."

Dauphin bowed and began to leave.
"Wait!"
Dauphin..still facing away from the king..halted.
" I heard the battle outside.
You killed one of Cardacs elite...Why?"

Dauphin turned and face the king.
"Mordon..along with Cardacs other 4 elites..tried to kill me."
122121112211.title: to stay and fight....?

choices: Go back to the fort and get her faelan
12212112.content:
"What is your business with the king?" the guard yelled down at them.

Dauphin searched her mind for a truthful reason that was safe to talk of in such an open place, but came up short. "We cannot tell you that, sir," she answered.

"If you cannot tell the business you have with your king, then we cannot let you in to carry it out," the guard put his hand on a switch and pulled. The first portcullis came crashing down at breakneck speed. Dauphin grabbed Rendle and jumped back.

"What are we gonna do now?" Rendle asked, hand clutching the stone.
12212112.title: Rejected

122121121.content:
Dauphin sighed and scratched her bent head, brow furrowed and mouth pursed in disapproval of the turn in events. General protocol required kings to present themselves before common subjects at least once a week to deliver justice and patronize. She had shrouded memories of King Daray coming before his lesser audience on Mondays, but those were the merry days and it would be foolish to expect such exposure to danger now.... besides, it was all so hazy- now that she thought about it, Tuesdays rang a bell...

Dauphin looked up at her small companion from under her eyelashes, irritation growing as she realized Rendle was mimicking her pose.

"Come", she said gruffly, turning on her heel and choosing an alleyway at random, "let's get you home."
Rendle quickly abandoned his position and hurried on her heels, making her stumble and pause outside a somber inn.

"This ain't the way to the Grotto," Rendle remarked worriedly, "and I don't wanna go home. I wanna show the king my sto-"

Dauphin glanced suspiciously at the dusty windows of The Plucked Fowl, and slowly released her hand from Rendle's mouth, knuckles white with suppressed tension. The boy looked suspiciously close to tears at her rough handling, and Dauphin realized a tantrum was imminent. She motioned that they should keep walking, and kept her hand on the pommel of her sword until they turned into a pleasant little town square. Rendle sat on the edge of the marble fountain in the centre and pouted pointedly at her. Dauphin glared back into his eyes before shaking herself out of such childish behavior.

"Rendle, I can give the... your stone to the king soon. Tonight," she said, sighing as he moodily shook his head. She really did not need this. Dauphin wasn't sure why she was even bothering to escort an urchin she had just met home. Chances were he didn't have one, but just slept in the refugee campgrounds. It would explain his lack of a proper birthname.

As Rendle trailed his fingers through the water, and Dauphin stood in indecision, the rest of the city was much less placid. Rendle's ears pricked at the sound of distant fearful screaming, and he stood, gazing the direction that the sounds of human terror were echoing from. Dauphin frowned as the little boy got up. She spun around to see what he was looking at, simultaneously inhaling traces of smoke. Dauphin stepped up onto the fountain's edge to peer over the rooftops and could just make out flickering green flames leading off into narrow plumes of smoke.

"Dragons," she told Rendle, only to see him racing away on short legs, down the alley they had just come through.
122121121.title: Go to Rendle's house

choices: The King is a wielder and preparing for the gathering
122121122.content:
Anger flashed in Dauphin's eyes. Never had she been treated with such scorn. She held tightly to Rendle's hand, he was alone, much as she had been. He was the wielder for the Silken Stone, she did not know how she had missed it before; he was like her, only he was too young to understand his destiny. She was the wielder of Ra'ardo, the war must truly be beginning if the gathering had already begun.

She had tried the peaceful approach, it had not worked, the King did not understand the circumstances around his very kingdom, or what had stood in its place before. She must gain access to the King and, more importantly, to the castle.
122121122.title: The gathering begins

1221211222.content:
When Dauphin and Rendle reached where her faelan was stabled they were surprised to find someone within. "Put the stone in your pocket," Dauphin whispered to the boy. Resting her hand on the hilt of her sword, Dauphin marched into the stall demanding, "What are you doing here? It is forbidden!"

The cloaked man jumped, his hood falling back to reveal a wrinkled and scarred face. "My dear, you scared my old heart." He pulled out a small wineskin from a pocket hidden within his cloak. After taking a swig to calm himself, he added, "May I point out that you have no authority in this city to forbid entry to the stables."

"It is forbidden to touch a faelan unless you tamed her."

"Quite. Which is why I did not touch him, my dear child. I was just admiring him, he is truly a magnificent beast."

"What do you want old man?"

"I was drawn to your presence from the moment you entered the city."

"Why?"

"I find 'wielders'. The King needs you, the gathering has begun."

"I have no idea what you are talking about. Do not waste my time."

Dauphin moved to eject the old man from the stall. He avoided her hand, swirling his cloak around him. Its colour flashed from black to blue to green and back to black. In an ominous voiced he intoned, "I wield The Cloak of Anamoric, do not play games with me!"

Randle gasps from the corner where he had been hiding. "My stone glows too!"

"Ah, then you must be the child I have been searching for. You have caused me great difficulties, my boy."

"Why could you sense me and not Randle?" Dauphin asked.

"Because you use your gift, he does not."

"We already tried to get to the castle but were refused entry."

"I can lead you on paths like no other." The old man pointed at the stall wall, "Veriaz, illiaco iz remabdo, contiw." A portal opened, a faint green light spilling out. The faelan snorted.

"Sorcerer!" Dauphin hissed.

"Sorcerer Malkika, at your service."

"Blackness, evil, darkness!"

"Hush, my girl. I am the King's sorcerer. The King wields the Axe of Kalhorque. It is time, come with me to see the King."

Dauphin looked at Randle, who looked back up at her.
1221211222.title: Sorcerer Malkika

choices: Rendle becomes the center of attention
12212112221.content:
They stepped into the portal and disappeared into a ghostly green light. Instantly they appeared in a room filled with men.

Malkia introduced them, "Welcome wielders, it is time. May the gathering begin."

Dauphin and Rendle were amazed: before them were several people obviously weilding objects of immense power.

"Hello I am Dauphin wielder of Ra'Aardo and this is Rendle," she said, "We are looking for an audience with the king."
12212112221.title: The Gathering

12212112222.content:
"Sorcerer Malkika, at your service."

"Blackness, evil, darkness!"

"Hush, my girl. I am the King's sorcerer. The King wields the Axe of Kalhorque. It is time, come with me to see the King."

Dauphin looked at Rendle, who looked back up at her. She shoved him hard to one side as she drew her blade and rushed at Malkika. The boy landed in the straw and the point of the sword landed in the man's gut.

Malkika laughed. "You think that THAT is all it will take to end me? My my girl, perhaps you weren't quite as clever as I had imagined..."

A flick of his wrist and Dauphin was thrown back across the stables, colliding with the wall and slumping to the ground.

Rendle watched as the sorcerer withdrew the sword from his belly, allowing a thick gout of blood to gush forth, splattering to the ground accompanied by a charnel stench.

"That will take time to replace," Malkika muttered to himself. Then he looked to the boy, and extended his free hand. "Come with me, child. Leave this place behind."

Rendle looked from the sorcerer to the portal, to the unconscious form of Dauphin. The slightest hint of red showed at her forehead.

"No," he replied.

"You would deny me as well?" Malkika curled his lip. "Then clearly I will have to be less kind than I had hoped."

His wrist rotated, and the sword did too. Slowly, but getting faster with every moment, the sorcerer span the stolen blade around, thrumming through the air. Then he took a step forward.

"That's quite fancy," Rendle remarked. "But I don't think that she's impressed."

"The girl?" Malkika snarled. "She should be grateful that she's sleeping. Such pain-"

"No, HER," Rendle said.

The sorcerer turned to follow the boy's gaze, and caught the hooves of the faelan right in the chin. Catapulted over, he crashed to the ground, dropping the sword and breaking several bones, if the snaps were anything to judge by. As his eyes closed, the portal did as well, and the stable was plunged back into darkness.

Rendle saw that the stone in his hands had stopped glowing as well. It must be worth quite a lot, he reckoned. There would be plenty of people that would pay a fair price for it in the market. It had been months since his last proper meal.

Dauphin still lay sprawled in the hay. he didn't really owe her anything, he told himself. She was safe here.

The faelan snorted.
12212112222.title: Confrontation

choices: Dauphin takes Rendle to the King's Palace
1221212.content:
"Let's get you home first," Dauphin told Rendle. He looked at her forlornly. "You do have a home, right?"

         He shook his head sadly.

         "So you have no home, no official name, nothing?" Dauphin was utterly shocked, this was worse than she had thought.

         Rendle shook his head again.

         "Then how the hell did you get that thing?" Dauphin reached down to grab the glowing object from his hand, but Rendle darted away.

         "I was told to give it to no one but the king," he clutched it to his chest.

         "If only you knew what it was that you hold..." Dauphin muttered to herself, "Fine," she sighed, "Let's get you to the palace."
1221212.title: No Choice

12212121.content:
Rendle and Dauphin quickly headed toward the castle, each with their own purpose in mind and Rendle still tightly clutching the orb.

The road was long, going straight through the middle of the town. Dauphin observed her surroundings as they ambled down the dirt path. All the shops were closed down for the next, except for the town's tavern, also connected to an inn. Even from the road she could here a lot of noise and music escaping the building.

The castle was still a bit in the distance, which caused Dauphin to be slightly interested in taking a rest and checking out the tavern. She could perhaps discover some helpful information about getting in to the king.
12212121.title: Journeying to the King

choices: they try to find another way in
122121211.content:
They keep walking, heading to the castle. As they walk Dauphin tries to figure out what she should tell the king. How can she explain the reason that she was sent, will he believe her? And what of her new friend, what is his story? She silently prays that fate will lend a helping hand. When they reach the palace grounds, they are stopped by a huge stone wall with four towering spires.

At the outer wall a shape separates itself from the shadows. Dauphin reaches for her sword. Rendle scurries to a nearby doorway. "Rendle and Dauphin, please have no fear. Follow me. We have been waiting for you, both of you," comes a soft lilting voice from inside a heavy black cloak and hood. Dauphin watches the figure, trying to distinguish the race and gender of the creature in front of her. "This way please," the voice coaxes, motioning which a gloved hand. The figure glides along the edge of the wall, heading south.
122121211.title: The shadow figure

choices: Dauphin convinces Rendle to give them the Silken Stone.
Dauphin and Rendle refuse to let them have it.
1221212111.content:
Dauphin and Rendle hurried after the figure, already several feet ahead. After fifteen minutes of jogging, the shadow stopped and turned to the wall. Dauphin stared at it, but not even her keen eyes could see why they had stopped.

The shadowy figure murmured some strange words under its breath, and the stones in the wall faded away, forming a gap. "This way," it said to the two in its ethereal voice. They followed it into the recess. A number of people stood in a dimly lit room, all shrouded in cloaks as the guide was.

"We are the Guild of Shadows. We know why you have come, girl. As well as why a young boy trails behind you. We will help you, but we can do nothing unless the stone that the boy holds is given to us."
1221212111.title: The Guild of Shadows

choices: Let them go and take the stone as it is tossed out before the portal closes
12212121111.content:
"Who are you do ask for the stone? " Dauphin asked considering the request
"We have already said."
Not your group who are you?" Dauphin motion for Rendle to get ready to run then grasped her swords hilt"
"No need for conflict, my name is Zyta." She step back with hands out "If you wish not for our help then go about your way" The stone was tossed upon Zyta touch it a portal opened. "Sometimes these doesn't work."
12212121111.title: Dauphin convinces Rendle to give them the Silke...

choices: Guild reinforcements come, making the chances of survival smaller.
Blood-thirsty rogues try to kill the Guild 'and' them.
12212121112.content:
Dauphin twitched a moment, and muttered, "And if we refuse?"

The cloaked figure chuckled, pulling a pair of daggers out of his robes. "Then we'll take the stone with force. Be cautious, girl. We may not want to spill blood, but won't cringe from attacking."

Grabbing her energy sword, activating it, Dauphin whispered, "I don't think you're 'worthy' of touching the stone. If you feel willing to prove me wrong, by all means...let's see your skill."

Rendle felt like he was shaking next to her. Turning around, the girl was a little surprised by a group of new shadows coming from the forest. Great, that complicated things a bit...
12212121112.title: Complicated

choices: Cardac has an assassin following her
She makes it to the king unhindered
122122.content:
The Silken Stone. It couldn't be the actual thing itself though, could it? Regardless, she couldn't leave it in the care of this child. She knew of only one person she trusted enough to hold onto that particular dreaded artefact.

Herself.

Dauphin allowed Rendle to follow her for a while, but led him down an alley where, sure that nobody was watching, she dropped him with a clout to the back of the head.

As she picked up the Stone, she felt a brief twinge of guilt, but she had long ago learnt that the ends justified the means. Besides, if the boy had had possession of the stone for long enough, then he was probably already damned.

She carefully wrapped the Stone in her bedroll and hid it amongst the saddlebags on the faelan's back. It would be all the proof that she required to show the king of this dirtwater town that Cardac intended nothing less than total destruction of his 'kingdom'. The Stone was nothing less than an omen of doom.

She didn't know much specific details of its powers, but tales had followed in its wake of the bad fortune that befell all who glimpsed it. It was also said to be a summoning stone for daemons, the gallstone of a god, a shard of Cardac's own throne....

Most of the rumours were probably false. She wouldn't be surprised if there was nothing intristically magical about it, and that its power was derived solely from the fact that those that saw it expected bad things to happen after hearing stories of bad things happening to those that saw it. And in so thinking, they cause those very events themselves...

Gah, what morbid thoughts, Dauphin told herself, shaking her head. It could be some sort of psychic wave from the Stone -

Enough speculation. She had to see the king, and warn him of the enemies at his gates. Although presumably, after the attack he would already know. She had thought herself well ahead of the beast hordes, but they clearly travelled a lot faster than her. Which prompted the question - how?

She mulled over the possibilities on her way to the king's longhouse, paying no attention to the locals milling around her, staring in surprise at the faelan.
122122.title: The Silken Stone

choices: Try to fight and kill it with your sword
1222.content:
The guards stood there awe struck at what had happend, when there came an unearthly roar followed by thundering foot steps that shook the very earth around them. The girl turned around, reignited her sword and took a definsive stance as the looming form of a sickly creature came thundering out of the forest at them. It was taller than the wall of the city and it had spikes sticking out of its body along its spine and a huge mouth full of twisted and jagged yellow teeth. The claws that stuck out from its feet and hands were as long as Dauphin's arm and it had two eyes that were dark as coal except for two dots the size of grapefruits.

"Damn mummaklin," the girl whispered under her breath.
1222.title: What now?

choices: That's the end of her!  So, about this faelan...
12221.content:
The mummaklin tottered toward the girl. With a shrill battle cry, Dauphin twirled her blade and slashed. A tiny scratch appeared on the creature's leg. Gasping at the ineffectiveness of her weapon, Dauphin realized that the creature had remarkably thick skin.

As the mummaklin took a deep breath, Dauphin jumped away. Belching flame, the creature leaned down to hit the girl. As the fiery breath blew past her, Dauphin noticed it smelled like moldy fruit.
12221.title: Out of the frying pan, into the flaming breath

choices: Dauphin awakens inside the city, physician on hand
Dauphin awakes amidst the burnt aftermath of a great battle
122211.content:
The oddest ideas flashed through her mind as she came so close to death, but Dauphin didn't allow that Mummaklin's hallucination-inducing breath to affect her unduly; steeling herself, she lunged with all her might at its one vulnerable spot: the gaping mouth through which it was expelling the fumes.

She felt resistance as the tip of her sword met the back of its skull, but was unsure as to whether or not she had killed the beast as unconsciousness dragged her away from the fight, to a cosy darkness...
122211.title: Weak Spot

1222111.content:
Dauphin writhed back and forth, plagued my evil memories and saddened scenes of death and loss.
Crying out, she sat up heaving and gasping for air.

"relax..." a calm voice told her.
"you're experiencing the after-effects of a hallucinogenic nerve toxin. you're lucky to be moving at all....let alone be alive."
Dauphin eyes slowly open to see multiple people standing over her...primarily a physician.

Dauphin tries to stand.
"easy girl..easy....guard...have some people carry her into my clinic. We can take better care of her in there....and we won't have to worry so much once we are inside the gates."
