the guard nods and helps two others carry Dauphin inside.

After being propped in one of the beds there, Dauphin tries yet again to stand.
"listen...i will warn you only once....the toxin is still in your nervous system. You keep trying to move and you ould cause irreparable damage to your body. I suggest you stay here at least overnight and let the toxins dissolve.
your choice...."
1222111.title: Dauphin awakens inside the city, physician on hand

choices: Dauphin searches for a army to rally
1222112.content:
Dauphin's mind raced with memories and illusions that made her twist and turn.
She jolted herself awake in panic and full of sweat.

Looking around, she noticed the creature was nowhere to be found...but neither was the castle.
Had the creature spared her and attacked the castle instead?
She had to figure out what happened.

Standing on what little strength she had left, she began searching the area for survivors and clues.
coming upon the gate she had been before all this happened, she heard slight groaning.
She ran to a pile of debree to find one of the guards still alive.

"What happened?"
"the creature....after you fell, it came for us. We managed to kill it. It melded into the very earth and a massive army exited the trees right after...like a signal.
they overwhelmed our forces and killed everyone."
The wounded guard coughed up a handful of blood.

"stay still...."
"it is too late for me warrior...but please, find this army. They had flags...symbols of red vultures on a yellow banner.......pleas...e...."
The guards eyes close and he lays still.

"red vulture on a yellow banner......Velarius!!"
Dauphin searches further and recovers her sword.

"Velarius will pay for this massacre...i swear!"
1222112.title: Dauphin awakes amidst the burnt aftermath of a ...

choices: The oldest guard sees a flaw in her "credentials"
12222.content:
The strange girl untethered her "horse."

"Kari, take ye flight!"

"Fly!" She cried.

Kari took to the air. Kari's hooves dashed the grapefruit-ed eyes so fast that it brought a very odd smile to this strange girl's face.

The monster fled, blind and luckless in its evil endeavor.

"Mercy!" She cried out, and Kari flew to earth. Kari's calm, black eyes shined and smiled.

"Mercy, that's right, Kari," she said to her wild steed. "Mercy." And then she turned to the guards in laughter.

"I am not so merciful," she told them. "Never hear me say the word 'revenge.'"
12222.title: Kari's Mercy

choices: Dauphin is captured by the enemy
123.content:
There's bravery and there's stupidity. Dauphin could see the sheer quantity of attackers and knew she would be straight in the firing line at the gates - there was no option but to run. Hopefully the attackers would be more concerned with gaining entry than with a wanderer like her.

As she started to run however, she could see the futility of her attempt. The area was surrounded and her chances looked very slim.
123.title: Too close for comfort

choices: Try and get into the city to see what you can do to help
Escape the area while you still can
1231.content:
Dauphin felt strong arms grabbing her from behind.

"What have we here then?" a deep voice asked.

"She's unimportant. Kill her and get back to attacking the gates," another speaker responded and Dauphin felt a blow on the back of her head which sent her briefly into unconciousness.

She woke with her head spinning. Not much time could have passed, but the enemy had evidently believed her for dead or at least of so little threat to be irrelevant. She rose to the carnage of dead and dying however and a sight which made her heart sink even lower. The attackers had breached the gates. They must be inside the city now as there were only a small number of them left, obviously to try and stop people escaping.
1231.title: A woman of no importance

choices: Attack the soldiers on the gates directly
Try and bluff your way in
12311.content:
Dauphin knew two things. One, that she was better off in a city with an army than on her own in the wild. And, more importantly, number two, that her faelan was gone, a captive of the enemy. They had come too far together for her to abandon her steed now.

How to get in was of course the question.
12311.title: Into the breach

choices: The girl has gained access to the city
124.content:
Over and through the walls the guards quickly identified the attackers and were able to get rid of them. It was a small skirmish for now, a mere group of travellers desperate for entry who had been rejected earlier in the day, rather than an enemy attack. It took a matter of moments to identify the threat and cause the attackers to flee in terror.

Once the attackers had been dealt with the guard turned their attention back to where the girl had been earlier. But both girl and animal were gone!!
124.title: A brief struggle

choices: Dauphin manages to free her hands
1241.content:
Dauphin awoke in darkness, her head spinning. She tried to reach out her hand but discovered that she was bound. She could hear the thundering of hooves however, so it was evident she was a captive of someone or something. But what did they want with her? And where were they going?

She fought desperately against her bonds once again. They couldn't be that tight surely?
1241.title: Captured

choices: Delphina goes to speak to Cardac alone
12411.content:
Dauphin heard the transport stop and felt strong arms drag her out of the carriage. Looking around she was horrified to realise she was back in the land of Cardac again, after she had tried so hard to escape and gotten so far.

The guards handled her roughly, dragging her towards the palace gates. So, her disobedience was to be punished by the King himself!

"Move girl. We haven't got all day," said the one in charge, yanking the rope that held her roughly.

"I wouldn't treat her like that if I were you."

The comment was spoken in a quiet voice but turning to face the speaker the guard was immediately silent. Dauphin knew who it would be, and was not suprised to turn and face her sister Delphina.

"I am to take her from here. Give her to me," she commanded and without a single question the guards stood aside. After all it did not do to question the heir to the throne.

Delphina undid Dauphin's bonds and led her in through the gates.

"I'm sorry. Is he very angry?" Dauphin whispered.

"What do you expect?" Delphina asked wryly, "You should know not to cross our father like that now."

"You know how much I needed to escape. It's alright for you as the elder twin but me..." Dauphin said, on the brink of tears.

"I know," Delphina replied.
12411.title: Sisters

choices: Ask the man what he means
12412.content:
Dauphin managed to free her hands, what do they want with me she thought again to her self. She noticed that the ground below her seemed to be moving and realized that she was in some sort of carriage. She reached for her sword, but it was not there.

The horses stopped and she could hear someone coming to check on her. Panicing, Dauphin quickly tried to tie the rope back on her hands. The door to the carriage opened and she could hear two voices. One she recognised as the leader of the warriors that kidnapped her and the other one she had never heard before. As soon as her eyes adjusted to the light she could see the leader and a tall man wearing a cloak.

"Is this her?" the tall man asked.

"Yes," replied the other.

"Good the master will be pleased," the man in the cloak looked down at Dauphin and after examining the ropes he got really mad.

"Fool!" he yelled at the other man, "Any idiot can escape from ropes this loose! You know how much power she has - what if she were to escape?"

Dauphin looked up at him confused. How much power she had. What power? She didn't know that she had any power.
12412.title: The carriage

124121.content:
"What exactly do you mean, sir?" Dauphin asked haughtily. The cloaked man looked at her astutely. "Are you sure this is the one?" He asked the cowering man behind him.

"Her name is Dauphin." The man, a servant of some kind, answered shakily.

"Is it?" The man's master asked Dauphin. The girl raised her chin sharply. "Yes, you are the one. Now, I knew your father, and I know your kind's tricks. You'd best be advised to stay quiet."

Dauphin opened her mouth again but the man clamped a hand over it. "Quiet." He demanded quickly and Dauphin nodded compliantly. He smiled and stood, sweeping away. Dauphin looked at the servant. He was a weasel like man, stooped and beady eyed. She could tell he wasn't about to help her. Instead he eyed her greedily. "Give it to me."

"Give you what?" Dauphin began to wonder if this man was mad.

"The--the p-power." The man was so excited he began to stutter. "Give me the stone."

"What stone?"
124121.title: The Stone?

1241211.content:
"The stone, the stone! Don't play stupid with me, girl - you know as well as I of what I speak! Your father had it, had it for all his life, but not at his death..."

"Death? My father.... My father's dead?" Dauphin didn't know what else to say. She should say something more, she knew. She should feel something, too - sad; angry, if nothing else - but she couldn't find any emotion of that sort within her. It was a simple fact, and she was fine with it. In a way, that scared her more than the news.

"Of course! Times are changing, and rulers must change with them! If they don't, well, then others must take charge! But without the stone, without the power, Lord Greensword cannot properly claim the throne. He must have given it to you, so tell me where it is!"

"I. Don't. Know." Dauphin spoke through gritted teeth, trying to hide her inner turmoil from the weasel.

"Come now, there's no need to think me your enemy! You can have a place of power within the new order. Your father was never kind to you, was he? No need to tell, he confessed it all before he - died."

So others now knew. Dauphin had run from her father, abandoned her birthright, because of what had gone on behind closed doors within the palace. She'd never told anyone, and she doubted that her father would, as the shame of such a secret becoming public would be no good for someone of his position. But to tell all on his deathbed? It didn't sound like him, somehow....

The weasel was talking again, holding her chin up with one of his emaciated hands, the nails digging into her cheeks.

"Believe me, girl, I can be more persuasive if I put my mind to it. It would be well for you to tell me now, to give me the p-power, and n-not make me ressort t-to..."

He paused, withdrawing his hand and clamping it to his eye.

"Not now, not now, wait..." It was whispered under his breath, but Dauphin heard it all the same. Maybe now was the perfect moment to attempt an escape, while the man was distracted....
1241211.title: Bad News About Your Father...

choices: Try to struggle out of the ropes.
124122.content:
The men drag Dauphin outside, into a growling horde of monsters. A skinny Goblin pokes a stick at her and an Imp cackles. She shuts her eyes tight, horrified. Dauphin is slammed into the ground, and roughly tied to a wooden stake. Squinting her eyes, she glances around her.
Tied to a stake to her right, is a worn-looking Hobgoblin. He looks over to her and smiles encouragingly.
"Whats your name, little one?"
124122.title: Remain silent

1242.content:
With a smile, Dauphin and her steed were walking along the main street of the city. Immediately she was able to see how many refugees from the north the city had attracted. A lot of goblins, thin, ugly creatures stood huddled around a pitiul fire in front of a store. Once, she even thought she spied the ethereal beauty of an elf but the crowd began to thicken as the day wore on and she shook her head of fanciful thoughts.

"What should I do first?" she wondered absently, reaching the crossroads. "Shall I find the nearest inn or go immediately to the king and offer my services?"
1242.title: Inside the City

12421.content:
"The inn," she decided aloud, fearing that by delaying in seeking a room she would find herself huddled over her own fire that night.

She continued on until she found herself standing infront of a dilapidated inn whose painted placard proclaimed it to be 'The King's Way Inn and Tavern.'

"Better here than nowhere," she thought absently and walked into the ailing building.

Inside she found more goblins and a few trolls. The dank atmosphere caused her skin to crawl but she plodded through the crowd until she reached the dark counter behind which one of the largest men she'd ever chanced to see stood.

"What d'ya want?" he roared above the din of the paying customers.

"A room and a meal," Dauphin stated simply.
12421.title: To the inn

124211.content:
With no further argument, the inn keeper took her money and handed her a key, pointing down a hallway at the back of the main room.

'You're in luck, our previous guest only left this morning. I'm sure that there's more than a few others out there who'd be glad of a roof over their heads tonight...'

Dauphin made her excuses and went straight to her room. She had no time to waste in idle chit chat with the man, and she had no taste to hang around for too long in the bar.

When she got there, she soon found out what the barman had meant by 'left'. The bloodstains on the wall above the small bed's headboard were still quite fresh. What could have happened here?
124211.title: There IS Room At The Inn!

choices: Go and listen at the window
1242111.content:
Dauphin needed her sleep - it was too late to find anywhere else to stay and besides, what could happen in just one night after all? With little thought of anything but sleep she quickly undressed and got into bed.

Little more than an hour later, Dauphin awoke to the sound of voices. Although they were talking lowly she still had the reflexes of a cat, awakening to the slightest sound. Someone was talking quietly in the street below.
1242111.title: Troubled sleep

choices: Dauphin swiftly goes to meet the king
Dauphin gathers her steed and prepares to silently follow the king
12421111.content:
"Have you horses ready?" A clear male voice inquired. The owner of the voice was shrouded in a black cloak. The horse holding him up was white as snow and well-trained - one might have thought a statue had been placed under the window that night.

"They are ready, m'lord," a second voice whispered. It, too, sounded male. Dauphin could not see the second man - shadows from a broken streetlamp covered him.

"It is time then," the noble responded. He sighed. "It is time for me to leave my city. This impending war is growing too steadily. We must be swift and sure and cut it at its source."

"But - your highness - YOU should not be the one to lead battles! You know your place is in the city." Within the shadows, a crystal ball appeared. "I will arrange for the Golden Knights to escort you back to the palace."

"Grim!" Dauphin now realized the king was below and willing to wage war himself! "Grim... I must do this. I am not a king who stands idly by."

As the two men argued politely below, Dauphin awakened fully. She bit her lip as she decided what to do.
12421111.title: Night time Quandry

choices: You have to prove you can fight
124211111.content:
Without hesataion she jumped out of the window. Of course this startled the king and his men had there swords drawn in a moment and had them at her throst before she could even get up.

"Who are you?" said the first voice she heard.

"I wanted to see the king," she said.

"You have no business with the king," he growled in her face.

"STOP," the king bellowed. "Why do you seek me?"

"I wish to offer my services to you," she said.

"And what services do you have to offer me?" asked the king in a stern voice.

"I-I-I can sing."

All three men went limp and stared at her with eyes wide open. "What!" they said simultaneously.

"I wish to keep you entertained on your journey," she answered.

"Well then, give us a song right now," said the king.

"Okay," she answered, took a deep breath and started singing.

"Sometimes in the dead of the night I'm dreaming that I'm flying at the speed of light. Two seconds, I'm brushing past the face of the moon. Eight seconds flat, on the surface of Mars I'm kicking up the red dust. I'm drinking at bars, lean back, I raise a toast to the stars and I... well I'mm dreaming at the speed of light. Some days I just settle for the speed of sound. step off this porch, I blow a kiss to this whole damn town. Let off one of them sonic booms and break all the windows in the living room. Your love makes me move at this speed, if trees lay down some roots of grown eyes full of maple leaves, but if it weren't for that face of yours I'd be rattling windows and blowing down doors. Look at me here I'm planted square down on my knees, oh on my knees, asking for the speed of trees."

"Not bad, I will have to think about it."
124211111.title: A song for the king

choices: KIll the king while guarding him
guard him with your life while providing entertainment
1242111112.content:
Dauphin quickly kicked at the kings servant knocking his sword form his hand. She then drew hers and blocked an oncoming swing. Sparks flew into the air like fireworks. Duaphin rolled backward avoiding a blade stroke from the kings royal guard. she then jumped up and pointed her sword at his throat.

All of the kings guards looked at her with a look of acceptance.

The king then stated "You may acompany us".
1242111112.title: Proving worthiness

12421111121.content: They walked into the night until they came to a resting point. They went into the inn and rented a room. While the guards stayed outside the door watching the room Dauphin went in to see the king. He was sitting at a desk working on papers. She stealthily got behind himdrawing her knife. When she was within range she pounced on him cutting his throat quickly and quietly. His eyes glazed over with expression of death. She quickly withdrew the sacred amulet from his neck. She then went to the window and looked down to the street. It was a 10 story drop.
12421111121.title: The amulet

choices: The amulet responds - but not in the way Dauphin would have hoped
The king's personal wizard snares Dauphin with his magic
124211111211.content:
She'd come so far. What was a little fall, eh?

The gasps of astonishment as guards burst in behind her was all the convincing that Dauphin needed. Taking a deep breath, she jumped through the glass of the window, toppling head-first towards the ground. Seeing her doom approaching at such a speed, she clutched the amulet tighter.

With it acting as a focus for her magicks, surely she should be able to survive the drop, or fly, or something. Anything!

Screwing her eyes tight, she willed the arcane energies pent up within her to intervene, to save her one last time and not make her recent murder a worthless act.
124211111211.title: JUMP!

12421112.content:
She listened carefully, but could not hear anything significant being spoken. She yawned and decided to go back to sleep.

Just as she was about to go into a deep sleep, she was woken up again. It wasn't voices that woke her up, but fighting outside her bedroom door. She jumped out of bed and dressed quickly.

She held her sword in her hand and tiptoed to the door. Opening it little, she saw a fierce battle ensuing. There were twenty men in the room and all of them were hacking everything that was in their way. Blood and guts splattered everywhere. Clearly, they were murderers that wanted something. She did not know what to do. Should she stay here and wait until they have gone or should she fight against twenty strong, dangerous men?
12421112.title: Battle

1242112.content:
A closer inspection of the blood stains on the wall made her stomach turn.

"Oh God," she groaned. "I can't do this."

With several whistful thoughts of a hot meal and a few hours sleep, she gathered her things and turned back towards the door. In the dim light, a shimmer from beneath the cupboard caught her eye. Leaning down, she took a closer look. A blade. Pulling it out gently, she found it to be a simple steel blade; straight and unadorned apart from a jewel the size of her thumbnail embedded in the hilt.

"Strange," she thought aloud. "So austere a weapon, with such a beautiful stone."

Slipping the blade into her belt, she quickly fled the room. She made her way quietly through the common room and out into the stables.
1242112.title: A surprising find

choices: Dauphin decides to get a bite to eat
12421121.content:
Her faelan was there. Dauphin was quite relieved, as at first she had been cautious about putting her expensive, beloved faelan in the inn's stables.

She mounted her faelan. The raining had faded to a drizzle, and Dauphin pulled her hood down. The young woman didn't mind getting wet a little. After all, Dauphin had an amazingly strong and immune body compared to most.

Once again, she rode off. It was good thing that the innkeeper gave Dauphin's gold back, and certainly staying in a room where a murder had recently occurred was never really a favorite thing of hers. Plus, she had felt bad vibes in that room for some reason. Dauphin was now to look for a good, better inn, wherever she could find one, and the refugees were taking up a lot of space.

The refugees as in some of the victims of the vicious, mean Cardac and his merciless army.

Dauphin knew that they were heading to this same city at the very moment. Tommorow she would warn the King, and anything else that would be necessary to prevent any more heavy bloodshed.
12421121.title: For A Better Inn

choices: Dauphin insists upon a room - it's getting late
Dauphin leaves to go somewhere less dangerous
124212.content:
"In case you haven't noticed," the bartender said slowly, sweeping his arms wide to draw Dauphin's attentions to the rest of the room, "this is a bar strictly for persons of the non-human persuasion. We don't want your sort here."

Dauphin looked around, seeing that several of the creatures around the inn, whether bulky troll or scrawny goblin, were looking right back at her, their eyes narrowed and glaring. All had gone quiet and several weapons were being idly brushed with taloned fingers.

She sighed. How did these sort of things always happen to her?
124212.title: A Hostile Reception?

choices: Stay in the bar a little longer
1242121.content:
Ah well... here we go again. "I'm not human," Dauphin said softly. "Well, not fully human...."

"You look human enough to me." The bartender's smirk was mocking.

"I am... what is called a Sharle, or a Creanth. I don't know what it would be in your languages," she added apologetically in the general direction of the other customers.

They all understood. An empty space formed around Dauphin. Some of the creatures looked scared, others uncomfortable or sullen. Quiet whispers passed between them and none would meet her eye. It always happened this way. She always tried to hide who she was as long as possible. At least there was no weapon in sight now.

"Are you trying to scare all my customers away?" the bartender demanded angrily. Indeed, the bar had become noticeably emptier. Dauphin mentally grinned: it was as if the man's position gave him the courage to face her that was lacking in trolls almost twice his size.

"I don't want to cause trouble," said Dauphin pleadingly. "I just want a meal and a place for the night. I won't bother anyone."

Just then, someone remarked audibly, "Some humans have no taste! To cross..." Dauphin shot a cold stare in the direction of the remark.

"If humans have no taste, how come no human has ever crossbred with a troll OR a goblin?"

"That's just because they have no taste," piped up a shortish, skinny goblin to some nervous laughter. Mostly, the bar's patrons just wanted to escape her attention.

Just then, the barman addressed her again. "What will the creanth have for dinner?"

"Human food, of course," Dauphin said firmly.

"Well, we don't have much demand for that, but I think we could find you some... beef. And perhaps I could fix you some potatoes..."

"That would be just fine, thank you."

The man disappeared in the kitchen.

As she was waiting for the food, Dauphin thought that there was something unusual about this bar. Despite the bar's refusal to admit human customers, the barman was obviously human. And, as she observed, the relationship that existed between him and the bar's non-human customers was friendly, if on the gruff side. As the girl watched, a large troll ordered a drink, threatening to eat the barman if he didn't like it. The man just laughed, saying, "If you do, where will you get your next one? No-one else will serve you in this town." The drink finally arrived, and the troll quaffed it on the spot, apparently satisfied.... Then there was the way the man had called her a creanth. That would make him Fahrian, or possibly Seraelite. A long way from home, either way.... A most curious place.

It was obvious that the cook wasn't very familiar with human food, but it was edible. It filled the stomach, too. After the last two weeks, that was more than satisfactory.

Dauphin scanned the crowd again. They were still avoiding her eyes. Some of them were probably discussing her, judging by the furtive looks thrown in her direction, but they made sure to keep their voices too low for her to hear. It always happened this way. Dauphin knew she was safe here: no-one would be stupid enough to challenge her now that they knew who she was. Still, sometimes she just wished not to be such a freak, despite all the powers she had.

Dauphin felt a sudden desire to go to one of the little groups of drinkers and just talk, or even join in the horrible song trilled badly by a drunken goblin and his rowdy friends in a corner. No, they would all run away if she approached. She felt very alone. Always alone.

Dauphin decided to...
1242121.title: Feared and friendless

choices: Ask the meaning of the tune
12421211.content:
She ventured next to the goblins only to hear a very sad croon sung by the monsters in unison.
May we survive
May we endure
May our lives
Be ever pure....
12421211.title: What are they singing?

choices: Try and investigate the rose further
12421212.content:
There was no point in staying in such a sociable place when no one wanted to be sociable with her.

"My room?"

Sighing slightly the barman handed Dauphin a large brass key.

"Through that door, up the stairs, third on the left."

Leaving a gold coin on the bar, far exceeding payment for a room and a meal Dauphin proceeded upstairs. Placing her key in the door she opened her room. It was simple but would do for the night - she had no desire to stay any longer than that.

Keeping her belongings, especially her sword, with her at all times Dauphin relocked the door and went to the bathroom at the other side of the corridor. Washing away the dirt of her long journey was necessary before sleep and did not take long thankfully.

Unlocking her door again to re enter her room, Dauphin immediately registered something was different. Her sword was drawn before her eyes had even fully recognised the difference - on the before empty bed a single red rose. The rest of the room was empty still.

Who could have left such a gift? And why? Whatever the case, she did not find it threatening. It was more comforting that in her loneliness maybe someone out there cared.
12421212.title: Alone or not?

124212121.content:
As tempting as it may be to study the rose's reason for appearance, she settled with the idea of it just being a small compliment of the tavern's. Dauphin reluctantly ventured onto the solid structure the owner called a bed.

"They ought to just call it a rock," she mumbled under her soft, slowing breath. As she was dozing off, a soft crooning from the trolls floated through her room.

"May we survive
May we endure
May our lives
Be ever pure
Thank the creator
For what he has given
Is it just fate, or
Is life just graven
May we survive...."
124212121.title: Songs of sleep and survival

124212122.content:
Dauphin sniffed the lovely rose again. Her eyes glanced upon it, only to notice an inscription.

"Those who smell, are to dwell amongst the souls."

Dauphin fell to her knees and rolled back to fall into an endless sleep.
124212122.title: Rose of... passion?

1242122.content:
Memories of her father the village blacksmith came to mind as Dauphin thought twice before speaking. It was very painful for her to have traveled so far to assist the village and now she was being treated like the enemy. Her father had told her she was to earn the trust of the village before she would be accepted in any foreign land.

The troll leaned toward her and noticed her oval shaped earrings encrusted with rubies. They were a gift from her father. They belonged to her mother whom had passed away while giving birth to her in the bath house. The mid wife said she was too small to bear a baby as big as Dauphin.

"Your earrings, give them to me, they are mine, you stole them, you are a thief! I will call the police and demand that you return them to my safe!"

Trolls were known to lie and cheat everyone. That is why the kingdom was in such ruins. Dauphin remembered her grandfather the village baker whose father was the nephew of the king of Octavias. He had dealings with the trolls back in the old kingdom. Her grandfather left the royal palace to take up baking, a craft he learned from the palace baker whom he fell madly in love with and bore her father. This had caused him to lose his place in the line of succession, because the King had an arranged marriage arranged for him with the Princess of Emerald. He did not agree with the arrangement because there was a condition in the marriage that stated her grandfather, Alcheas, must wear a skirt and leggings at all times and also he had to cut his ponytail off and allow the Princess of Emerald to boss him around. This was something he could not deal with.

Dauphin used her knowledge of the trolls and their greedy ways to bribe the inn keeper into allowing her to stay in the tower area of the inn. She asked where was the fresh bread.

"Bread, we haven't had bread for years? What are you a crazed maiden or something, everyone knows there is not a crumb to be found in the kingdom."

"Oh, I apologize for my ignorance," she whispered. "I can make bread from a white powder called flour."

"A white what you crazy gal?!" He tossed his head back and laughed loudly, revealing all the gold in his mouth that trolls were notorious for having in their teeth. He also had a huge gold celtic cross around his neck with a massive chain that seemed to weigh five pounds. The band played the troll music of the alleys, expressing their feelings of that period, which were violent tunes with trolls dancing around on stage acting like they were committing violent acts against one another. There was ale all over the floor. One of them tossed a cup over her head and she did not react as her father had warned her.

"Tolerance" she remembered he had taught her as a child, telling her stories of his travels to shoe the horses in the village of the trolls and how they were so anti-human.
1242122.title: Gaining the Trust of the Inn Keeper

12422.content:
"I'd best not dawdle," Dauphin thought to herself. "I shall travel to the King immediately."

Turning to the left fork of the crossroad, Dauphin gently nudged her steed onward toward the palace. Ever so slowly, she entered a more respectable part of the city. The streets cleared of refugees, the homeless and other undesirables. Beautiful stone and marble houses rose on both sides as she passed by. Eventually, the houses grew to mansions and suspicious eyes of private guards began to watch her progress.

Within moments, the palace came into view, a giant sprawling building designed to awe the visitor and display the grander of the city. Having travelled widely, Dauphin remained unimpressed. The place could easily be overrun, captured and sacked, she thought cynically.

Her opinion of the palace did not improve after meeting the Royal Guardsmen manning the main gate. They were distracted by the wet, miserable weather, and looked to her professional eye to be unworthy and slothful in their duties. After the briefest of challenges, she was granted entrance to the palace. The city was at war, as she was granted easy entrance to the palace! What if she'd been an assassin?

The King could most definitely use her services against the armies of Cardac, for she, Dauphin, was a...
12422.title: To Serve the King...

choices: Demonic creatures come, seeking out the girl
The city is attacked by human forces
124222.content:
Dauphin knew she was playing with fire coming this far. Her kind were loathed by the peasants, seen as the source of the evil that had swept the borderlands and, even now, inched its way towards the capital.

She didn't blame them but she hoped the King would know better. In this instance, sorcerors were just like people: some good, like the healers of the past, and some pure evil, like the invading Cardac.

Dauphin had walked with fire. She knew what the dark side looked like and felt its sensual allure. Yet somehow she had overcome the dark calling, escaping to the last true refuge left open to her.

It did not matter. The darkness would follow. She just needed enough time to warn the King first.
124222.title: Dark days are coming

choices: Dauphin calls out a challenge to the demons
Dauphin returns the way she came
1242221.content:
The king's audience chamber, to which the ushers had directed her, seemed an agony away. The blood-red carpet strecthed onwards further and further the more Dauphin walked toward the far door, and it was clear that she was making no progress.

She stopped. Magic.

Looking around, she focussed her inner sight, hoping for a glimpse of her attackers. But amongst the antique columns and works of art that lined the processional, she could sense no presence, no human soul lingering.

Which meant that it was demons, not humans, that stalked her. Alone, in a building warped by their desires, she stood little chance against them. But sometimes a little was all one needed.
1242221.title: Demonic

choices: The Arbiter, and ancient powerful and evil demon
12422211.content:
"Come on!!" She cried out. "Are you afraid to fight me?!!!!! I do not fear you!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"
"You should"
She whirled around to see
12422211.title: Dauphin calls out a challenge to the demons

choices: a beautiful woman in a sky blue robe.
a tall, shadowy figure hidden in cloak and cowl.
125.content:
As the guards drew their weapons, a voice sounded in their head. "Be at ease. That was of my doing. The young warrior was being followed by an ingenious device, one crafted of equal parts spell and machinery. I merely took the liberty to ensure the device would no longer dog her tracks."

The rider looked around, trying to find the source of the voice that was in her head. There was a mental chuckle. "Be at ease, Dauphin. I am not entering your thoughts, merely projecting my own into your mind. I mean you no harm. Indeed, you and your faelan will prove most useful to the defense of the city in days to come."

There was a commotion among the guards as another figure entered the area, obviously the source of the voice in their minds. The figure was...
125.title: Taking liberties

choices: sneak in with you so it could spy on the city
1251.content:
Dauphin was overwhelmed by the woman before her. She couldn't believe that this was truly just a woman. She was the most beautiful vision she had ever seen. Surely she must be dreaming!

The blue clad woman laughed, obviously used to this reaction. Even some of the guards, who were used to her presence, were a bit slow in moving in the woman's presence. One of the guards brought a pile of burnt items to lay before the woman's feet.

The woman's brow furrowed as she studied the destroyed remains of whatever had been tracking Dauphin.

"Very ingenious. Our enemies are growing cleverer... and bolder as well."

"What---what was it?" Dauphin managed to stutter.

"An invisible tracker. It was meant to..."
1251.title: The remains of the tracker

choices: Continue through the gates without another word to the queen
12512.content:
"It is a spy, meant to enter our cities and eavesdrop on our defences. I must say, they are clever."

The blue robed woman bent down and picked up one of the charred remains. "Although they must have forgotten that the guiggens used to spy aren't exactly waterproof."

The woman started to chuckle. She looked at the girl and smiled. "My name is Queen Elflaed, I grant you safe passage though my city."

The girl couldn't help but smile, it was impossible not to feel happy and fearless while the queen looked at her. Her eyes were as green as blades of grass in the morning dew, her wavy red hair lay lightly in the air, it looked as if it wasn't even affected by the pouring rain. The girl finally managed to speak after several seconds, "Yes, thank you, your majesty."
12512.title: The Beautiful Queen

choices: The queen continues to be helpful and friendly
The queen is brusque and rude
125122.content:
Queen Elflaed stepped forward, no more noticeably relaxed inside the city's heavily fortified walls than outside them. Dauphin was a different sort. Quickly she stepped past the city's heavily fortified walls, glancing up in admiration. Though she wore thick mocassins suited to nearly any sort of weather, she had been walking for more days than she cared to count, and her mocassins had begun to wear. Puddles of water which had collected on the city streets, and the tiny rivults which ran accross the dark stones, did little to help. She shivered as she felt the water seep through the loose stitching, and she wondered where she could find lodging here.

"Queen," she spoke faintly, eyes lowered both in respect, "can I ask, do you know of any good inns this side of the city?"
125122.title: Inside the City

1252.content:
As the figure emerged from the shadows it removed the hood to reveal a youth of about ninteen. He had fair hair and the bluest eyes and, as the two guards turned and noticed him, they stood at attention.

"It's the crown prince," she heard one of the guards say.

"That is a very nice faelan you've got there," the prince said. "Where did you get it from?"
1252.title: Prince abroad

choices: Ask the prince why he helped her?
12521.content:
"When I was ten, I journeyed to the Isle of Faenalen."

The guards gasped. This Isle the girl so calmly spoke of was the one place that wild faelans could be found!

"There, through a series of adventures, I met and befriended this noble beast."
12521.title: To catch a faelan...

choices: Dauphin attends dinner at the palace
Dauphin refuses the prince, and he's not happy
125212.content:
"But that's a matter for another time. Why do you interfere here, Prince..?"

"Oh, you don't know my name?" The young man laughed. "My, but you are an ignorant one, aren't you? It is below my royal person to answer such trivial questions."

Catching his meaning, one of the gate guards piped up. "This is Crown Prince Pliant, milady. He -"

The guardv was silenced as Pliant held up a hand. "That's enough. As to why I chose to aid you here, I do as I wish, my reasons not for the lower orders to wonder of. However," and here his eyes twinkled, "if you would do yourself the pleasure of having dinner with me tonight in the palace, mayhap I may be persuaded to be more... forthcoming."

Dauphin really didn't know what to say. Obviously, she needed to get inside the city, and to offend the Crown prince would not be a good idea, but after how she'd seen him deal with other people she wasn't sure if she wanted to spend even another moment in his wretched company.
125212.title: Crown Prince Pliant

choices: Prince: "You lie!  Guards, away with her!"
Prince: "Your father knew Captain Typo?  Tell me more!"
12522.content:
"Your highness," said Dauphin, bowing. "I am the daughter of the captain of a merchant ship. My father once befriended the famed pirate Jimmy Typo. The last time that my father met Jimmy Typo and his murderous band on the high seas, Jimmy recognized him and gifted him with this beautiful faelan."

Dauphin's countenance took on a sad, faraway look. "He brought it to me last winter for safekeeping." She sighed, "Alas, my father and his men were lost in the huge typhoon of last season and I will never see him again."

The prince and the guards listened attentively until she finished her story, then the prince stepped forward, eyes flashing.
12522.title: A lie will keep us high and dry

choices: Try and find somewhere to stay for the night
Explore your new home under the cover of darkness
13.content:
"Identification?"

The girl walked over to near the gate and placed into a hole in the wall her small identification card. Within a matter of seconds the card had been read and approved, so the guards stood aside to let the girl pass through into the city.

Making a small whistle like noise the girl walked towards the gates, and her animal, previously still, followed unled through the gates. There was total obedience from the faelan to its master.

Getting through the city gates is not the same thing as being in the heart of the city. Indeed the several gates to a city are purposefully set at least an hour on foot beyond the city centre, so that even if the gates are breached there is still quite a distance to be covered. A decision had to be made on what direction to head, as strangers wandering round aimlessly were still under suspicion.
13.title: Inside the gates

choices: They claim to have never heard of him
131.content:
Wandering round at night was never advisable however, and Dauphin knew the safest idea would be to find somewhere to stay the night before attempting to go to the castle in the morning. Not that that would be easy, but she was determined if there was going to be a war against Cardac then she would do all she could.

Dauphin removed from her pocket a small map. She thought she could find the place... although it was a long time since she had seen Tamor, it was easier to look up old friends than wander around in the dark. She just hoped he would remember her!

Arriving at a small house, she was suprised to see the lights still on. At least she could feel less guilty about waking anybody up as she knocked.

The door opened a few inches.

"Yes?"
131.title: Finding rest

choices: Discuss why you are here with Tamor
1311.content:
Despite the gloom Dauphin could see the welcome was not a friendly one. The person on the other side of the door was armed, and looked as likely to kill her as let her in.

"Is that the way to greet someone who once saved your life Tamor?" she asked.

"Arian?" came the incredulous reply.

"It's Dauphin now... but yes."

And with that, Tamor flung the door open and embraced her.

"Took your time didn't you?" he asked.

"I've been busy. But I'm here now aren't I?" she replied.

"Well from now on I am your obedient servant."

"All I need now is a bed for the night... and somewhere for my faelan, of course."
1311.title: Old friends

choices: Find Tamor and ask for his help
Leave for the palace straight away
13111.content:
Tamor showed Dauphin up to a small room and left her to herself. It was nice to have friends who would ask so few questions as she desperately needed sleep. She would need all of her wits in the morning after all, so rest was all she needed for now. She lay down and drifted off into dream land.

Morning however came too soon. Dauphin awoke in the room and knew it was time for action.
13111.title: Sleep

131111.content:
When morning came, Dauphin set out to find Tamor, but he wasn't in the house. She looked for a note and found one tacked to the door of the stall where the faelan slept.

"Gone to the market, be back in 15 minutes."
131111.title: Note Found

1311111.content:
She sighed and walked into the large stall, "Well boy, I guess I'll stay here and wait for him."

The faelen bobbed his head and touched it to her shoulder. .:Where are we going to go?:. His mindvoice asked her.

"To the palace. Cardac will be here within a week and the King needs to be warned."

.:Are we to fight again?:. The mindvoice had a trace of weariness in it.

"Yes. I know you're tired, I am too, but I cannot bear to see this city fall."

.:I understand:.

"I knew you would," Dauphin laid her head on the faelan's broad shoulder and waited for her friend to return.
1311111.title: Discussion with a faelan

choices: Tamor asks more about the 'big business'.
Dauphin says she wants to eat first.
13111111.content:
Tamor returned very soon, making Dauphin relieved. Fifteen minutes, to be exact, and Dauphin's friend always kept his promises.

"Good morning to you," Tamor said good-naturedly, putting down his many, abundant groceries on a sturdy table. He was much older than the young woman, and they had known each other for quite a while.

"Nice to see you again so quickly. You've certainly bought a lot of things, and, trust me, I don't each that much," spoke Dauphin. She eyed the assortment of newly bought food.

"Well, then. More for me, and, anyways, what shall we have today? Perhaps I can make something with this delicious cheese," Tamor suggested, as he picked up a small wheel of parmesan and sniffed it. Tamor was a big lover of cheese.

"Whatever you wish. Tamor, you certainly are a good cook, and I would eat anything you'd whip up, but remember that I'm not just here to sample your cooking. After all, I have big business to do. And I mean big business," acknowledged Dauphin.
13111111.title: Big Business

131111112.content:
"What business is that?" Tamor asked. "Before you answer, we should eat something. Surely you are too hungry to tell me this business now?"

"I guess you are right. It has been a while since I had a decent meal." Dauphin looked at him.

"So what will it be?"

"Anything that is simple and easy to make." She smiled at him.

"Well, there is cheese and bread, or would you prefer a warm soup?"

"A soup is such a hassle to make. I know it will be a bother to you."

"Oh no, not at all. I can make it quickly." Tamor started to walk to a kitchen bench, readying what he needed for the soup. He chopped vegetables and meat and put them in a boiling cauldron.

"It should be ready soon." Tamor sat on a chair next to Dauphin. "So what big business have you to tell me?"

"I..." Dauphin started. She was about to explain everything to him, when a man rushed into the inn. He was carrying a sword and his face was bloodied.

"Quickly, the gates are under attack! We are outnumbered! We can only defend it for a few minutes!" He shouted with alarm and rapidly rushed back outside.

"Under attack!" shouted Tamor with surprise. "From whom?"

"Cardac." Dauphin whispered. "Listen," Dauphin continued, "This is the big business that I was meant to tell you. I will tell you along the way if you come with me now. Are you coming Tamor?"
131111112.title: Meal Interrupted

choices: Dauphin tries to convince him not to go with her
131112.content:
It would have been polite to go downstairs and thank Tamor for his hospitality. However, Dauphin had no desire to drag him into all this. It was best for him to remain unaware of her true purpose in the land, so no blame would fall on his shoulders if she failed.

Regreting leaving her friend she exited swiftly through the window. To bump straight into Tamor!

"Now where do you think you're going?"

"I needed some air," she replied.

"A likely story. I've been watching your window for three hours now, guessing you would do something like this."
131112.title: Predictability

choices: Tamor insists on taking Dauphin to see someone right away
13112.content:
As the faelan was led away by Tamor's manservant, Tamor invited Dauphin to sit at his table while he prepared them both a hot drink.

"You look as though you need it," he smiled.

She returned the compliment and he disappeared into a back room. She had time to look around, and saw that Tamor's spartan outlook on life hadn't really changed, even after all these years. His only decoration seemed to be the unsheathed blade that was mounted above the hearth, a memory of his other life, before he had become civilised and moved south.

"So, what brings you to my door?" his voice travelled from the open doorway.

"War is coming," she replied simply. "Cardac is on the move."

"That's hardly news," he told her as he returned, two steaming mugs in his thin hands, "the whole city has been in uproar for weeks. Refugees, evacuees, mercenaries - I've seen them all. This place is ready to burst. Were Cardac to arrive tomorrow, we'd be taken in a day."

"That may be somewhere where I can help." Dauphin said, letting the heat of the cup warm her chilled hands. "I haven't come all this way to see this town burn. And we have less than a week until Cardac arrives."

"A week! It's not me that you should be telling this news to!"
13112.title: A Brief Respite

choices: Insist on resting. The situation can wait.
Go with him. He's right, waiting could cost them.
131121.content:
"We must tell someone right away!" Tamor exclaimed practically jumping through the roof.

"Who?"

"Who else? Alczar of course! He must know this information right away!" he could barely contain himself.

"Well, all right. But I am really tired," she said slowly after a long pause. She was really tired and it was very visible on her face.

"I know but if we wait it could be dire!"
131121.title: The situation

choices: Go home and try and get an appointment in the morning
1311212.content:
Alczar was the governor of the whole region, so getting to see him in the middle of the night was easier said than done. Upon arriving at the mansion where he resided the armed guard refused to even pass on any messages.

"We'll have to wait till morning then," Tamor said dispirited. "God knows what this delay will cost them."

Dauphins eyes were alert however. Years of fighting the enemy had given her a natural ability to search for weaknesses in strongholds, and the building was certainly not entirely inpenetrable.

"Not if we break in and see him tonight," she calmly replied.
1311212.title: Plans

choices: the governor listens to Dauphin's news
the governor has her put in the dungeon
13112121.content:
“Come, let us find Leczinska,” said Dauphin to Tamor, loudly enough for the guards to hear. They made their way along the outer wall of the governor’s mansion. The guards' gazes followed them. "Who is Leczinska?" asked Tamor. "An excuse in this direction," said Dauphin. "When we reach this corner go back to the guards. Tell them I have gone to find someone to convince them to let us in and implore them once again for our admittance. As you speak with them, I will seek a more direct path to the governor."

They reached the corner. Tamor turned back towards the guards, shielding Dauphin from their view as she deftly turned the corner hugging the wall. As she suspected, there were other guards down the wall on this side too, but her movement had been slight enough to escape their attention. She heard Tamor, in a loud voice, again imploring the guards for admittance. Looking down the wall, Dauphin saw a tree whose branches were just inside the grounds. Slowly unfastening a cord around her waist, she fixed her gaze on the guards in the darkness ahead. Just then, a sound from down the road caught their attention. In a flash she had lassoed the tree branch with her rope and pulled herself over the wall.

Dauphin gazed from behind the tree at the large stone mansion before her. A distance of about 50 feet separated the wall and the mansion, which was surrounded by a gravel path. She furtively began to edge away from the wall when she heard footsteps on the path. She ducked behind her tree again then glanced out to see a patrol of four guards go by. As they turned the corner, she glanced around again and spied a small doorway on the side of the mansion. Seeing no sign of more guards, she darted silently for the doorway. Upon reaching it, she found it descended a few steps to a passage which was barred by a large knobless wooden door. She went down to it and listened for any sounds on the other side. Nothing. She groped for some means of opening the door, but on pressing her hand on it, the door slid silently open. She was in.

The corridor before her was dimly lit with torches. She went forward slowly. Soon she came to another door, this time with a handle. She opened it. It led to a further corridor. She had not gone more than a few steps when the door slammed violently shut behind her. Without much choice she went forward, even more stealthily now. The corridor opened on what appeared to be a large rotunda, though she could make out very little of it in the darkness. She thought she heard movements as she stepped towards the center of the room.

Suddenly the room was ablaze with lights. On all sides of her were guards brandishing pikes pointed in her direction. She turned towards the man clad in black velvet robes, seated on a large wooden chair, almost a throne. She met his firm penetrating gaze. "I’ve been expecting you," said Governor Alczar.
13112121.title: The Governor's Mansion

choices: The governor comes to visit her
131121212.content:
"Governor Alczar, it's been ages."

"Since the siege of Asgath. You caused us no small amount of trouble there."

"It was a foolish venture as you well knew even then. Think what troubles you'd have now if you'd overextended yourselves that far. You'd already be cut off by the Cardacians in a desert town, dreaming of having so much as the rats you find here."

"Such sentiments are treasonable to the king," said the governor sternly.

"Then you're lucky to have someone else to express them for you, no?" replied Dauphin. Instead of meeting the knowing smile of a sagacious and seasoned warrior, Dauphin saw the governor looking uncomfortable around his subordinates.

His gaze alighted on the warrior immediately to his right. He had a haughty expression and his eyes blazed as he burst out, "My lord, this woman is an enemy of our kingdom. She must be imprisoned immediately!"

"Perhaps first we should hear what her purpose here is, shall we not Kaltar?" replied the governor.

"So that she can deceive us with lies in our time of gravest peril? And perhaps she came not to speak, but to spy and only speaks now being unable to spy any longer."

"Well, Dauphin, what have you to say for yourself?" asked the Governor.

"That Cardac will be here shortly and if you don't wish to have your head displayed on the battlements on the tip of a Cardacian spear, you must prepare and you will need my help --"

"Your help," shouted Kaltar, "is this the same help you provided at Asgath?"

"You should know, Kaltar, that my loyalties lie with peace and truth, and with the same powers that I saved you from your folly at Asgath, I will use to preserve you from Cardac. Their armies will be here within the week," replied Dauphin calmly.

"Within a week!" cried the governor astounded. "Where did you hear this?"

"I did not hear it. I left the Cardacian army 50 leagues from here. That was 3 days ago," replied Dauphin.

"Kaltar, you reported to me that the Cardacians were at least 80 leagues away yesterday," said the governor.

"That is the word of my most trusted scouts and I had this word from them myself. She lies my lord, and must be imprisoned," said Kaltar and, in a low and sinister voice, added, "Who knows what the punishment awaits for those who would shield an enemy in this time of crisis?"

The governor turned to Kaltar, his eyes blazing, but only for a second. Then he fixed his glance on Dauphin again. For a second she thought she glimpsed understanding. But then the governor's features hardened again and he said, "Yes she must be imprisoned. Guards, take her to the prison."
131121212.title: Interview with the Governor

1311212122.content:
Once in the dungeon, Dauphin began to think of an escape. How could the governor trust Kaltar? It would be a matter of hours or days before the attack on the city.

"Why have you come here?" she turned around to see the governor.

"I have come to help you."

"Kaltar is my faithful advisor. Why should I believe what you say?" The governor looked at her with burning intensity.

"Because I have seen the army myself. They are more powerful than ours. They are advancing at a great rate. If you do not trust me, then follow Kaltar's advice. It would be your responsibility if this city falls from your mistake by trusting him. He is a traitor!"

"Traitor! How could you say such a thing!" the governor shouted at Dauphin. "He has been my advisor for many years, and he has not betrayed me before!"

"Well, maybe this time, it is different. He does not want to be discovered. He is waiting for this moment. Once Cardac's army attacks, he will leave you!"

The governor was silent. "So what do you suggest I do?"

"Trust me and help me escape or trust Kaltar and let the city burn."
1311212122.title: The Dungeon

Tamor lifted the hot cup from the table. He finished the contents all in one gulp. Dauphin sipped slowly on the hot drink getting all she could from it.

"Its been a fair while since my last drink," she said as she held the cup blowing into it.

"Ok, shall I show you to your bed?" Tamor said as he stood from the table.

Dauphin followed behind Tamor, he opened a old wooden door, it looked very old, and makes a loud cracking sound as it is pushed open.

Tamor began to speak, "It's not much but it will do for the night."

"This is great, I shall sleep fine in here," Dauphin said.

Tamor lit a candle and placed it in Dauphin's hand.

Tamor slowly closed the door. Dauphin climbed atop the old make shift bed.
131122.title: Any old bed will do

choices: She is allowed to make her case to the council
1311221.content:
Dauphin woke to the sound of voices in the next room. Cautiously, she laid her ear to the door. Tamor may have been a friend some years ago, but who knew where his loyalties lay now? Last night, she had been tired; in the light of the dawn streaming through the window, she realized how foolish she had been to stay without assurances.

She recognized Tamor’s voice. His soft tones seemed to be attempting to calm someone else, though she could make out no words. A deep, gravelly voice broke into Tamor’s words. Angry and harsh, she knew this was the voice that had awakened her.

“Dragon’s bollocks, Tamor!’ At a swift hiss, the voice was lowered by a half tone. “Some girl comes here in the night prattling about an invasion we all know is coming, and even names the time, yet you say she is not a spy? She is here to seek out our defenses, mark me! 'Tis often enough Cardac has done the same or similar. We know how to deal with her kind. The crows will feast before evening!”

“Hold, Cyrnan. We may not kill the girl without first ascertaining whether she is indeed here to spy, or even to help, as Tamor says. Our duty is to question her and determine whether the entire council shall hear her tale. Tamor, did she say what help she brought? I see no army of warriors, or wizards, or aught else with her.”

Again, Tamor’s soft tones came through the door, though the words were lost. Dauphin took a deep breath and opened the door.
1311221.title: Spy or Saviour?

1311222.content:
Dauphin makes her way downstairs. It had been a long time since she and Tamor had seen each other, but comrades in battle remain comrades for life, even if those kinds of lives never last long she thought wryly.

She noticed that there was candle light eminating from the living room. Tamor always did like to burn the candle at both ends.

"Did I wake you?" he asked, looking up and putting down his pen.

"I can't sleep!" he watched her thoughtfully.

"Why change your name? Your old one was... beautiful," Tamor asked. Dauphin smiled.

"People change, Tamor. Why shouldn't their names?" her voice wavered, and was cut of into silence. Tamor looked down. He knew what she was thinking about, who she was thinking about.

"And you've changed a lot, haven't you, Arian?"
1311222.title: Memories

choices: He describes more about his own change
13112221.content:
Tamor looks at her and smiles lightly.

"Yes I suppose I have,' He looks into space past Dauphin and his face turns grim. "Yes I have indeed." He rested his elbows on the table holding his fist in his hand and leaned his head on it. "Five years ago I was also amidst a war and that war, I decided, would be my last." He drew a long deep breath waiting for the right words to come to him. "I killed in that war, we all did, but not just soldiers." Tamor's voice rose with emotion. "Defenseless men and young boys who held their doors shut and pointed pitchforks at us as weapons." Then settled as he regained his composure. "We killed them too. It was when I fund out what the others had done that left the service. The vile acts they had committed. No one leaves the service without dieing in combat. So I tore off my armor and jumped from the tower. I couldn't bear the thought of being among those who kill women and children." Then his face brightened and he leaned back looking up at Dauphin. The dark curls that hung at this shoulders seemed to reflect the radiance of his face. "That was when you saved me from falling off of that tower With you magnificent steed. That was when I realized I had to become a different man. The man I was, Arian, had to die when he fell from that tower. I then could only become someone else." He stood up as she looked on agape at having herd his real story. "So, yes, I changed my life."
13112221.title: Tamor talks about himself.

"Now it's Tamor the wheelwright that lives here, with Arian the soldier just a memory. It's been a good life here, and I can't say that I miss any part of the man that I was."

"But Cardac -"

He cut her off. "Cardac will rise every few years or so, attack and be driven back. It's been that way for as long as I can remember, and the king knows so as well. Your big news isn't likely to hurry his move to a war footing any more than it would persuade me to return to my murderous ways."

"It's different this time, Tamor," Dauphin insisted.

"Really? Has cardac so changed its ways that they'd welcome a deserter back to their ranks? Do they no longer burn and despoil all that crosses their path, hmm?"

"That's not what I meant, and you know it. What's wrong with you, Tamor?"

"I've been doing my level best to forget, Dauphin. And then here you are, running from the coming storm and asking for my help, dragging the past with you. How can I forget when you are here to remind me?"
131122211.title: Cardac

13121.content:
Before he shut the door, Dauphin hurriedly grabbed his arm. "Please wait," she said, almost begging, "You know something. Please tell me."

The man turned around and Dauphin was surprised to see tears in his eyes. Something was definitely wrong. Was Tamor in trouble? "Hurry, come inside," he said shakily. Dauphin stepped in the house and he shut the door.

The man, young though he was, sat down in a huge wicker chair in what seemed the living room of the house. He put his head in his hands and seemed tired beyond his years. Dauphin sat in the chair across from him, which was black oak with a silk cushion. "Now then," she asked patiently, "What has happened?"

Dauphin suddenly felt as if she were being watched. She turned around, and saw a girl of about fifteen gazing at her from the other room. Her eyes were pitch black, and they seemed to pierce Dauphin's very skin and see into her soul. She felt almost vunerable under the girl's sight. Then she smiled, and the weak feeling was gone. "Ith okay Jor, sheth not one ofth them."

Jor, the man, lifted his head at the voice. His sadness was now mingled with relief. "Praise be to Faire. I was so worried," he said. "But now, what are we going to do with her Raine? Can she help us?"

Raine walked, or really, glided over to us. In the light, Dauphin saw her better: she seemed the very essence of light. She wore a white blouse with white breeches, both immaculate. Her boots were soft white leather, as were her gloves. Her long silky hair was white, and on her head she wore a star-shaped diamond, suspended in her hair by a silver chain. But her eyes were black, not one inch of them was white. She was Dungulian, from a country across the Tourk sea.

"Well," she said, with a Dungulian accent, "I think thath she should hath say in thath." Raine sat down on a chair beside me. "What ith your name?"

"Dauphin," I said politely.

"Well then, Thauphin..."
13121.title: Jor and Raine

"Do you want to help us thave Tamor?" said Raine quietly.

I shivered. Her voice was deadly serious. "What has happened? Where is he?"

"We are grateful," said Raine sybillantly. "But we mutht know. In sooth, who are you? How do you know of our cauthe?"

I hesitated a moment, but I felt I could trust them. "I am Dauphin Sanara of Renagin." Their faces revealed they had heard of me. "I am here because I know of the suffering Rabinoth has inflicted upon your people, and I wish to help you free your homeland."

"Dauphin Thanara?" breathed Raine. "The mithtreth of disguithe, who dethieved the great King of Thanara himthelf? If thith is the truth, we shall be most glad of your aid!"

1312111.content:
Even though Dauphin was extremely tired, the thoughts that raged within her brain kept her awake. Raine pointed a twisted finger to the table in the small kitchen of her home, motioning for the two to follow. Dauphin, Raine and her husband took their seats around the dusty table. The chairs slid on the floor with barely any sound at all. On the table sat a big wooden bowl with clear, still, bluish water filled to the brim inside.

“Now.” Raine spoke the silence apart, “Tamor, he stayed in this house for about two weeks, hiding from King Rabinoth’s men. The king had been tracking Tamor down for the longest time. It’s terrible… Tamor, he knew what the King had in store for the land. As you know, he was the last Druid of the lake at Wonradolk. Neither his brother, nor the people would tell the king where Tamor was, so the king’s men burned his village and staked his bother.”

“What did Tamor know?” Dauphin asked.

“We’re not sure. Tamor had kept it from us, though we tried he wouldn’t give up much, said it would be too dangerous for the wrong hands to get a hold of. There is talk around town, about the king’s plot, but I don’t know what to make of it, or believe. Some say that… which is the most believable of all stories… is that the king has conspired, with his councilmen’s help, to resurrect the evil black robed Mage of Concored, who was banished in the war of Nables. Tamor said he was found out through the king’s messenger spy, to have sworn oath to the protection of the land and the king. The king is evil and dangerous. Be protected at all times.” Raine sparked a warning.

“I will.” Dauphin said, looking at the floor. She felt uneasy, even though she promised to save her friend the Druid, she didn’t know if she should get involved. Upon instruction to her room, she set her belongings by the bedside and lay down to sleep.
1312111.title: The Story

13121111.content:
Dauphine woke in the middle of the night, alerted to danger by Raine's voice.

         "What can a poor, humble servant of the Great King Rabintoh do for the city guards?"

         "The City Guard? What are they doing here?" Dauphin quickly, but quietly, got out of bed, pulling on her clothes as she went on her way to press her ear to the door.

         "We have a few questions for your guest."

         "I have no guest."

         "Well, in that case, in the name of King Rabinoth, this house is to be repossessed and the occupants are to be taken into custody under the charges of treason. Men, search the house."

13121111.title: The Royal Guards

1312112.content:
I decided to go to bed now and I would start helping Tamor tomorrow.

Suddenly someone pulled my blanket away. "Hey, Raine! Let me sleep just ten more minutes," I said dozy, trying to continue sleeping. Suddenly someone shouted "Stand up!" and I realized, that this wasn't Raine's voice. So I opened my yes - and got a shock. There were three soldiers standing next to my bed.

"You've got ten minutes to dress," said the tallest of them, before starting to count. I jumped out of my bed, faster than I ever did before. I found it embarrassing to dress in front of them, but at least I managed to do it within eight seconds.

When I was finished, I saw that the soldiers were holding a rope in their hands. "You're not going to enchain me?" I asked them a bit scared. They grinned and one of them said, "Sure we will. King Rabinoth wants to see you alive."
1312112.title: Unpleasant Awaking

Raine burns Dauphin with the branding iron
131212.content:
Dauphin stared in shock and horror. For a moment she seemed frozen in fear for her friend. What in the name of Light had these people done to him? The moment passed quickly though. With her usual sharpness of mind, she said conversationally, "Of course. Why do you think I'm here?"

Raine nodded in satisfaction. "Good. I will tell you briefly of where we thtand. Tamor ith hiding in an empty houthe on the outthkirth of town. Tomorrow, we and the retht of our group will thurround the houthe and corner him tho he cannot ethcape ath he did before. Then, finally, we thhall have him." A look of sheer evil croththed . . excuse me, CROSSED her face. "I look forward to that day when I thhall make him thcream like a thqualling infant!"

Dauphin winced, as much at the appalling idiom as at the sentiments it expressed. She said, "I'm tired now - it's been a long day. Do you have any place for me to sleep?"

"Of course," said the old man in a creaky voice. "Come right along."

She followed him to a small bedchamber under the eaves. Thanking him, she did not even bother to undress. She had not lied; exhaustion was gibbering about the edges of her conciousness. Though she was in the house of some very strange enemies who obviously intended a dreadful fate for her friend, her eyes closed and it was more than she could do to open them again.

She woke suddenly and horribly. Reaching up to rub her eyes, she realized what had awakened her and froze still as stone.

Raine stood over her, holding a... a poker? No, with an icy jolt of fear, Dauphin recognized it for what it was: a branding iron. A red-hot branding iron. The end formed a strange symbol that she knew well. It was the sign of Cardac.

"I knew from the thtart you were none of our kind," hissed Raine. "How fitting, then, to mark you with thith!"

"Why?" whispered Dauphin. "What does it do?"

Raine's voice dropped to a whisper. "The thign of Baneg, King of Cardac and mighty sorcerer, ith no mere thign! Thith mark, once it touches your flethh, will make you one of uth forever!"
131212.title: Midnight Attack

choices: Her faelan smashes in through the window
1312122.content:
Dauphin's hesitation in attacking one so young proved to be her undoing. Raine wasted no time in driving the branding iron into Dauphin's arm, where the stench of burnt meat roared into the air alongside the woman's screams and the child's dribbling joy.

The brand was held in place for several long seconds, but Dauphin felt the pain lessening the more contact she had with it. "Oh no," she thought to herself, "I'm becoming one of them."

She surged to her feet, knocking the brand aside with her other arm before slouching from a lack of strength. Raine hissed as she backed away crabwise, but Dauphin paid her no mind. She didn't have much time if she was to cure herself of Carnac's infection...
1312122.title: Just a Child

13121222.content:
Raine heard a commotion upstairs.
She heard the old man groan and a thump against the floor.

Suddenly, Tamor ran downstairs and saw the mark on Dauphins arm.
"You witch...why did you do this?"
She spat curses at him and backed away.

He ran to Dauphins side.
"Let me help you..."
He pulled a vial of green liquid from his pocket.

" It will repel the curse that coarses through your body.
I only have one..so hurry!"
Dauphin grabs the vial and drinks.

Raine curses under her breath.
Her masters would not be happy.......
Of course..if there was only one...

She smiled.
Sneaking behind Tamor, she rushed.
No matter who she hit...someone would get branded.
13121222.title: Tamor bursts into the room

13122.content:
Dauphin knew she was going to get no more information off the person tonight. She would continue to investigate Tamor's disappearance in the morning though, through other sources, no one would sway her from discovering what had happened to her friend.

In the dark lonely city Tamor had been the only one she had known, and now rest was becoming more and more necessary. The problem was that of the various inns many might have infiltrators who might recognise her. She did not know if she would be safe for long in any of them.
13122.title: No refuge

choices: Beer swills, shouts and bumps in the night
131221.content:
Dauphin decided that she was going to have to take her chances and find an inn to stay in that night, to sleep rough would be suicidal at this time of year, she could already feel that it was going to be a particularly cold night.

"Come on Capo, lets find somewhere warm to eat and sleep that's hopefully friendly," though this last bit she said more to herself. Her faelan 'Capo' had been her rock since she has left Kappatilus, she had never had to rely on another living creature as much as she had in those last few weeks.

She looked back the way she had come, there was an inn she had passed which had been full of people and which, she noted, had looked particularly rowdy, this was good because she doubted that in a crowd she would be recognised by any of Xouter's spies, but she did not know who to trust any more anyway.

She knew of an inn on the other side of town that Tamor had frequented, it was quiet and she remembered that she had thought the innkeeper a little odd when she had last been there. "Oh by the balls of Crueton, he could be dead for all I know," she sighed as she kicked a rock across the road. She remembered the worried expression of the new tennants within Tamor's house, thinking, "I have to find him."
131221.title: A place to stay inn

choices: They are disturbed in the night
131222.content:
"I'm sorry girl," she said gently to her faelan. "It is to be another night under the stars for us. But one day soon you will have a fine stables again and all the food you can eat, I promise."

Her faelan snorted, a reassuring sound. Tavara, the faelan, was used to the wild: they had been travelling for many long weeks now and inns had been scarce and full of danger. Unfortunately within the walls of a city there was little shelter of trees and Dauphin and Tavara had to settle for the cold comfort of a lonely alley, far off the main road to the city. It was obscure enough to attract little attention from guard patrols or other wanderers. Nonetheless Dauphin knew she would be happier when it was morning once more.
131222.title: The alley

132.content:
The city was vast, but at least under the cover of darkness few people were around outside. Dauphin decided to try and get her bearings and learn what she could about this new place.

The city spread out with the castle in the centre. Where she was now appeared to be a living quarter, and people were in short supply on the streets after dark here. However, there were lights shining further to the east and the murmur sounds of many people talking quite a distance away. Something was evidently going on over there, although what exactly could not be determined.
132.title: Directions

choices: Go check out that other faelan
Get your palm read by one of those gypsies
1321.content:
Dauphin meandered eastward, observing the strange noises and rumblings coming from that direction. The grass and well trimmed shrubbery around her was an excellent example of how a main city of a powerful country should look.

The sounds grew louder and as Dauphin rounded a corner the bright colors of the festival hit her eyes. Bright splashes of magic lightened red, orange, and gold cloth waved gently in the breeze, untouched by the rain. People mingled here and there, and an auctioneer seemed to be bargaining off a faelan similar to the one walking next to Dauphin.
1321.title: Colors!!! Aah!

choices: Leave - this place is dangerous for travellers alone
13211.content:
Dauphin looked at the other creature. It appeared to be genuine which was a suprise, as faelan's were so rare in captivity. Then again with the war threatening, people were selling a lot of items of value as hard cash had much more appeal.

"Give me the faelan."

Dauphin turned to the voice. She saw the knife glinting in the man's hand, but even before she had time to think her arm had swung out suprisingly the man with its suddeness. The knife was on the floor before he had even had time to blink.

"If you want one, try the auction," she suggested.

The man looked to be considering attacking again, but Dauphin's supreme confidence was as off putting as the obvious skill with which she had removed the knife. He turned on his heel and swiftly moved away.
13211.title: The fair

choices: Say yes, you need a stable
132111.content:
Dauphin looked at the other faelan. It was clearly unhappy and shaking badly. To get it to appear before the crowd she had a feeling it must have been mistreated by the state it was now in.

The auction was nearing a close.

"Any more bids?"

"6,000 ira," the crowd heard.

The auctioneer turned his head.

"6,000 ira from the lady at the back. Going, going, gone! Sold to the lady at the back."

Dauphin moved her way forward. Bidding on the faelan had been a rash decision, as she had nowhere to live and no stables and now two faelans to support! But she handed over the money with confidence and looked over her new faelan. It was tied in several places - obviously the auctioneer had not trusted it not to break free.

Dauphin walked closer and held out her hand to touch its fine silver mane, keeping as far from its jagged teeth as she could manage. Not that such an act was difficult the way its head was captured.

"It's okay. Come with me," she told the creature and slowly undid the head restraint. Its body was still captured, but if it wanted to attack her it was now capable of doing so. Dauphin was intelligent enough to know, however, that its attention was elsewhere on her faelan Aeredne. Aeredne was female and if she was not mistaken this faelan was definitely male and although it might not follow her anywhere it would happily follow Aeredne!

She undid the back restraints also, so the faelan was entirely free and guiding it with her hand alone walked through the crowd with Aeredne at her other side. It was an amazing sight to the locals, who had seen the faelan's earlier viciousness - that this small girl had it seemingly under her power. Dauphin hid an inner chuckle that they did not realise it was not her but Aeredne that had the faelan under her spell!

"Madam, have you anywhere to stable those creatures?"

Dauphin turned to face a well dressed man. He had been the bidder she had beaten at the auction. She needed stables desperately, at least for the night, but this man could be attempting to steal the animal soon after she had bought it.
132111.title: And then there were three

1321111.content:
"Not now. But I will do soon enough," Dauphin replied curtly. It was not a no, but it displayed the right lack of enthusiasm.
