"May I be as bold as to offer assistance?" the man said, offering a strong but well manicured hand to Dauphin. She could feel the iron behind his grip as she shook it. "There are far too many unscrupulous stable owners in this city. Besides which, mine is the only one, besides the royal stables, to comfortably accomodate faeleans. The others don't have the flying height you see."

Dauphin knew that wherever she went there would be problems with her faelans. Sometimes it was better the devil you know than the one you don't. "How much?" she asked.

The man's reply made her wince, but at least sounded legitimate. A faker would offer a lower price to entice her to danger. It was only for one night after all, and she could sleep in the stables to ensure her steeds' safety.

"Lead on," she answered.
1321111.title: A place to stay

13211112.content:
As her guide tumbled to the ground with a familiar knife-hilt jutting from his chest, Dauphin realised that some people in the city didn't give up so easily.

"I asked you nice, last time," hissed a voice in the darkness. The faelans instinctively turned their heads in the direction they sensed it coming from, and Dauphin looked that way as well.

It was a mistake. The man had friends, one of whom leapt from behind her to bear her to the ground. The faelans panicked, and then there was shouting.

"Get them under control! Don't let them get away!"

The man atop of her, his weight and stench overpowering, spat in her ear as he growled. "Keep still, and I won't have to cut you. Got any more of that money you were being so free with earlier?"

Dauphin read his intent in an instant. While his comrades were subduing the faelans, he was going to get as much for himself as possible. If asked, he could always say that her pockets were empty....

She could use that against him. He was holding her so tight that he'd have to move to allow her to reach her money pouch. In that time she could strike out, try to free herself.

There was the risk of him 'cutting' her, though. Maybe she should play it safe for now, and look for an opportunity later....
13211112.title: Bushwhacked

1321112.content:
"Fine, have it your own way," the man mumbled, moving back into the crowd.

Suddenly, the jovial party atmosphere of the festival was shattered by an ear-splitting boom. People began running hither and thither in panic as fireballs began raining from the sky, exploding on the ground, buildings and crowds indiscriminately. Dauphin watched as one landed directly on the podium where the auctioneer had been standing, incinerating the man and spraying flame onto those nearby.

It seemed that Cardac had begun his assault on the city.

She couldn't stay out in the open, inviting death at any moment from one of these seemingly random trebuchet shots. But there was really nowhere to hide, and she was penned in by the mass of panicking townsfolk stampeding away from the attack.

The only problem was, the attack was coming from all around. Rocks were now joining the flaming ordnance, and the devastation was terrible to behold. Dauphin closed her eyes, trying to block out the images of her own home destroyed in just such a manner.

A whinney, and she opened her eyes again. The newly bought faelan was clearly startled by the crowds, raising up onto its hind legs and kicking out at nearby runners. A short man in a monk's robe was caught a blow on the head, and toppled backwards to be trampled underfoot in the charge.

Dauphin tried to find the words to calm the faelan, but the truth was that she was far from calm herself. She had been foolish to believe that she could change anything, that she could save this city when she had failed to save her own home and family. Now she was to die, with nothing to show for her efforts.

The tears were just starting to form when the bombardment abruptly stopped. Dauphin had seen enough of Carnac warfare to know what that signified. The beating of wings only confirmed what she already knew to be true, and she looked skyward with trembling, tearing eyes.

The Cardac Flying Cavalry were attacking, borne on steeds of scale and claw, and wielding weapons of ancient deathdealing. All hope was now gone for the city.
1321112.title: The Siege Begins

choices: "We should flee. We have no chance of victory."
13211122.content:
Hundreds of death cries came from the sky, drowning out the din created by the panicking townspeople. Dauphin stared in awe at the sky-borne opposition: they wielded gigantic metallic spears and massive blades that both glowed blood-red in the sunrise. It was difficult to tell whether these were soldiers or the very same balls of flame that set the city ablaze.

Before Dauphin could make any sense of what was happening, a familiar, albeit unwelcome, face was seen dashing toward her on a body carried by a pair of swift legs. It was the bidder from the faelan auction.

"Those faelans of yours could be our only chance for survival," the bidder panted breathlessly. "Let me lead the way on that male. You follow behind closely and carefully with your female."

As ridiculous as this sounded to Dauphin, her choices were limited to a rock and a hard place. She reluctantly nodded her head in agreement, and quickly mounted her beautiful silvery-white faelan. The Unexpected Ally took to the sky after a brief dash, with Dauphin following in quick succession. The cool morning air whipped against her face as she gained speed, sending her long hair trailing behind her.

Dauphin heard a horrifying screech from above, and quickly turned her watery eyes toward the source of the sound. One of the heavily armored Cavalry units was swooping down for an attack, blood-red sword in hand, with Dauphin as the unfortunate target. Dauphin quickly attempted to evade the death strike, but the rider was dismounted from the faelan by an attack from the Ally. The heavily armored victim fell to hit the stone ground with a dull metallic thud, barely missing a frail old woman shrieking for her life.

The Ally quickly switched directions toward the Northwest, in the direction of the castle. He was picking up speed, and Dauphin followed suit. The west side of the massive and grand castle was in sight, and in the dim orange light of the gradually rising sun shone at least a hundred white faelans rising to meet the opposition. The castle was now mounting a counterattack.

The Ally quickly dove towards the area where the town's Flying Cavalry had gracefully risen to the challenge. Dauphin noticed an opening in the side of the castle, and apparently so had the Ally. Dauphin followed the Ally into a dimly lit passageway at the foot of the castle, and landed only feet away from him.

The Ally spoke quickly. "My name is Allan, and I can assure you that aiding you and this beautiful city is my top priority. I am a mercenary by profession, and I assume that you have some skill with weaponry also." Dauphin nodded in agreement as Allan continued speaking. "This castle must contain weapons we can use. I suggest we procure these weapons and aid the town in it's counterattack."

Dauphin was reluctant. She felt tears well up as she forced her eyes shut. It was going to be difficult facing the army that single handedly murdered her whole family and village. Could she face the trials ahead and avenge those that had fallen? She lifted her head and opened her mouth to reply...
13211122.title: An Unexpected Ally

choices: ...he laughed.  He's leading her away from the fight to attack her
...he explained.  The armoury is protected by glamours
132111221.content:
"Yes, Allan the Ally, I will aid this city. Let it not be said that I was to flee at a time of crisis and impending defeat."

"Yeah, desperate last stands are so terribly romantic, aren't they?"

Dauphin couldn't be sure, but for a moment she'd thought that Allan had winked at her before he strode off down the corridor. No, it must have been her imagination....

Allan led the way through deserted hallways and galleries, in a winding course that went up and down stairs in a manner than Dauphin could attribute to no logical pattern. And when she brought this observation to Allan's attention...
132111221.title: "I will rise to the challenge!" (of my rival?)

13212.content:
Dauphin walked towards one of the tents and, leaving her faelan outside, entered.

"Want to know your future, dearie?" the old lady seated asked.

Dauphin held out her palm. In it was a gold coin, of far greater value than would be expected for a fortune telling. Dauphin was not seeking her future but information.

"I'm looking for someone," she replied.

"The one you seek is far from here still. But she is coming," the gypsy replied.

"I did not tell you who."

"No, but I can tell. It's what I do. And now your palm please," the old gypsy insisted.

"My future is of little concern to me. It is hers that matters," Dauphin replied, but at the old gypsy's persistence Dauphin held out her hand.

"You have led a troubled life so far, and it will continue to be so for some time. But your life line is strong - you will stand against whatever obstacles life throws at you. But the path will not be an easy one," the old gypsy said.
13212.title: The future

choices: Leave to try and find an inn
132121.content:
The old lady had clearly told all she was going to tell, so Dauphin left. She still knew nothing more of Alene, other than she had was not here for now.

The busy crowds provided anonimity enough for her for now, but tiredness was setting in. She glanced over at one of the brightly covered food stands - the prospect of a meal first was appealing though...
132121.title: Tiredness

choices: Say again that it's not for sale
Sell the faelan as you need the money
1321211.content:
The array of food was impressive. Many of these people were likely to be refugees from foreign lands, so for small market stalls there was a selection spanning several lands. Dauphin chose a Saxlanian dish, of mixed berries and herbs with wild rice and stood to one side away from the majority of the crowds whilst eating.

The fair was intoxicating, contageous in its light and warmth, but Dauphin knew it would not offer sanctuary for long. She gently stroked her faelan and made sure it was well watered from a nearby trough.

"How much do you want for the beast?"

Dauphin turned and saw a small, withered old man.

"It's not for sale I'm afraid."

"1,000 carus?" the old man offered.
1321211.title: Fed and watered

choices: Dauphin wakes to find the faelan has been stolen
She wakes up as a prisoner
13212111.content:
"No, I'm sorry," said Dauphin firmly. "I'm not selling him." She turned and walked away.

It was very late at night and she was exhausted. Intending to leave the fair, she made her way through the revelers and away from the light and noise. But where to now? She had little money.

Dauphin decided to look for an inn. Since fine hospitality was not within her price range, she left the main street area where she had previously been and began to search the dark, narrow streets for an inn.

As she rounded a corner she knew something was wrong. Her finely-tuned senses screamed an alarm as she spun around, but she was too late to dodge the blow that crashed onto her head from behind. She pitched forward into darkness.
13212111.title: Attack in the Night

choices: Dauphin, angry and shaken, leave the gypsy's tent.
Dauphin demands an explanation from the old crone.
132122.content: The old crone's hands suddenly tightened to an iron like grip on Dauphin's hand. She started chanting ancient words. As the chanting raised in volume Dauphin started feelimg dizzy. Slowly, so slowly, she sank into unconsciousness. While sinking into visions the old crone was sending, Dauphin began to dream. Or was she not dreaming??!! She could smell fresh blood and death. All around her she could hear the deafening sounds of war. She could sense all of the agony, fear, greed and hate that seeped out of the thousands of warriors that surrounded her. And, as quickly as the old crone took Dauphin under, she woke her up.
132122.title: Gypsy's visions

choices: Dauphin asks what she must do for this
Dauphin decides that it isn't worth it to know about the vision and leaves.
1321222.content:
The old crone protested, but finally bent to Dauphin's will. "It is a dark future, is it not?" she said. "This is what is to come if you do not triumph in your task."

Dauphin looked around and after a moment's thought she asked, "What is this task?"

The old woman shook her head. "If I tell you, your life will be changed forever."
1321222.title: The Vision

1322.content:
As Dauphin walked towards the castle, with lights shown in the windows, she spotted a line of men, marching towards the castle as well. As they passed under the lamp post, Dauphin could see the listas. Although Dauphin had grown up in a farmlike area, she knew that listas were the most expensive and powerful kinds of weapons in the whole world.

Dauphin kept watching the line of men and she noticed a symbol on their outfits. It was the symbol of the royal crown that the king of Cardac prized so much.

Dauphin...
1322.title: Line of Men

choices: They travel away from the castle
13221.content:
Quietly she placed one foot in front of the other. Her heart pounded in her chest, her breath came in short gasps. She felt as though they must hear her, her heart like a gong pounded in her ears.

Still she followed.
13221.title: After them

132211.content:
The men did not appear to be travelling towards the castle, so an outright attack was unlikely. No, this was something far more sinister and subversive....

Dauphin could hear the murmur of lowered voices, but not clearly enough to pick out any of the words. She watched as the men broke into two groups, one heading towards the West, the other the East.
132211.title: Break away

1322111.content:
One of the men who stood to be the leader of the group noticed Dauphin. He halted his men, exclaimed, "A spy you are! Take her!" Two of the fierce bulky men nabbed her, but Dauphin gave no resistance.

"Wait!" Dauphin explained. "I'm no spy. I'm just here to pass away the night."

"Then who are you?" asked their leader.

"I'm Dauphin from Malta, the land besieged by plague. I have fled from the course of the gods. I don't mean any harm as you can see. And I'm not a spy," she pleaded as she released herself from the hold of the two men.

The men conferred upon themselves on what to do with Dauphin. Should they slaughter her or feed her to the dragons? Or should they just make her a slave and take her faelan?

"All right," the leader approached her. "You are free to go, in exchange for... your Lovely."

"You can't take Lovely, my faelan... you can't even ride her," Dauphin refused to trade her faelan. She was her only wealth, had considered her family. Both of them were lucky to be spared by the wrath of the gods. Something, some luck had accompanied them in their fleeing together.

One of the burly men grabbed her. "Your freedom or your Lovely?"

With this, the faelan moved its wings, violently producing some thunderous winds. Daphin took this opportunity, jumped onto its back, and rode through the winds like they used to.

The wind was free, and they were free, but not forever. Daphin's Lovely couldn't fly for long. Her flying strength had waned considerably because of hunger and thirst. It was just so lucky, they were able to escape from the plague. They were able to hide in a portion of the castle. The men were there looking for them.
1322111.title: Adventures in the City

choices: struggle to get out of the stranger's grip
1322112.content:
Dauphin proceeded east, making sure that there were always several metres between herself and the guards so as not to alert them that she was there, stopping only to tell her faelan to stay where it was until she got back. Although she did not seem like the type, Dauphin was afraid of lightning and in the past few minutes it had continually pierced the black sky. She had felt compelled to shout out to the soldiers for companionship but she knew that she couldn't if she wanted to find out where they were going.

Dauphin was concentrating on where the soldiers were going so much that she didn't hear the person sneak up behind her until it was too late. Dauphin was too shocked to respond instantly, so she cleared her mind and decided to...
1322112.title: Unknown ally

choices: Or do you ask to know the REAL reason?  It's obvious that he's lying!
13221122.content:
Dauphin went limp. Holding a veiled lantern close to the girl, Dauphin heard her captor mumble, "Huh! It's only a girl."

As the man's grip relaxed, Dauphin struck out, hitting her assailant in the stomach. With a loud "Ooof!" the man went down.

As Dauphin spun around to run off, the man grabbed at her legs and sprang up. Both of them had their swords out now, menacingly facing each other.

"Who are you?" demanded Dauphin.

After a long stare-down, the man replied, "My name is Shiv Kinrak, girl. Who are you?"

"I am called Dauphin. What were you doing?"

Uneasily, Shiv answered, "Oh, I saw the lights out here and came to see what it was."
13221122.title: Shiv Kinrak

choices: Unlock the door and enter the castle
Take the key and go find shelter, returning tomorrow night
132212.content:
The band stopped suddenly. Dauphin tensed and waited. The band started up again, marching into the castle. The two guards at the doors close and lock them.

Dauphin walked up to the guards. "Can I go in?" she said calmly.

"I'm sorry miss, only those wearing the royal symbol may enter," the left guard said.

Dauphin took out her sword and killed both guards. She took the key from one of them.
132212.title: The Guards

1322121.content:
Dauphin had thought it a simple task to enter the keep. It turned out to be a lot harder than she could ever have possibly imagined.

With war brewing, the guard within had been trebled in size, and she was apprehended within minutes of her unlocking the door.

She would have been let off with a sound thrashing and sent on her way, but for her grievous crime of double murder.

That was how she found herself in the dark cell where she now weeps, waiting for the hooded man to drag her off to her execution...
1322121.title: Justice

choices: Finish the child and make a run for the exit
Take the child to your faelan
13221212.content:
Sitting in the damp cold cell for over a week, she was useless. A broken tool thrown aside and discarded. Not even guards came down to these dark distant cells. Once a day a young servant would come down and give the prisoners some musty water and a stiff piece of bread. The food was barely edible, and the bread would serve better as a hammer.

"Hey!" she whispered to the young boy, "Get me out of here!"

The boy, having much experience with prisoners, knew better than to talk to them... the punishment was lashings.

"I need to get out of here!" So many things needed seeing too. "At least tell me if they're taking care of my faelan!"

"You own the faelan!?" The boy seemed infatuated with tame creatures, "I've always wanted one."

Seeing a chance of talking her way out of this, she put on a sweet voice. "They are wonderful. I love mine, I'd let you ride it if I was out of here, but I can't do anything in here."

"I can't let you out."

"Do you know what the castle does to extra livestock?"

"No."

"Hope you like faelan drumsticks, kid."

His eyes opened wide and watered, what a softie. He pulled the keys out of his pocket and opened the lock.
13221212.title: Soft-hearted Servant

choices: Bring the kid with you. He could prove to be a valuable investment!
Ditch the kid. Or better yet, kill him. I doubt it makes a difference.
132212122.content:
Dauphin looked for other guards as she stepped outside the cell. Those foolish guards had neglected to search her for her sword. Now, all she had to do was one quick slash and she could...

Wait, that's not a good idea. Dauphin knew she could hold her own against simple jailers, but if she accidentally ran into the army, she'd be done for. She had better use the kid to get out of here. "Do you know any secret passages we could use to get out of here?"

The boy shook in fear. "No, I don't think..."

Dauphin grabbed him by the collar and said more tensely, "Listen to me. If even one guard catches us out here, we're both toast. You can kiss the faelan ride goodbye, then."

"Wait!" Dauphin shushed the boy. She hoped no one had heard him, it echoed. "There's an entrance to the sewers down here. They go all across the town."

Dauphin released him. "Fine, let's try the sewers." The two of them quietly trotted down a labyrinth of corridors until they got to a trapdoor.

"This is it. The sewers."

Great. The child has served its purpose. Dauphin grabbed her sword, but she had second thoughts... she did say she'd give him a ride. Dauphin mentally shook her head. What was she thinking? Bringing this kid along would be like dragging dead weight! But, he could know some valuable information which could prove vital in her quest! Either way, she should move quickly. She thought she heard a couple guards coming!
132212122.title: A Stealthy Escape

choices: "I don't think I want to go any more…"
"Follow me, I'm not going to stand and let people die."
1322121221.content:
Okay, if I leave a dead body for the guards to find them they'll be sure to send out armed patrols into the sewers… Fine he can stay for now. Dauphin quickly dragged the young child forwards, ignoring his quiet protests and moved quickly throughout the disgusting mess.

"Hey wait, does this go to the castle?" Dauphin asked. Them boy mumbled something quietly and turned away. Dauphin stopped and turned, looking the boy straight in they eyes. "Please, this is very important, you have a family here don't you?" She asked. He nodded and she said, "If I don't get to tell the king this news then everyone here could die so please, just tell me."

He stared back with a sad look and said
1322121221.title: Fine, you can stay

13222.content:
This is not the place for me, Dauphin thought. She left for some shelter, outside of the dark and unmerciful castle.

Into the forest she went, to find a good place to stay. As she walked farther and farther into the forest, the rain grew harder. The rain could not make her cold, for she was wearing her enchanted coat from the Northland, but she was worried about her companion.

A voice sounded behind her. "Are you lost?" it asked. She turned around to see a woman who was young like herself.

"In a way," the traveler said, not seeming desperate.

"Well, come with me. I have a home and a stable for your... pegasus," she said, eyeing the animal.
13222.title: Into the forest

132221.content:
The soft winds blew past in the night and Dauphin knew she must look for some soft hay, for her legs could carry her no more that night.

As dawn was breaking she saw a dew drop that offerd her the first taste of her new home life. The hay was now damp and her bones somewhat stiff: it was time to go look upon this beautiful gift. A home she had yet to know and the wonders that had yet to be known.
132221.title: Sleep softly upon this night

choices: The man challenges her to a fight
The man would not fight a woman, but Dauphin gets to stay
133.content:
Dauphin could see a tavern just down one of the streets. Here she would at least be able to find refreshment, and maybe some additional information about her new home.

Murmuring a few brief words of reassurance to Sarian, her faelan, Dauphin left the creature outside near a trough of water. There was no point in securing the the faelan, as they were far too independently minded to be bound, and besides few thieves would be able to match one in strength and intelligence. She entered the tavern alone.

Adjusting her eyes to the light, after the darkness outside, Dauphin could see the tavern was half empty. The occupants were mostly male, and in uniform, obviously guards who had recently come off duty.

"What are you doing in here?"

Dauphin turned to look at the speaker. It was a large man, obviously highly inebriated.

"I'm looking for food," she replied.

"You're a woman. No women in here!"

A man behind the bar responded nervously, "Now there's no rules that say that..."

"There's my rules. Now get out," the man cut in.

"Make me."
133.title: A hostile reception

choices: The man decides to fight anyway
1331.content:
"Make me? This isn't a tea party girl. Get out of here before you get hurt... or worse."

To his surprise Dauphin stood her ground and gave the burly man a menacing look.

"I will not move for anyone, man or beast, for I can not tell which one you may be," she said, then taking a seat at the bar and speaking to the bartender.

"Please kind sir, I have been travelling since the last moon was full, I need a drink and someone to water my faelen. I will pay you a handsome sum."

The burly man walked over to where she was seated.

"I told you girl, you are not allowed here, leave now or we may get to see you cry."

Undaunted by his words, she turned toward him and said, "I am the high priestess of the lord, Varoon. Do you wish to speak to me with such malice or shall I have your tongue fed to my pet?"
1331.title: The stand

13311.content:
The man's arm muscle flexed, but he nonetheless stepped away. Another man cleared his throat to stifle a laugh.

"I've warned you girl. You mess up and you're toast. I can't hold myself responsible if something should happen."

"Ah, but I will hold you responsible if something happens." Dauphin turned away from the portly figure in front of her and spoke to the bartender again. "I really need something to eat and drink. And water for my ride."

"Yes, ma'am." The bartender turned to his work. The burly man sat in the corner and glared at Dauphin. She watched as his face turned from dislike to loathing.

"Hello. I have heard you are a priestess of Varoon. I am of the neighboring county. I am Sir Eltoon of Drashmire." The tall sandy haired man extended his hand.
13311.title: Sir Eltoon

choices: Eltoon has been sent to extend an invitation
133111.content:
"Good for you," Dauphin replied. "Now that I've got s drink, I was hoping to drop all of that high-falutin' 'since last the moon was full' talk. If you're willing to do the same, join me by the fire; else, you can go talk to muscles at the bar."

Eltoon clearly shuddered at the casual dismissal of formal introductions, but soon smoothed his features clear of emotion, nodding his head once and retracting his proferred hand to pick up his glass.

The two proceeded to the threadbare chairs that had been set aside for guests of importance near the inn's hearth; the scum loitering around with their dirty tanakards of ale weren't allowed near for fear of ruining the heirlooms, but clearly two nobles were trusted well enough by the owner.

For Dauphin, it was quite the relaxing experience to sink into the cushions following her long ride.

"I'm just going to relax here for a while," she said. "I warn you that I may close my eyes, and maybe even smile in comfort, but I assure you that it has nothing whatsoever to do with you and that I am paying full attention to your words. So tell me: why do you want to talk to me, Eltoon of Drashmire?"
133111.title: Talk to Sir Eltoon

1331111.content:
Eltoon leaned in close and whispered.
"Our lord is troubled.
Many people in our vicinity have been murdered.
Their bodies after death glow something terrible.

He suspects a priestess or a sorceress is doing it.
When he heard you were close by...he sent me to investigate."
Dauphin opened her eyes and looked at the man.

"Am i to understand that i am being charged with these crimes?"
He shook his head.
"Our lord only wants answers.
He is suspicious of all female spellcasters and priestesses...like yourself."

Dauphin leans back and relaxes again.
"Also, he wants me to tell you...
If you refuse to cooperate, he will take that as a sign of guilt...and retaliate accordingly.
So please..just tell me what i want to know."

Dauphin leans in close.
"My business here is none of his..or your...concern.
Tell him I am a priestess....i am here on official business...and that i am not guilty.
If he retaliates...he will regret doing so.
Now leave me be...Sir Eltoon of Drashmere."
1331111.title: A storm is coming

choices: Find a friendly place to stay
133112.content:
Dauphin stifled a curse. She was, in reality, no more a priestess of the neutral Lord Varoon than her faelan was.

The man was still waiting, regarding her with a perplexed expression.

"Forgive me, Sir Eltoon," she said wearily, "but I am not in a fit state to entertain. If you don't mind, I would like to be left alone for I have traveled long and hard to get here."

"Of course, my lady," murmured Eltoon, "Perhaps we will speak more when you are rested?"

Dauphin made a noncommital noise and gratefully accepted the steaming plate of food set down before her as Sir Eltoon sketched a bow and sat down in a corner table.

Unsuccessfully, she tried not to wolf the delicious food down but her stomach had complained of hunger for far too long. The food was gone within minutes. Fearing that she had made a spectacle of herself long enough, Dauphin left a coin on the table and slid out into the darkening night.
133112.title: Errr...

1331121.content: Street after street, she walked into the ever-darkening sky, in quest of a place to stay. She didn't want a palace, just a place to put her sleepy head on until the sun shone on her rugged face. She reached a wooded area but was hesitant to enter. Spotting a light, she went in to find a beautiful cottage home. Her face lit up as she heard footsteps following her knock. An old man stood and softly asked her what she needed. " A place to stay the night, sir... if you please."
1331121.title: The cottage house

choices: Keep quiet and accept his offer
1331122.content:
"My lady, wait," Sir Eltoon called after Dauphin. "Lord Varoon would never forgive me if I were to let you travel on your own in the darkness."

"Lord Varoon knows I am more than capable of looking after myself," Dauphin replied. Why could he not get the hint and leave her alone?

"Nonetheless it is a basic courtesy that would be expected," Eltoon insisted. "May I ask where you are headed?"

"To find an inn for the night."

"An inn! They are all booked out. Too many refugees in the city. But I have lodgings here, where you may stay if you wish. They are very spacious, plenty of room for guests."
1331122.title: A place for the night

choices: Slap him for fooling you.  Creep!
13311221.content:
"Good sir, I must confess to you. I am no priestess of Lord Varoon's. Will you still offer me your hospitality, knowing this?"

Sir Eltoon smiled. "In truth, my lady, I did already know this. For I am the assistant high priest to Lord Varoon."

Shock registered on Dauphin's face. "Then we both lied?" she exclaimed.

A momentary frown passed over Sir Eltoon's visage. "No, my lady. My word is my life. I would never lie. You see, my father was a lord of Drashmire, but my mother was their high priestess. I, as the only child, have inherited the ranks and duties of both. I am, so to speak, two people in one. I ask you again, will you come with me?"
13311221.title: Two sides to everything

13312.content:
With those words, the bartender raged out at Dauphin and made a blow at her. But she quickly moved, and he fell into the wall. He had several red marks from the painful bruises he had made for himself, and left the bar in shame. Never to return.

Dauphin left, finding the bar amok with thoughts of protection she sensed from the occupants. Most involved her hanging. She got her ride, and made her way to the castle.
13312.title: Bar fight

choices: Dauphin and Makarin fight them together
1332.content:
The man had his hand on his sword and for a second Dauphin had to mentally prepare herself for a fight. But one of the other men at the bar intervened.

"Would you really fight a woman? Hardly very gentleman like is it?"

"What are you calling me?" the first man replied.

"I'm just saying why pick on a defenceless girl. It'd hardly be fair to send her out into the night alone, would it?" the other man responded.

"Okay, you can stay for now," the man said looking at Dauphin once again. "However you - outside," he said to the other man, withdrawing his sword.

Dauphin watched as both men moved towards the door. The second man had got into a fight by trying to protect her, so surely she had to do something to help.

"Don't follow them girl. Makarin knows what he's doing," the barman advised.

Dauphin threw caution to the winds and followed outside to where the fight was about to begin.

"Go back inside. I can handle this," the man she now knew as Makarin told her.

"Can you handle them as well?" Dauphin asked, as another five men came out of the street to join the original agressor.
1332.title: A defenceless girl

13321.content:
Dauphin stood aside to allow whatever macho pride Makarin had to remain undented for a while at least. But she would be ready for if and when he was forced to admit he needed her help after all.

The men were an unruly mob, rather than trained agents with a purpose and were easily seen off by Makarin's skill with a sword.

"Drink?" Makarin asked Dauphin.
13321.title: Another fight

133212.content:
Dauphin gave Makarin a lopsided smile. "I suppose that since you were defending my honor, the least I can do is let you buy me a drink."

As Dauphin followed Makarin back into the pub, little did she know that Makarin was a spy for...
133212.title: Double Agent?

13322.content:
"Of course," Makarin replied.

"Well let me draw my sword just in case," replied Dauphin, hand on the hilt as the men approached.

Showing no respect for her femininity one of the men lunged towards Dauphin whilst the other five concentrated on Makarin. Dauphin was obviously considered the far lesser threat!

Unfortunately the man was in for a suprise, as Dauphin withdrew her sword with a speed and agility that suggested long experience on the battlefield. Within seconds she had brought her blade against his with such force his sword clattered out of his hand onto the street. As he dived for the fallen sword Dauphin administered a quick kick to the side of his head. Hardly ladylike, but she had no desire to kill him so knocking the man unconscious was a far easier solution.

She then turned to Makarin, who was outnumbered but still coping quite admirably.

"Still not need any help?"

Grabbing the blade instead of the hilt, she drove the heavy handle of the sword into the back of one of the men's heads knocking him to the ground. In the momentary confusion she was able to lash out at another man, although not quite as effectively whilst Makarin was seeing off another two of the attackers, more permanently. Two just turned on their heels and fled the carnage.

"Come, it's not safe to stay out here any longer," Makarin urged her, taking her back into the tavern.

"A meal for myself and the lady - she's earned it," Makarin told the barman and led Dauphin towards a smaller room at the back.

"You didn't harm those men. Why?" he asked her.

"This is not my land. I know nothing of them, and if a traveller such as me caused their death who do you think the authorities would believe?" she asked.
13322.title: A minor scuffle

choices: rare spices to bring out the food's full flavor
133221.content: The innkeeper himself put Makarin's and Dauphin's meal before them. As the two dove into their meals hungrily, they were soon to discover that the food had been laced with...
133221.title: A happy meal?

133222.content:
Before any more words could be spoken, the door of the tavern suddenly crashed open. A strong gust of wind flew over Dauphin, as she looked towards the door in surprise.

Standing in the doorway were a pack of men, clothed in almost tatters. They were tall and each broad shouldered, telling of their knowledge of battle. Their eyes roved over those in the bar, and quickly found Dauphin.

"My Lady?" One of the men asked, his voice reverent.

Glancing about her, Dauphin noticed the confused stares of those around her. Makarin eyed her warily. Quickly she stood and faced the men standing so humbly before her. "Sirs," she nodded, "You wish to speak with me?"

The leader of the group nodded. He glanced about at all those staring, open mouthed, at his small posse. "Please, my lady, come with us. There are important things we must discuss."
133222.title: The Lady

choices: Daupin doesn't go with the Scouts
1332221.content:
Dauphin noticed that Marakin's hand was once again resting on his sword, his dark eyes fierce. Seeing that he was more than willing to engage in battle over her a second time that night, Dauphin gently placed a restraining hand on his arm. Marakin had proven he was skilled with a sword, but he wasn't a match for these men.

"They are Latanish Scouts, my friend," she told him. "They mean me no harm."

Marakin didn't take his eyes off the men standing in the tavern's open doorway, their ragged travel-stained cloaks swirling about their tall figures like smoke. He'd heard of the Scouts, but he'd never actually seen more than one, much less six, in one place. Throughout the Seven Kingdoms the Latanish Scouts were feared and revered as warriors and wizards. They could command a man to speak nothing but the truth, though he were the basest of theives. It was said that their direct gaze was like that of a basilisk and could freeze a warrior in his tracks. According to legend, they spoke the language of the trees and the dragon kin and walked though forest shadows without a sound.

All of which Marakin knew was a load of nonsense.

He grudgingly loosened the grip on his sword. "Do you wish to go with them?" he asked Dauphin.
1332221.title: The Seekers

choices: Leave to take care of the ambusher
Finish the business you have in the city
13322212.content:
Dauphin left with the scouts, noticing as she did so that the tavern seemed to have gotten rather empty. She hid a grin as they took her to a hut not far off.

"What took you so long?" Dauphin asked. "You were supposed to meet me at the gate!"

"Milady," one of the scouts replied, "We were ambushed on the second night of our journey. We've just barely escaped. We need to take care of this new threat."
13322212.title: The scouts fill you in

133222122.content:
"The ambush took place outside the city walls?" Dauphin asked.

The scouts nodded as one.

"Then it would be foolish to go back out there. We are small in number and easy prey. Our lives are of more worth when combined with the forces within the city. I must see the King, for I have information of much value to him of the enemy's plans."

"Well let a few of us go back out then. We can gather more information that may be of use to you."
133222122.title: Within the city walls

choices: the Taura is an object of power hidden in the city
the Taura are a mysterious society of great power
1332221221.content:
"Huldor come with me. If we can’t get information without then we must get it within. I will talk with Makarin. The rest of you seek lodging somewhere you won’t draw too much attention. Go in pairs if necessary. Meet at the bar in the morning. He doesn’t trust you Huldor. Let me be the one to speak for you and watch your temper."

They entered and saw Makarin at table. "Thanks again for your help," said Dauphin, as she sat down. Huldor remained standing. "You know that the storm approaches – I need your help or rather the city needs your help. If this city falls, not only this land but many other lands will suffer."

"Many lands will suffer if this city falls or not. It is said Cardacian armies threaten not only this kingdom."

"Yes that is true. But perhaps there is something here, which if lost, or found, will cause greater grief than the mere passage of armies." Dauphin noted that at the words lost or found Makarin tensed every so slightly.

"I'm not sure I understand," he replied.

"No? I can tell you are a man of observation and it seems you have lived here long enough to know of what I speak." She paused and looked into Makarin’s eyes. He met her glance but said nothing. "But perhaps I was mistaken," she said and got up abruptly, scowling to Huldor.

"Wait," said Makarin. "Send away the Latan."

"I go whither my lady goes," said Huldor.

"Huldor," interrupted Dauphin, "go have an ale. See if you can find a set of lips offering more than just drunken babble."

Huldor went off with a snort and a stern glance at Makarin.

Again Dauphin looked into Makarin’s eyes. Their eyes met and the intensity of their stares might have been mistaken for newfound love. But this was not time for love -- the motive was much more primal – survival.

Makarin broke the silence. "You refer, of course, to the Taura."

"Yes."
1332221221.title: Broaching Minds

choices: Dauphin keeps her secret and departs
1332222.content:
Dauphin displayed no sense of surprise. She looked at them with cool, understanding eyes. Then she turned to Makarin. His lips seemed ready to curl into a smile, as if he was too timid to ask her to stay. She smiled at him, as if willing him to finish his own smile.

Then she turned to the men and spoke with a sharp confidence, "Not yet. I will find you when I am ready."

The men seemed stunned, but she did not give them another moment of her attention. The men looked at one another, and the one in front, presumably their leader, nodded at his men and led them out of the tavern.

Makarin looked at Dauphin with hopeful eyes and asked, "Who are you?"
1332222.title: A new friendship

13322222.content:
Dauphin laughed, as if the question was absurd. Malakin knew now: he'd like this girl. "My apologies," he said. "I tend to forget that in times like this people have no names." She grinned. "I keep no secrets. I am Malakin. I follow all fighting."

"Desperate to be a hero?" she asked with a sneer.

Malakin laughed. Yes, he'd like her a lot. "Heroism has little appeal to me. I only know heroes who have died."

"Maybe you'll be the first..." She had finished her food and now stood up. "I must not keep those men waiting much longer. Thanks for your help earlier, Malakin. I'm sure our paths will cross again soon."

Malakin watched her leave with great curiosity. Perhaps it was something stronger. Something like enchantment.
13322222.title: "Desperate to be a hero"

choices: The girl arrives at the stables and rests her steed
134.content:
The main priority, of course, was finding somewhere for the faelan. Riding in bad weather is comparitively easy for the rider as opposed to the animal, and she needed rest. Following the main pathway the girl lead the faelan. It was tired enough already without having to take her weight as well, as they had been travelling nearly flat out for several days.

A good stable was required. Faelans were ridiculously expensive, and anywhere disreputable might make the move to steal the creature rather than looking after it. It would be their mistake of course, as faelans are notoriously untrustworthy of strangers and likely to take the head off any fool who dared to come too near.

"Nearly there girl, nearly there."

Anyone watching the girl would be suprised that for one who had never been to the city she unerringly was heading in the direction of the best stables in town. Without map or directions, her mind had already worked out the route. Indeed you might be tempted to think either she had previously studied the city in great depth or there was a little bit of magic going on here....
134.title: Any room at the inn?

choices: Go to an inn and get some sleep.
Do errands and get some food.
1341.content:
A stable boy was sleeping in the corner of the barn, and so the girl took a moment to examine the facilities, the faelan following at her heels like an obedient puppy. The long rows of stalls were small, but they seemed to be clean, and there was just enough space for the faelan to stretch her wings and pace back and forth. She examined a couple of the other animals stabled there. A bay mare whickered softly as the girl approached her stall and nuzzled her ear. The girl appraised her carefully. She did not look diseased. In fact, she was well groomed and there was food in her trough.

The girl turned to the faelan, "Come with me, girl." The faelan was a relatively intellegant beast and she obeyed readily enough.

The stable boy woke with a start as the faelan's silver hooves stopped about an inch away from his ankle. He lifted his eyes to the girl in her travelling cloak. "Sorry miss," he murmured, climbing to his feet with a uncertain glance at the faelan. "Do you want to stable here for the night?"

She nodded. He held his hands out for the faelan's reins, only to look confused when he noticed there weren't any. "She obeys only me," the girl told him bluntly. "Don't touch her yet or she may bite your hand off."

The boy jerked his arm back. The girl turned to the beast and murmured something in a fluid language. The faelan visibly relaxed. "Now, will you show us to a stall?"

The boy nodded, then said, "I can take the... horse for you."

She shook her head, "Faelan. And no, she probably won't follow you. I always see to her myself anyway."

The boy shrugged and led them to an empty stall.

The girl opened the door and stood back as the faelan passed through. She kicked some of the wood clippings at her master, who giggled.

"Do you have a curry comb?"

The boy nodded,and handed her one from a shelf on the wall. Then he left while she desaddled the faelan and brushed her out.

He returned a few minutes later with a pile of alfelfa, which he put into the trough. The faelan looked from the food to the girl in distate.

"She's a carnivore..." the girl explained.

His eyes widened, "We don't have any meat, miss. We have never had any... any..."

"Faelans?" the girl supplied.

"Yes, we've never had any here before."

She sighed, then looked at the beast with a grin. "Then I suppose she'll just have to have you for supper."

The faelan pulled her lips back to give the boy the horse equivalent of a pointy toothed grin. His eyes bulged and he backed up.

"Just kidding!" she said, giggling at the look on his face, "She'll just have to eat the hay today."

The faelan looked at her with an expression of pure equine entreaty, then stalked over to to trough and begun to eat. It had been a long, exhausting journey, and they were both famished. She wanted to go find an inn and sleep, but she also had people she needed to see and really should go to a tavern for a bite to eat.
1341.title: The Stables

choices: Dauphin awakes to someone in the room
Dauphin awakes to a knife at her throat
13411.content:
Dauphin realised ruefully that she would get little done in the middle of the night, feeling as tired as she did. No, she had to get rest and leave things till the morning.

Getting the stable boy to recommend a tavern was easy enough, and Dauphin was soon lying in a warm bed. As sleep washed over her it was pure bliss just to lie back and think of nothing for once.
13411.title: Sleep

choices: Bolt from bed and perhaps gain the advantage.
Lie still and wait for a better opportunity.
134111.content:
"Wake up!" the voice screamed in her head. "Wake up!"

She was suddenly awake, but made certain to show no signs of it. She lay there, perfectly still, branching out with her other senses to feel what possibly had torn her from sleep.

Listening she could faintly hear the presence of someone or something in the room. The breathing is what gave them away. The breathing... and the smell.

She peeked beneath her eyelids, slowly scanning the room. It was too dark. She could see nothing. She could see nothing, but she could 'feel' something.

"What should I do?" she thought to herself. Without being able to see this enemy (from the smell she assumed it was an enemy) she would be at a disadvantage. She could only smell and 'feel' the presence in the room. The feeling you get when you know someone is watching you.

She ran over the options in her mind. She could bolt from the bed and perhaps surprise the intruder or she could continue to lie still until she could more surely pinpoint its location.
134111.title: Enemy Presence

1341111.content:
Dauphin used her sense of smell to locate the stranger in her room. The smell of fear and adrenaline on the stranger's person helped Dauphin locate them with no problems.

Steeling her muscles, Dauphin waited just a few seconds more. The stranger still had not moved. In a single motion, Dauphin flew out of the bed and the stranger found themselves with the tip of Dauphin's blade within a hair's length of the underside of their jaw. Dauphin found herself staring into the eyes of...
1341111.title: In the blink of an eye

13411112.content:
Dauphin took stock of the young woman under whose chin her dagger's tip was resting. She was fair-skinned to begin with. Watching Dauphin seemingly explode into action from a deep sleep had bleached all color from her skin.

"Please..." the young woman stuttered.

Dauphin pressed the blade just a millimeter higher, producing a high-pitched gasp and a drop of blood from the woman before her.

"A name," Dauphin said bluntly. "And it better be one to my liking."

The woman caught her breath, then continued in a surprisingly firm voice. Recovers quick from a surprise, Dauphin thought. A plus.

"I am..."
13411112.title: A visitor in the night

choices: She trusts the man and he names a time and place.
She doesn't trust him and they are attacked by the stable lad from behind.
1341112.content:
"Stay still, I want to talk, that's all. I am called Lord Marquine. You are a puzzling character, Lesandre."

Dauphin sat up and behind her mask started to panic. She hadn't been called that name since she was seven, when her father left.

"Relax. You probably want to know why I am here." He pausee for a second, then quietly, almost to himself, said, "So would I."

Marquine stepped forward and lit a lantern, which he then placed next to the bed. He was wearing a brilliant red cape and his hair was the color of mud. He had green eyes, but other than than he could be her father.

"I want to know why you're here."

Dauphin wondered, should she trust him, her inner child's heart told her to, but her brain said no. After all half of his face was in shadow. Was he evil, or was it the light?
1341112.title: The Man

choices: Dauphin gets dressed and follows him
Dauphin reaches for a weapon and attacks him
134112.content:
Having a blade at her throat wasn't an everyday experience for Dauphin, so it took a while for her to wake, even with the feel of cold metal against her skin.

Her eyes snapped open, and looked into those of someone else. In the dark of the room it was hard to discern much else about her assailant other than it had brown eyes.

"Get up." The voice was soft and male, but with a hard edge that told her that any attempt to escape would result in her neck getting a new air hole.

Dauphin slowly got to her feet, finding that someone had already been prudent enough to pull the bedsheet off of her. As her vision adapted to the gloom, she could see that it was a human that stood across the room from her, the knife still held up in his hand in a threatening gesture.

"Do you mind if I get dressed?" Dauphin asked after a short pause. The room did turn out to be rather cold clad only in her nightclothes.

"O-of course. But make it quick, there's someone that wants to see you."
134112.title: Night Visitor

choices: go back with the stranger and try to escape later on
1341121.content:
Dauphin walked to her bags and searched them for something warm to protect her from the angry storm raging outside.

Once she found something she turned to the stranger and said, "Would you please turn around while I change?"

"Yeah, like I'll fall for that trick," the stranger said harshly.

"Excuse me but I am just an innocent girl helpless and defenceless. What could I possibly do that could prevent you taking me to who ever wants to see me?"

"Listen lady! Don't you try to trick me with that innocent girl act! The boss told me to treat you with caution so treat you with caution I will!"

"First of all sir I don't even know who your boss is or why he would want me, and second how could you blame me, you would do the same if you were in my place! Could you at least wait outside the door? That way I can't sneak up on you."

"Yeah and that way you could sneak out the window."

"It is storming outside and we are at least three storeys up! Only a fool would try to get out the window."

"Fine. But you have five minutes. If you try to escape there will be dire consequences."

"Thank you sir."

After that the stranger left the room, and Dauphin changed into her warm clothes. After she changed she ran to the window and struggled to open it. When she finally got it open she looked out side only to be greeted by a strong gust of wind and the cold rain. She looked around the window to see if there was any way to climb down.

"Are you done in there yet?" The stranger called from behind the door.

"Almost!" she called back.

No time, she had to act now. She slowly climbed out of the window and hung on to the window sill for dear life.

Below she saw a cart of hay. She could jump and land safly on the hay. But the cart was some distance away. Should she try to jump for it or just go with the stranger hoping to escape on the road?
1341121.title: Attempt

13411211.content:
Dauphin decided she would jump for the hay. She heard the stranger knocking on the door checking on her. She had to jump now if she had any hope for escape.

"Hey lady, I said five minutes!" The stranger said as he burst through the door. He got one look at Dauphin at the window ready to jump and then yelled, "Hey, what, are you crazy? Lady get down from there you'll be killed!"

Dauphin then jumped from the window sill. At first she thought she wouldn't make it but then she hit the hay. For the first few moments she was shocked at having actully succeeded, but then she came back to realty.

She saw that the stranger was no longer by the window she had jumped out of, but instead he was running out of the inn door toward her. She jumped off the hay cart and ran towards the stables.

When she got to the stables she saw her faelan just outside of the stables with a group of men tying her up and beating her. The stranger was coming closer now. She had two choices. She could either try to help her beloved faelan and possibly get caught or she could run away and find a horse and get as far away from there as she could and leave her faelan behind.
13411211.title: Escape

choices: Cole takes Dauphin to an abandoned building
Cole ties up Dauphin and puts her on a cart.
134112111.content:
Dauphin decided that she just had to help her faelan and that she couldn't leave her there for those men to handle.

Dauphin ran towards them and tried to free the faelan, but one of the men grabbed her.

"Now what do we have here?" he said.

Dauphin tried to break out of their grasp but they were too strong. Just then she saw that stranger running up to them. She was completely trapped. There was no way that her or her faelan would get away now.

"Hey Cole!" the man hanging on to her yelled at the stranger. "I thought you were supposed to make sure this little girl went to see the boss, not run away."

"Sorry," the stranger, Cole, said. "It won't happen again. You just make sure you get that faelan to a safe place."

"No!" Dauphin yelled. "She stays with me! She'll bite your head off if I'm not with her."

"Don't worry sweety pie," another of the men said. "We'll be careful. You just be a good girl and go with Cole."

"I'll take her from here," Cole ordered.

"Don't let her run away this time!"

With that Cole took Dauphin's arm. Dauphin struggled to get away but Cole just gripped her tighter. He hung on so firmly it hurt.

"If you knew what was good for you, you'd do what you were told!" Cole hissed in her ear.

As Cole dragged Dauphin away Dauphin could see her faelan struggling to get loose from the ropes that the men had tied her up in.
134112111.title: The struggle

13411212.content:
Dauphin stood still and formed a mental image of the man with the knife. He was right handed, with a grizzled, stubbly face. He had the characteristic red, veiny nose of a heavy drinker. His reflexes were no doubt dulled by years of whisky. She could probably disarm the man, even kill him, easily enough. But what would that accomplish? Whoever sent him wanted her alive. And she might not ever find out who it was if she didn’t accompany him.

She had a short knife in her belt and another, longer dagger, in her boot. There was no point in revealing her skill in weaponry and hand-to-hand combat just yet. The Boss, whoever he was, clearly didn’t know that, despite her youth, Dauphin was an experienced assassin.

She opened the door. The man with the knife smiled appreciatively as he noticed her skin-tight buckskin pants and shirt. She felt almost violated as he looked her up and down, but said only, “Let’s go.”

The man motioned with the knife, indicating she should precede him. As they descended the stairs, he whispered. “Walk through the lobby. Don’t talk to anyone. Remember, I got my knife right here in your back.”

Dauphin did as he ordered. Outside, a light rain fell. “To your left,” the man said. They walked through the darkness for what seemed like a mile. Dauphin kept track of what landmarks she could see in the half-moon light, so she would know exactly where he was taking her.

Eventually they arrived at a one-story building quite a way from the tavern and the stables. Another man, standing guard, smiled when he saw them approach. “Good work, Dolm,” said the guard. “The Boss will be pleased.” He opened the door and motioned Dauphin inside.

She found herself in a large room with a ceiling so low it nearly brushed her head. A short, heavy-set man sat at a desk. Two other men, apparently bodyguards, slouched in chairs against the wall. Sloppy, thought Dauphin. I could probably have a knife in each guard’s throat before they knew what had happened. But then she’d never learn why a man had abducted her at knifepoint.

The fat man said, “Thank you for coming at such short notice.”

Dauphin didn’t think it was funny. “You didn’t give me much choice. Why couldn’t you have waited till morning and then asked me politely?”

“Because you might have said no.” He motioned her to a chair.

She sat down, but remained alert, ready to spring to her feet if need be.

“My name is Wel Dun,” the man said. He waited, apparently expecting Dauphin to introduce herself. She remained silent. After a moment he went on. “You entered the gate of our city with a faelan.”

What was he after, Dauphin wondered. Was he going to demand her steed for himself? Everyone knew a faelan was loyal to only one person. If it was loyal to any human at all.

“I have a faelan myself,” he said.

That bit of information surprised her. The stable boy said they had had no faelans previously. And if there had been a domestic faelan in the city, she would likely to have known it.

“Oh, I don’t keep it around here,” the man continued. “I built a special pen for it several miles to the east.”

“Surely you know that a faelan should never be penned up,” said Dauphin. “They need to be free, to fly, to hunt.”

“Yes, but if I let it fly free, it wouldn’t be mine any more, would it?”

It’s not yours now, she thought. Aloud, she said, “What do you want from me?”

“I need someone to break and train the beast, so I can ride it.”

Faelans respond to love and gentle coaxing, if they respond at all. Dauphin knew one could never be “broken.” It came to its rider willingly or not at all. It would die before it allowed itself to be ridden against its will. “I can’t help you.” She stood up. “Now if you’ll excuse me, I need my beauty sleep.” She stood up.

“My dear,” said the fat man, “I’m afraid I must insist.” He gestured to the two guards, who came to their feet brandishing swords.
13411212.title: The boss

choices: Dauphin kills the guard, takes her faelan, and leaves.
134112122.content:
The two brutish guards obviously had no training in swordsmanship. For the barest fraction of a second, Dauphin considered reaching for her daggers. If she could kill one quickly, the other one would likely present no problem. Still, they had swords while she had none. Better to discretely bide her time.

She sat back down and said to the Boss, “I have information for the Lord Of The City. Important information, concerning the war in the north.”

“Fine,” agreed the Boss. “By all means, pass your intellegence along to Lord Antirr first thing in the morning. Then meet me at the gate and we’ll go and see my faelan.”

Did the fat fool think actually she would meet him anywhere, wondered Dauphin. As if reading her thoughts, he grinned and said, “A faelan is a fearsome beast in the open, but yours is penned in a stable... and it’s not arrow proof.”

Dauphin cursed her self for twenty kinds of idiot. She should have let her mount roam free outside the city. Here she thought she’d done it a favor by bringing it to a warm, dry stable. The Boss had posted a guard at the stable who would kill her mount if she attempted to retrieve it and flee.

Through clenched teeth she asked, “May I go now?”

“Certainly, my dear,” agreed the Boss. “I’ll meet you at the gate at the ninth hour.”

As soon as she was out of sight of the Boss’ building, Dauphin backtracked to the stable. It looked dark and quiet. Silently, she crept closer and heard voices coming from inside. She didn’t want to look in and announce her presence, so she stood outside and listened. She heard the voice of the stable boy. He was apparently playing cards with another man.

“I can’t believe you’d really kill a faelan, Mokker,” said the stable boy. “They’re beautiful, magnificent animals.”

“Yeah, they are, and tame ones are incredibly rare,” said the other voice, apparently Mokker. “But the Boss told me to kill it if that dame tries to cross him. I aim to follow the Boss’ orders, seein’ as how I’ve grown inordinately fond of breathing.”

It sounded like there was only one guard in the stable. The Boss and his men were still taking Dauphin lightly. They had no clue that she was a highly trained assassin. She could dispose of the guard here at the stable easily enough. But then what? The boss would be gunning for her. She’d have to leave the city. She had to pass her information to the Lord of the City.

What to do?
134112122.title: Go or stay?

1341121222.content:
There was nothing else to do but bide her time. Dauphin kicked a rock on the ground as she headed back to her inn. How could she have been so stupid? She should never have hesitated, she should have killed all those men the minute she walked in the door.

But the past was past. As sick as she felt, Dauphin had really walked into this spiderweb. There was nothing else to do.

She tossed and turned for hours; it was nearly dawn by the time she fell back asleep.

When Dauphin awoke, the weight in her stomach had not lifted. She went through her options in her head. There was no way she could help that horrible man "tame" his animal. But her own was in such danger.... They had been travelling together for so long. It would kill her to lose the creature.

And of course, there was still her message to deliver...
1341121222.title: Decisions

choices: The lord is away; another welcomes her
13411212221.content:
No matter how she felt herself, the message to Lord Antirr was more important than the life of the faelan. She had not reached the decision lightly, and her every footstep as she walked towards the lord's manor was laboured with her grief.

Gaining access was little trouble when the seal on the letter was flashed; all who saw it recognised it, knew what it portended. To impede such a messenger was to court a fate worse than death, not that one such as Boss cared for such archaic rumours.

After all, the two nations had not been in contact for over a century. The ceremonial guardsman on duty at Antirr's behest would recognise the importance of her mission, as would perhaps a handful of diplomats and attorneys. But the common man could know nothing of the matters at stake when such a messenger came calling.

Lord Antirr himself, of such a long and noble line, would know best of all, and it would be on his head that the eventual decision of what was to be done would rest.
13411212221.title: Not an Oft Occurance

choices: She meets a band of robbers on the road
1341122.content:
Dauphin slowly walked to her bags and searched through it to find warm clothes. As she searched she found a small pocket knife. She turned around and faced the stranger.

"Would you turn around while I change?" she asked him.

"Be quick!" He replied harshly

Dauphin got dressed as swiftly as she could and hid the pocket knife in the folds of her dress.

"Come with me!" the stranger said.

As she walked toward him she pulled out the knife and jumped toward him. He tried to block her but she managed to stab his arm.

He crouched down in pain and agony. She took the handle part of the knife and knocked him out. She grabbed her things and left for the stables.

There she found her faelan and quickly left the town without a word to the guards as she rode past them.
1341122.title: Leaving

choices: Starfinder carries her out of the forest
Starfinder walks past the dryad to a tree with a hollowed out trunk
13411221.content:
Free of the town's barrier shield, Dauphin immediately turned off the road and into the woods. The trees were mostly oak, with high canopies. Time and the passing seasons had rendered the ground a soft carpet of leafy mulch. Here and there small oak saplings grew, but there was no other undergrowth. Toxins released by the decaying leaves prevented anything else from taking root.

She was not happy to be back out in the cold night air. She wondered what had tipped her hand. The presence of her faelan Miriam would only have told anyone who cared to notice her that she came from wealth. She'd chosen a good inn, which should have had better security.

"Stop it!" She reprimanded herself out loud, causing Miriam to spread her wings and toss her mane in concern. "Not you, silly. Me. Everything is behind me. Everything is lost. I have to stop second guessing why things have spiraled out of control so badly and find my own path through this chaos."

Dauphin patted the faelan's neck affectionately. "We are all that is left, Miriam. We must build up from here and stop letting others dictate our actions."

A tall woman clothed in oak leaves stepped into the moonlight and blocked her path. In the pale glow of the full moon, there were no colors, but Dauphin could see that the woman's complexion threw back little light. It seemed tight, draw harshly across strong cheek bones, prominent from near starvation.

"You cannot pass here, human." The voice was dry, raspy. Dauphin suddenly noticed the woman's hair was not "hair" at all! A Dryad had woken from its slumber to stop her.

"I meant no disrespect, Keeper of the Tree, and what a fine tree it is! But I cannot return the way I came. I am the last of my house and I am hunted, even as you are, even as your daughters are."

The Dryad stood motionless. Slowly, as if studying Dauphin and Miriam in detail, she moved her head from side to side. Eventually, she stepped forward and touched Miriam's muzzle. She gently stroked the faelan's nose, then her cheeks. To Dauphin's surprise, Miriam did not object. She lowered her head so the dryad could fondle her ears.

"I see she loves you, human. Though I cannot imagine why. Do you know her true name?"

Dauphin was puzzled. What did a dryad know about faelan?

"Her name is Miriam."

The dryad looked up from where she was caressing the faelan's forehead. She frowned.

"Her true name is Starfinder. If you had let her guide you instead of forcing her to your path you would be free of my lands and our paths would never have crossed. Because Starfinder loves you, I will let you live, but there is one condition. You must remove the reins and never guide her again. Talk to her. Tell her where your thoughts are leading you, then let her choose the path."

Dauphin's first impulse was to simply command Miriam to destroy the dryad. The downside, she knew, would be her own death at the hands of the dryad's daughters and sisters hovering even now in the shadows of their trees where she could not see them. She would fight hard and it would be a find, honorable death, but there would be no poets to sing of it.

She did not want to be forgotten by dying in a forest and becoming mulch. She dropped the reins.

"I cannot reach the bridle from here."

With a smile that was almost warm, the dryad removed the bridle and reins and let them fall to the forest floor.

"Now tell Starfinder what your seek and let her take you there."

Doubt filled her mind, but now she had no way of guiding her faelan.

"Miriam..." she began, but the dryad frowned at her and looked about to strike, "...pardon me, Starfinder, I need shelter, food, and a place to start a new life."
13411221.title: She goes into the woods

choices: They have landed at the gates to a magic academy
They have landed at the gates to a castle she does not know
They have landed at an isolated farmhouse surrounded by open meadows
134112211.content:
Starfinder immediately screamed in joy, spread her wings, and leaped into the concealing canopy of the trees. Dauphin grabbed onto Starfinder's mane and held on as tightly as she could. Her saddle and stirrups kept her upright, the grip of her knees held her in place. In a moment, they broke through the oaks and were sailing against the full moon. It was cold here in the sky. Dauphin pulled her coat tightly around herself and held on to Starfinder as best she could.

To her great surprise in a moment they had flown back the way they had come and were over the town where someone had tried to capture her. Starfinder headed west away from the full moon and away from the town. They passed rolling hills, open meadows, farmland, countless small villages lit only by the hearth fires warming the homes.

After flying for an hour, or maybe a bit less, Starfinder began to circle downward to the earth. When she saw where they had landed, Dauphin felt a combination of both curiosity and relief.
134112211.title: Starfinder takes to the sky

13412.content:
Looking around she determined that the out lying people had not understood the furtive plan that she had been given. Nor had they fathomed the depth to the course which she must take.

And so, after ensuring the safety and comfort of the closest essence to her, she moved with the silence that generations of her lost tribe had unbeknown to her embued, they had laid the foundations of all that should be.

But this she still was not to know, nor understand, she acted with the the essence of one that acts for the moment.

Hers was different.

But, that would take time to tell.

She had mixed feelings as she strood pasionately through those "Hallowed" doors to the saloon.

To the entrance of the world that she had been warned about, and for an unknown reason, feared to tread.

Where her Father had been taken down.

With a corrupt establishment, which was scared to hold the fort against the power that they assumed was greater than them.

For that trial they were wrong, but the court holds no juristiction upon the complaicency of man.

Which, ironically, was why she was here.
13412.title: Begotten

choices: She takes her chances and sits down with the man
She plays it safe and waits by the bar
134121.content:
Fallon would be here, she knew. As she stalked silently along the side of the saloon, she stole glances through the dust-covered windows. It was dimly lit; business done here was not meant to be seen.

Though she knew it was probably useless, she looked for Fallon. A few darkly clad men sat at the bar; more men clustered around tables. They spoke in a hushed, controlled manner. This was not a place for drunks. In fact, it was not a place for most men, even those without a soft spot for alcohol. "Men." The first jitters creeped into her body then and she cursed them under her breath. A woman in this place would be suspicious, but she had no other alternative. He had told her to meet him here.

The door seemed to brood before her. Her nerves dulled as she took a deep breath, and she pushed the door open. Though the door was heavy, she pushed it open with ease. A few men looked up at the noise, and she noticed their faces as she kept hers blank. With a sixth sense she'd developed through necessity, she noted that many other men had noticed her entry. Whispers stopped momentarily as more men glanced her way. She felt an especially intense gaze and let her eyes drift to a table near the window where a man indeed was looking intently at her, his dark eyes hidden under the long straight hair that hung over the sides of his face. His blonde hair was in striking contrast to his dark features, and as she noticed his strong nose and curved lips, she felt a weakness run through her that she had not expected.

Startled, she turned away and inspected the other side of the room. His eyes still bore into her; she could feel their intensity, which was not letting up. Could he feel her heart, beating quickly? She wondered if this was Fallon. It would be a dangerous gamble to make in this place, but she felt a connection to this man.
134121.title: Saloon

1341211.content:
In defiance of her gut feeling, she turned once again to face the man. Their eyes met and she held his gaze as she started toward his table. Whispers arose as the men returned to their hushed conversations, keeping a wary eye or ear on the curious stranger. Lithely she weaved through the tables, watching the man as she approached. He sat alone, appearing deep in thought. He made no gesture of welcome and made no attempt to even acknowledge her approach, but she felt an awareness in him and knew he was waiting.

"Fallon," she whispered matter of factly as she sat lightly into the chair opposite the man. It was hard and roughly hewn, and obviously made for a person larger than she. It hurt to sit; the days of riding had left her bruised and tender. Stoically, and out of necessity, she disregarded the pain and concentrated on the man's face, his body. Body language was often easier to read than faces, especially if the eyes were obscured. Already she had focused her psychic energy on the man. She would need to use her every ability here, she knew. There was no room for mistakes. Not one of her senses warned her of bad intentions.

"Atalia," the one word was spoken with eloquence, rolling off the tongue with a dark sensuality that sent her nerves tingling. He looked up then, and his dark eyes caught the light from every candle in the place and flickered there, a thousand lights dancing, reflecting back into her eyes. She was mesmerized by the magic.

"Yes," almost an incoherent whisper was her answer.

"This place is full of danger," his eyes searched hers, and the depth of his eyes reflected the danger she too knew was all around them. "Every minute in this place is a risk. Too many eyes watch, too many ears hear our words," he glanced slightly to his left. A chair creaked; a man looked away. After a few seconds he continued, "We must leave. Follow me, Atalia, to a place where we can speak alone."

Every whisper in the place sounded like a scream to her ears. It was too strong, too sudden. Too new. It was a feeling not to be trusted, but as his magnetic eyes pulled her in, she felt that it was.
1341211.title: Magnetic eyes

choices: She follows him into the alley
13412111.content:
Silently they weaved their way through the city, him deftly navigating their journey and she following closely behind. His pace was brisk and though she was tall for a woman, occasionally she needed to jog to keep up. It was odd the way he moved, with a steady, sure, almost calculated gait. It reminded her of a faelan.

Just as she began to tire and lag behind, he stopped abruptly, his heavy cape left swirling behind him. After a sharp-eyed survey, he stepped to his right and disappeared. Dauphin, otherwise known in her homeland as Atalia, blinked.

"Come," the whisper was anxious, as though they were running out of time.

But she hesitated. Though given a layout of the city with the important buildings and places meticulously described, she had no idea where she was. And, she noted with a chill, Fallon was the only one who knew where she was. She could not guess the time she had traveled, but it had been a fair distance and she doubted she could track her way back. Not to mention, a young woman traveling alone after dark here was an easy target and would not cross the street alone at this time if she could help it. Cold rain stung her cheek and ran down her back as she glared into the dark alley into which her guide had disappeared. A mere two feet separated the buildings on either side, niether of which she recognized. There was no light. If not shown it existed, she would never have known it was there.

"This is not a place to to question your trust," the voice hissed, faceless in the darkness.
13412111.title: A test of faith

134121111.content:
Quietly she slipped into the alley. She could neither stay in the open nor safely follow Fallon through dark, unknown alleys but unfortunately she had left herself no other choice. She knew she had a better chance of fighting off one man in a narrow alley than five or six men in the street. Nearly any man would be stronger than she, but it did not escape her that the narrow confines of the alley would prevent him from using his full strength against her. Still she remembered the way she had been captivated in the saloon. The enchantment had faded, but the connection had not; it was nerves that caused her to doubt the strength of that feeling.

Fallon was the only person she knew in this city, and she couldn't truthfully say she knew him. Seven moons ago she had recieved a strange but intriguing letter addressed to a name that only her mother had ever called her: Atalia. The rest in their small village knew her as Dauphin; she doubted anyone else knew even of her existence. In the first letter the writer had earned her belief.

When she was very young, her family had fled a wealthy city. In fact she was too young to remember anything but the briefest flashes from that time, but she'd been told stories. On the darkest of nights, when snow blew in under the slats of wood in the walls of their home and the wind wailed its sad song in the trees, she would share the bed with her mother, sister and younger brother. They would stave off the cold that way, and her mother would stave off the sadness by telling captivating stories about the past.

They'd been very wealthy once, she explained, with a house that was never cold, food that never ran out, and a fine stable that was never empty. Colorful rugs from Traebol decorated the floors; jewels from Koche decorated their necks. In the winter, the hearths were alight with an unending supply of logs, and they would sit and wave their feet in front of the fire to warm them. Then, when their cheeks would glow red like apples in the summer, they would be carried to sleep in beds stuffed with the soft feathers of birds. They had even had a family crest, a red faelan with a man on its back. But the two were flying, like in the old myths, rather than on the ground like they are actually ridden.
