There was a story about the crest, her mother had said, but she hadn't heard it in so long that she couldn't even remember it. In her dreams Atalia had seen the crest, clearly as if she were awake, with the red faelan and defiant rider. But in her dreams, the person riding the faelan was not a man. It was her.

So when she opened the tiny package wrapped up inside the letter and found a gold ring with red Faelan and rider exactly as her mother described the crest, she knew it was no lie.
134121111.title: The beginning

1341211111.content:
The alley smelled of mildew and rotting wood, much the same smell as a healthy forest but with the dirty smells of a city mixed in. It was not a pleasant smell and she moved her riding cape over her nose to block it out. Eyes wide open, Atalia walked as quickly as she dared and the sounds of her boots on the stone floor echoed softly back at her. She could hear her breath in her ears and, because she could see little more than the black silhouette of the tops of the buildings against a dark navy sky, all four of her other senses were heightened.

Behind her in the street she'd left, new voices had materialized. First there were two, and then more joined in; she could not discern how many, though it seemed not more than four. As they talked, she heard metal tapping against the cobblestone. Horses. She glanced back, heart beating hard in her chest, but could see nothing.

"You are sure?" It was a soft voice, perhaps a woman's, but it was so muted from the distance that Atalia really could not tell.

"Yes, she is here. The guards let her in nearly two hours ago and I was notified shortly after."

A pause.

"There is something else," another voice offered slowly.

"What?" the soft voice snapped.

"The guards... they thought they saw... they said she had-"

"What?"

"Well, they said she came with a faelan."

Quiet laughs, whispers. They didn't believe him. Atalia caught her breath, suddenly afraid that even the smallest noise would betray her presence.

An uneasy silence followed; Atalia's breath strained in her chest.

"Which gaurds?" The whispers stopped immediately.

"Gate 7."

"How did they know?"

"She wore the ring." Dead silence, followed by urgent whispers. Moments later hooves clattered against the cobblestones and they were gone.

Atalia breathed a sigh of relief.

A tall shadow to her right and then the same dark voice, "Many know of you; of this you were not told. Either you trust me, or you trust no-one."
1341211111.title: Close encounter

choices: She sleeps soundly through the night
13412111111.content:
"I trust you," her voice gave away her surrender.

"Good," he whispered softly, his breath falling lightly upon her cheek, "Follow me."

Behind him the cape flared and she could hear his footsteps pulling away as she pushed away from the wall, following him obediently. As she walked, she scrutinized the dark, obscured ground for anything she might trip over. A faint beam of light fell from the alleyway then and she saw it was clear of debris; she looked up to find the man's caped figure retreat behind a door in the building, letting it close behind him but leaving a crack of light to guide her.

When she pushed the door open cautiously she was greeted by the warm glow of a room lit by candlelight. The spaciousness of the room took her by surprise, as did the warmth of furnishings and smell of cooked food. Immediately a hunger pain stabbed its way through her stomach and she became aware of her hunger. She'd not eaten since that morning, and only a few stale flakes of bread and dried fruit pieces at that. Carefully she shut the door behind her and, seeing the two locks this side of the door, locked them.

"I imagine you'd like a warm meal. There's food here," his voice echoed from around a dividing wall and she instinctively headed toward it, being sure to stay well away from any pieces of furniture or delicate looking decorations. Inspecting the room as she walked, she saw that there was a large hearth on the wall opposite her. It was well stocked with logs and she could faintly feel the warmth it provided even from where she was standing. Her body relaxed further and she allowed her eyes to roam. Though the floor was bare, the room was well furnished and, she thought, well lived in. Chocolate-colored leather furniture was placed before the fire and she longed to lay her tired body on the long armoire. A few throw blankets promised extra protection from chill. She continued to her left, away from the couches and hearth and toward what she assumed was the kitchen. Beyond the hearth and furniture to her right was an open door, with no light beyond. On the walls hung a number of lanterns, all unlit; a few tables held enough glowing candles to prive all the light that was needed. A large mirror - a luxury - hung on the back wall before her, reflecting the dark room mysteriously. The last thing she saw before she rounded the dividing wall were the glorious pictures. Rather than hunting animals for their heads and their skins, whomever had decorated this home had hunted them for their soul; beautiful paintings of animals adorned the walls and lent vibrant color to the room. Paintings of horses, wolves and faelans. Dragons, even, though she had never seen one and was never entirely convinced they existed.

"Here," Fallon put a wooden bowl before her and her nose and eyes recognized it as stew. It was gone within minutes and she asked for more. Fallon watched her silently, his dark eyes brooding, hiding his thoughts. She sensed his seriousness and the gravity of his thoughts, but was not skilled in mind reading and could not tell what words passed behind those eyes.

Later he showed her the other rooms of the home; there was the room she saw upon entry, a back room with stacks of books with bound papers and detailed maps dotting the walls which was directly behind the entry room, and three of what looked like bedrooms. These were what lay beyond the dark doorway in the entry room. They had beds - larger than those at home - and her bones complained to her wearily when she saw them. Thankfully she was instructed that this is where she would sleep tonight, and Fallon left her there momentarily as she dropped her traveling bag next to the bed and straightened the quilts blanketing the large bed.

His eyes notified her of his return - it was impossible not to feel when he lay them on her. Curiously she looked up and studied his face, opened her mind to his. He would speak now, she realized, and quietened her hands.

"You passed the test," he stated and it seemed as if he were congratulating her. "I've asked you to do things you should not have done, that were against common sense and everything you know, and you did them. You know I speak the truth," he smiled slightly as he said 'truth'. "Words cannot be trusted. They are dangerous; they can break a strong man's heart and kill the best warrior. By your actions I'm ensured of your trust and don't need to ask it, but I want you to know that everything I ask of you, I ask for a reason."

"I understand," she said, sitting upon the bed for the first time. It was soft and her body sunk gently into it.

"Tomorrow we will begin your training. Sleep well; you will need your strength."

With that he left and the remaining doubt lingering in her mind retreated with him. Exhausted, she fell upon the bed and pulled the blankets close around her chin. Slowly the lights which seeped through her eyelids faded and she was asleep.
13412111111.title: A bond of trust

choices: She wakes up in a cold sweat
134121111111.content:
Meadow. A meadow in the forest. I am walking through a meadow in the forest. Alone I walk. The meadow I walk alone. Grass gently teasing my fingers, my fingers grip a sword. The grass feels sharp, sharp like the blade of my sword. It is dark, perhaps dawn, as the sky remains lit by a fading sun. Beautiful scene, I like this. Peace and serenity, peace and serenity. I wonder to myself if I should continue with the walk. I continue and he is there. He stands beside me, he looks at me and he speaks.

"Who are you?" he asks.

"I am who you wish to be myself," I reply.

"You will fail. You are destined to fail. Your training will fail, if you fail you will no longer be who you wish to be."

Peace and serenity. The grass ripples in the meadow with the wind. Swaying to and fro, I hack at the grass, it comes off. The grass will come off. I continue to walk until I come to a tree, the tree is a bark tree. The bark on the tree is brown, brown like the hilt of my sharp sword. My sword is very sharp, it can cut grass. He appeared.

"You cannot make it," he shouted. "You will not make it!"

"I will, I will," I said. "I will I will."

Ghosts emit from the grounds below. He is not there. The ghosts tell me something, what do they tell me? They point, they tell me I am not the one. They tell me the meadow will sink beneath me, the meadow must sink beneath me. My world sinks beneath me! I fall, he was correct.
134121111111.title: Nightmare

134121111112.content:
Light filtered weakly through the drapes above her head and she could just hear the soft sounds of the life of the city outside when she woke up. With a happy sigh, she stretched luxuriously in the bed. She'd slept fabulously, and had not woken up a single time during the night. It was rather odd, she thought, considering where she was, but the thought did not concern her.

After she had been up awhile, had made the bed and organized her things, Fallon poked his head into the room.

"How did you sleep?"

"Very well, thank you," she replied with a smile.

"Good. Nightmares are a sign of discontent with the gods. Good sleep speaks of the gods' good will. We can proceed with training as planned," he paused to gauge her reaction and, satisfied as she held his eye, continued, "There are two methods of training you must choose from, as you cannot do both. One is Varchi'va, to train you for mental battle. No doubt you know of your inborn talents."

Atalia nodded.

"The other is Honci'va, to train for physical battle. Also you have talents here - most men are warriors and have little knowledge of the damage well trained female warriors are capable of. Each has their own strengths and weaknesses, and once you begin with one you may never learn the other. Your bath has been readied," he motioned for her to follow him, "and breakfast will be ready thereafter. I will expect a decision from you when I see you next."

With that he opened an old wooden door to reveal a small but clean and bright bathroom, complete with steaming bathtub. Gratefully she unrobed, sank into the bath and began to think of training.
134121111112.title: Training

1341211111121.content:
A short time later, Atalia joined Fallon at the table. Looking up, he noticed without surprise that both the night's rest and the short bath had done much to improve her mood and condition. They had little time and the matter of training would best have been cleared up last night, but doing so would have put undue stress on the girl. Already she had travelled days on the back of a faelan and while there were worse ways to travel, the exhaustion had been apparent in her manner and he knew it would have been a mistake to push her any further.

"You have decided?" he asked as he rose to retrieve the mash-grain he had prepared for breakfast.

Behind his back, her face twitched with irritation. Was he always this impersonal?

After a slight pause, she responded, "Yes. There was little choice."

Fallon turned around, bowl of grain and glass of milk in hand. Carefully he set it in front of her, pushed the utensils toward her, and took a seat across the table. He leaned forward, and the emerald green sleeves of his robe pulled back to reveal worn but strong hands which he set, clasped, on the table. He looked at her for a moment.

"It seems to me it was a very big choice," he said pointedly, watching as her chewing slowed and she looked him in the eye. There was a twinkle in her eye and a twitch of a smile on her lips. She knew he was testing her.

"It seems to me that's not your call to make."

Inwardly he laughed, and let her eat in peace for a few moments as he studied her. She had her father's grey eyes and flaxen hair and her mother's pale complexion and long, slim frame. Also he knew she had inherited the gift which had skipped her mother but ran in her entire family's blood, and he knew without having to ask which training she would pursue. There really was little choice, he agreed silently. It was her destiny, and she burned to follow it. It was why she had come this far.

Atalia stopped chewing for a moment.

"Varchi'va," she said, and met his eyes.

"Very well," he nodded and continued, "That leaves the question of how, exactly, you would like to begin training."

A question sprung to her grey eyes, and they glittered like glass.

"Would you like to begin training with friends," he asked slowly, holding her gaze and then continuing in a dangerous voice, "or against enemies?"
1341211111121.title: Friends or Enemies

choices: She doesn't notice Fallon watching her.
13412111111212.content:
Atalia weighed the two options in her mind for a few minutes before replying.

"Enemies," she stated simply.

"Very well," Fallon stated as he rose from his chair, long body taking forever to rise. Atalia had noted his height the night before, but now as she sat watching him, well rested and with clear thoughts, she considered it again. Any serious enemy would recognize him from a good distance not only because of his height - native residents here were usually of a shorter, stockier build and most foreigners were easy to spot - but because of his distinctive gait as well. With herself alongside, she doubted they would go unnoticed by any but the most distracted of people. Her mind wandered back to the horses and voices she had heard the night before.

"She wore the ring."

Atalia had been twirling the ring around her finger idly, but now she quieted her fingers as she looked down. As she had done many times before, she noted the bright gold band, the smooth glossy red of the faelan and the clear stone which twinkled in its eye, and the silvery, shimmering rider on its back. It was a beautiful ring and she had appreciated it as such from the first time she'd seen it, but now as she gazed at it with the knowledge that it represented something real, something more than the fantasy she'd played in her head for the past seven moons, it took on a new importance and a new beauty. Enemies would notice it, she knew, but the realization was not enough to make her take off the ring. Suddenly she felt that it belonged there, a part of herself that she'd not known of for so long and one that she was entirely unwilling to hide.

Seemingly hypnotized, she stared at the ring, suddenly oblivious to all else, including Fallon. He stood, feet away from her, piercing brown eyes resting on the ring.
13412111111212.title: The ring

134121111112122.content:
Fallon, knowing that Atalia would not break her attention, took the opportunity to inspect the ring. It was as he remembered it and though he knew it was hers by right, he marveled to see it on her hand.

With an inborn skill that had been developed over tens of years, he read the thoughts which streamed through her mind, cataloguing them incase they would help him later. But for now he simply listened, curious to know what was going through her head. Last night he had discovered that she was surprisingly good at mind-blocking and until now, he'd been mostly unable to break through the block that she had held up. Realizing now how powerful she was, a chill ran up his spine and he worked immediately to block it. There were so few of the masters left that he knew she'd had no prior training. Rather, she had a gift beyond that of any of their living line. Should she be captured and used in the wrong hands, she would be an exceedingly difficult force to defeat. Should the wrong side earn her loyalty, Fallon had little hope that their line would exist at all after this war was over.

"It is time," he spoke finally. Her head snapped up and immediately the connection was gone.
134121111112122.title: Inborn powers

1341211111121221.content:
Atalia shivered involuntarily as she stepped outside. Autumn was coming fast and while the days were still warm, the nights were getting colder and the lingering morning chill nipped at her hands and cheeks. Pulling the dull, black robe that Fallon had loaned her closer around her body, she watched the curled red, orange, and yellow leaves tumble down the gray cobblestone street.

Instinctively stepping sideways, she narrowly missed tripping over Fallon's feet.

"Pay attention," he warned, assessing the crowded street head.

Fallon slipped into the street; Atalia balked, waiting for an opening in the stream of people. Dark, hooded head bobbing, Fallon was quickly retreating down the street and Atalia pushed reluctantly into the crowd.

"Sorry," she appologized to a woman in red after she bumped her, and then immediately ran into a very tall man, who gave her a nasty look. Bodies came orderlessly from left and right and Fallon was nearly out of sight. Atalia wondered how he could possibly be getting through this that quickly. Knowing she was about to lose him, Atalia felt her heart beat wildly in her chest. Then, he disappeared.

Trying not to panic, she walked faster than she thought she could have. All these people. She'd never seen so many people in her life. She fought the suffocating feeling of being surrounded by so many people. As she walked faster, heading off tingles of panic, a funny thing happened. She began to anticipate people's movements. it began slowly, with a feeling that a person would move left or right, and as she began to lose herself in concentration, she began to see paths through multiple people. When she began to see colors, the crowd began to part around her.

Abruptly she stopped. She stood stalk-still, breathless, then her eyes were drawn to the left where someone sat on the steps of a shop. They were looking directly at her.
1341211111121221.title: Continue

choices: She gets her faelan and returns home.
She stays and searches for answers.
13412111112.content:
"I trust no-one," she declared angrily into the dark face before her. His energy radiated into her and his dark eyes seemed to shimmer in the darkness. She took a step against the wall, toward the street, and continued, "You say I will be safe, that I will be protected, and then lead me into an alley protected by none but yourself? Where are we going? Who were those people and why was I not warned of them?" It was more of a declaration than a demand. Defiantly she stared into the face, which was quiet for a moment.

"You would never have come, had you known the extent of the problem," he answered simply.

"How can you expect me to trust you? I'm wanted, there is a war brewing and I haven't a clue what side I am on or whose side I am in, and you tell me I can't know the truth," she spit the words out and stared defiantely into those dark eyes. "I trust no-one," she whispered again, voice steely. She turned abruptly and walked toward the street, feeling once again his eyes boring into her back, watching her as she left.
13412111112.title: I trust no-one

1341212.content:
Dauphin knew that she was vulnerable, a strange woman in an even stranger place. Yet she could not show the slightest fear of her surroundings. With her head held high she walked to the bar, scanning the array of bottles as she did. It would be unwise to appear foreign by asking for something not stocked.

"Davod," she ordered, handing over a small coin in return for a smoking goblet of the clear liquid. She had tasted it before, knew what to expect from the fiery substance as she downed it. The heightening of the senses as it burnt down her throat, warming her from within.

"You'll give yourself indigestion," came a voice from behind her.

"And a good day to you too Fallon," Dauphin said, turning.
1341212.title: Fire and friends

choices: Investigate - the killer could still be in the stables
1342.content:
Dauphin arrived at where she knew to be one of the best stables in the city. Which would have been a perfect place to house her faelan, if it were not for the simple fact that they were closed! There was not a stable hand or even a night watchman in sight, which was strange given the obvious value of some of the animals that would be inside.

Making her way round the side in search of anyone that could help her, Dauphin was unfortunate enough to find the poor night watchman. Or who she presumed was the night watchman anyway, it was hard to distinguish it as being anyone other than a body slumped to the ground, dead from a sword thrust to the stomach.
1342.title: Nowhere to stay

choices: Stop fighting and trust the attacker
13421.content:
Unsheathing her sword Dauphin muttered a few brief words to her faelan, before leaving it outside so she could investigate within as quietly as possible.

Edging towards the sole doorway Dauphin tried to see into the gloom, but little was apparent. A light moved towards the back, but she could not see clearly enough to tell how many were inside, or up to what purposes.

Just then a hand closed over her mouth, another over her sword hand, dragging her close to a strong male body. Dauphin was not to be so easily captured however and bit at the hand with all her fury.

"Hush you little fool. I'm here for the same reason as you," a voice behind her whispered.
13421.title: Captured or...?

choices: Check for clues and hide the body
134211.content:
The girl turned to find the towering figure still shrouded in shadow. But that voice, she would have recognized that voice anywhere.

"Damien!" She squeeled with delight and threw her arms around his neck, all the while showering him with kisses.

"You know you didn't have to bite me, What was I, or anyone for that matter, ever going to be able to do to you? Your steed out there would have manhandled anyone in a minute. Assuming that you didn't kick their ass first. It is good to see you girl. Did you find that body outside?"

She nodded, "Yeah, what are we going to do about him?"
134211.title: Damien

choices: Gernan is the leader of a band seeking to assassinate the king
1342112.content:
Dauphin followed Damien from the stables, and watched dispassionately as he half-lifted the body of the dead man and dragged him inside.

"Pleased as I am to see you," she said dryly, "I can't help but wonder about this fellow's death. Did you kill him?"

He nodded, and grunted with the weight of the corpse. "Had to. I'm staying at the inn and, when I came down to check on old Ceinfath here, this fellow very nearly slit my throat."

"Oh!" she gasped in chagrin. "You're not wounded, are you?"

"Not unless you call a couple of bruises a wound."

"But I don't understand. Why would a night watchman try to kill you? He wasn't a jealous husband, was he?"

"Of course not," said Damien indignantly. "I'll have you know that my acquaintance with you has put a stop to all of my... hmmph... 'wicked ways.' But nevertheless, his reasoning was understandable." He dropped the dead man onto a pile of straw with a thump. "I'm working for Gernan."

Dauphin gasped in shock. The name was familiar to her, as it was to all in the city.
1342112.title: Damien's Explanation

choices: Dauphin's armies are met by the kingdom's imperial guard
Dauphin is struck by a stray arrow, mistaken for an enemy by her men, and hunted
Dauphin comes to realize the evil in her actions
14.content:
One of the lesser guards began to open his mouth to speak, but then the lead guard inturrupted, "I'm sorry, girl, but no one gets in without proper identification."

"Well, that's too bad," Dauphin replied before turning around to mount Vrexx, her faelan. She raised her left hand towards the night sky and launched a fireball out of her hand, thus giving the signal. Then Vrexx carried her into the air as she watched the chainmail-clad huskarls emerge from the darkness from both sides of the gate.

The two forces engaged in combat, but the guards were easily slaughtered by Dauphin's army. One of the crossbowmen then shouted, "Okay! Bring out the rams!" Out of the woods, the bulky shapes of battering rams slowly advanced towards the gate.

The gate fell easily after being pulverized by the mighty siege weapons as the wall guards were killed by the crossbowmen. The huskarls and crossbowmen flooded into the city, the warriors in the rams emerged one by one as they unsheathed their blades and Dauphin flew over the city to survey the carnage.

"Are you sure about this?" asked Delpheus the Transmuter, her twin brother, as he emerged from the aethir to fly beside her with wings of magic.

"Of course," replied Dauphin. "After all, the evidence shows that this kingdom is the one responsible for all of the mysterious attacks on my homeland. But the diplomats of this nation still deny it. Remember our family, Del? Remember the blood, the soulless look in their eyes, the arrows stuck in their flesh? Now these heartless savages will pay for their crimes. After all these years, justice will finally be served."

"Uh-huh. And what if you're wrong?" Delpheus replied.

Dauphin didn't answer that, but just watched as the huskarls entered the houses of the vile people and butchered them in their homes, in their sleep and in the streets. Ah, she thought, sweet justice. The fiends deserved nothing less.
14.title: Into the Breach

141.content:
Sitting high in his palace in the centre of the city the King viewed the carnage by the gates. If action was not taken quickly the invaders would have control of the city, so there was no option but to send the imperial guard, the greatest of the troops. It would leave the castle dangerously underguarded, however, if the guard were to fail.

"Send out the imperial guard."

In the outskirts of the city, Dauphin turned to Delpheus once more.

"Before long they will send reinforcements. I suggest one of us takes a small group and tries to get closer to the castle."

Delpheus looked into the sky line. He could already begin to see the troops moving towards them in the distance. A decision had to be made quickly.
141.title: Apart

choices: Bluff your way past the guards
1411.content:
Dauphin hated the idea of seperation, but knew that the imperial guard would severely delay their progress towards the castle. She also knew that she would be the most efficient to try and single handedly reach the castle: few would expect a slight girl to be a fearsome enemy leader.

"I will go. Be cafeful brother," she answered and not giving anyone time to think about it vaulted off Vrexx and into a nearby street. Dauphin knew she worked best alone, but with her mental link to Delpheus back up would never be far away.

The route to the castle was mostly blocked with imperial guards at present. Dauphin knew she could either risk the more direct route or take a much longer, but less dangerous, circuitous route.
1411.title: A girl without fear

14111.content:
Dauphin walked quickly up the street. She gripped the hilt of her sword to keep her hands steady. Though she was no stranger to death, the Imperial Guards were well known for their prowess in battle.

She saw them coming towards her, armored and muscular. Realizing that no sensible girl would wish to be caught in their path, she made it appear that she was trying to conceal herself in the shadow of a nearby house. The guards paid little attention to her. She breathed a sigh of relief as the last few ranks passed her.

Then suddenly her plan exploded into infintesimal fragments. She saw a bearded, sneering face she recognized - and worse, Morkan obviously recognized her.

"Dauphin!" he snarled. "It's their girly captain!"

The guards turned in surprise, but at the sight of Morkan drawing his sword and advancing on her they joined him, blades at the ready.

Dauphin cursed inwardly. Pressing her back to the wall, she drew her own weapon and screamed through the mind-link, Delpheus, get over here now!

The guards closed in on her. Without waiting for them, Dauphin lunged forward, beneath one man's guard, to thrust her sword into his gut. He screamed as she ripped the blade out and then there was nothing but chaos. Dauphin dodged a sweep at head height to kick a man heavily in the shin, punch another in the face and decapitate a third. A guard blocked her stroke and she kicked him in the groin before whirling to ram her sword into the rib cage of a man behind her. The sword grated on bone; she tugged harder, trying to free it from the suction of the dead man's flesh.

Swinging the weapon around, it bit into a man's neck, and blood spurted everywhere. Elbowing another man in the ribs, she hooked his feet out from under him but his weight bore her to her knees as he fell towards her. Shoving him aside, she blocked one stroke aimed at her head but was powerless to defect another which crashed down onto her shoulder, splintering her collarbone.

With a wordless howl of agony she thrust her sword upwards into the grinning face of the man above her. Blood showered from his ruined visage as he screamed. Suddenly Dauphin's vision exploded in crimson bursts as a pair of heavy hands tightened around her throat. Choking for breath, her mind growing numb, she pulled her knife from her boot and slashed desperately at her adversary. He roared with the pain and hurled Dauphin from him. Flat on her back a heavy boot drove into her ribs; she tripped the man and they grappled on the ground. His hand forced her head backwards; she bit him till the blood came and hooked at his eyes with the fingers of her uninjured hand.

Injured, half-strangled, Dauphin knew that if help did not come she would die here, in these muddy streets, within a minute. Where, in the name of Faire herself, was Delpheus?
14111.title: Blood in the Streets

141111.content:
The fighting continued even though Dauphin was injured and near death.
Morkan watch from a short distance as she fought for her life.

"boys...boys. leave her be" says Morkan smugly.
The guards back away from Dauphin who has a shattered collarbone and a swollen eye.
"what? are you sissies afraid of getting whipped? huh?"

Morkan approached her.
"foolish Dauphin. you should have taken the long way around. we knew you'd come this way."
Dauphin looked at him.

"how could you have known?"
"because..." Morkan points behind him.
"he told us you would."

She turns, fearing the worst. And it couldn't be worse.
Behind her, standing proud and tall, was Delpheus.

"no...delpheus...."
"yes, dear sister. it's me, much to your surprise. you were always so predictable."

"why..brother?"
"why? dear sister, there is a great and powerful artifact here that i intend to make my own."
"with that, no-one would dare oppose me."

Standing over her, her brother and Morkan laughed.
"i'll get...you..for this...."
"oh, i don't think so....Morkan, i'm going on ahead. you stay here and finish things here. Can you handle that?"

"Don't worry about things here....i can handle her."
"I hope so..."

Delpheus heads further into town as Morkan and his servants advance close to Dauphin.
141111.title: no way

choices: Ask Seth about what they are
141112.content:
Dauphin groaned, trying to get up. A sudden pain in her collarbone made her gasp loudly in agony and drop to the thin blankets. The sounds of running footsteps approached and the door opened. "Oh! Are you okay? Do you hurt?" A female voice said, and Dauphin looked to see a blue-haired girl standing beside the makeshift bed, holding a cup of what she presumed was tea. The weird thing about the girl was her ears. They were about eight inches long, ended in a point, and went down wards. Her eyes were a clear blue, and she wore a crimson headband. "I hurt... my collarbone... where am I?" Dauphin said hoarsely.

"My name is Haruka, and you are in my house. I'm sorry about the mess. Here, I made the tea for when you woke up. It has some pain-relief herbs. They might not make it better, but they'll take the pain away for a while." The girl, Haruka, said softly, before placing the teacup next to Dauphin and grabbing a few flat pillows, propping them up behind her so she could drink easily. She forced the teacup into her hands and said, "I am really truly sorry..."

Dauphin quirked an eyebrow. 'What was she sorry for?' she thought, and Haruka, as if seeing the question in her eyes, said softly, "Your brother is dead. My sister, one of the royal army soldiers, set up a magic barrier. His wings were destroyed and he plummeted. I couldn't save him." Haruka looked down sadly at that, and Dauphin would of started to cry, but she saw another person walk into the room.

"Haru~! You have to go and play your victory songs~!" A masculine, but still slightly feminine, voice sang. Dauphin looked over at him. He had long emerald green hair, and ears like Haruka's. He wore, strangely, a white dress.

"Ah! I almost forgot! Oh, this is Seth! He'll look after you when I am gone, okay?" Haruka said and didn't wait for an answer. She was gathering up papers from a rickety old drawer and rushing out of the room.
141112.title: Haruka and Seth, the derines

14112.content:
There was nothing Dauphin would rather do than head straight to the castle. However, with the number of imperial guard heading their way, Dauphin reluctantly admitted to herself that a more roundabout path would actually be faster.

Moving along a series of city streets that ran parallel to the castle, Dauphin let herself move some distance away from the forces now led by her twin brother before heading straight to the castle. Upon reaching the grounds of the castle proper, she found an entrance to the castle...
14112.title: A direct line not necessarily the shortest distanc

choices: Something happens before you can separate
1412.content:
"You have always been the warrior, I the bringer of peace. I shall go towards the castle and try and make a truce with these people's leader," Delpheus responded.

"You are sure?"

"Can you imagine me trying to fight the imperial guard? No, that job is much better suited to you."

"Pick whoever you need to go with you," Dauphin replied, her mind already on the upcoming fight rather than her brother's actions.
1412.title: Delpheus the peace maker

choices: does Dauphin find her dragon's charm in her tunic
or has she left it back at the camp?
14122.content:
Dauphin and Delpheus then were met with a group of men escorting a strange animal out of the castle's inner gates. Its leathery wings beat the wind as billows of smoke rose through its nostrils.

"It's a dragon," cried Dauphin.

"I think it is too late to make peace," said Delpheus.

Them dragon was propped up on a wooden cart with chains around its neck and body.

"Surrender or die," cried the castle guards.

Dauphin and Delpheus looked at one another and began to tremble.

"Where is your dragon's charm?" asked Delpheus.
14122.title: Dragon's Charm

choices: The king sends a messenger to inform Dauphin of the fate of the outlaws
141221.content:
"Oh My God" exclaimed Dauphin. "I forgot my Dragon charm."

"Well this is a fine mess you got us into," replied her brother while unsheathing his sword.

"I must send Fire, my Hawkin, to the camp, retrieve it and bring it back or all is lost. In the meantime we will have to maintain a holding action. Luckily, Fire can teleport after retrieving the picture from my mind of where I left the charm."

With that, Dauphin flung her Hawkin in the air and he disappeared with a pop from air displacement. It seemed like hours but was only minutes until Fire returned with her charm. She held it up, facing the dragon and moved toward him while a beam of blue light emitted from the charm. The charm usually looked like a cloak brooch of copper and pewter, until it was called upon by the chosen one to use its power and then it could cut down any dragon no matter the size or power that dragon held.

Dauphin advanced steadily toward the dragon and the blue beam touched him. There was a loud bellow and a hole was burnt into his hide. He took one look at what was happening and retired from the field, springing into the air and flying toward the west.

When the enemy camp saw the power of the brooch they turned around and ran back to the keep behind the protection of the walls. For the first time they wondered if they would be able to survive this conflict. The outlaws from the keep who had razed Dauphin's village had been executed but no message had been able to get through to let Dauphin know that justice had been carried out. Somehow, they would have to inform her before it was too late.
141221.title: Dragon Charm

choices: go inside and talk with the king
1412212.content:
Dauphin stood before the keeps gate and shouted to the occupants inside.
" I know you are in there. your keep houses the men who murdered my village. I'm here to get even."

Some of the guards bring the message to the king.
"what? is she refering to the outlaws we executed last month? someone has to tell her! get a messenger out there..now!"
Dauphin redies her attack on the keep when Delpheus stops her.

"Dauphin...maybe we should wait. They could either have information for us..or it could be a trap.

Dauphin grimaced and rubbed her temples. "I know it was foolish, brother, but please do not lecture. The pain in my head is punishment enough, believe me."

The frown slowly faded from Delpheus' handsome features. His sister took far too many such chances and he knew that someday soon the risks would prove too much, even for her. He sighed.

"See what it is you have wrought, sister, in your gamble with a dragon."

Now that the king was dead, it was time to retake what had been theirs. With a roar, the rebels with Dauphin in the lead ran up to the gate and by sheer numbers splintered it in pieces. Dauphin surveyed the castle and grounds and notice an alcove covered in body guards. She lept through the melee and climbed the castle stairs that lead to the alcove. The body guards came after her, but her brother had followed behind her and was covering her back. Between the two of them, they dispatched all in their way. They then pushed through the alcove into the room behind it and saw a young man standing at a table with maps and charts. He had a scowl on his face and his sword was drawn. Delpheus watched his sister. She was a fine warrior, no one could deny that. But whereas she had the charisma, the power to lead and the strength he had other skills. Delpheus looked at her back, so strong and proud on Vrexx. Dauphin was his sister and he adored her, but the killing had to stop.

Dauphin awoke to the cool of her bedroom. For a moment she was completely disorientated - what was she doing back here? Or had everything just been a terrible dream....

Things being a dream seemed rather unlikely now, and it was time to find Delpheus for some answers. As she walked along the landing however, she could hear murmured voices from the bottom of the stairs.

Peering in quietly from the doorway, Dauphin saw that her sibling was nowhere in sight and thus she heaved a sigh. Where was Dauphin's brother? She thought there might be one to the left so starting to trek over bodies was her only option. She held a hand to her side, too scared to pull the arrow out and let more blood pour.

Eventually, Dauphin made her way to a shedlike home. She banged on the door as hard as her weakened fists could manage until, finally, someone cracked the door. A pair of eyes peered from the slight opening and widened at the sight of the girl.

The person yanked the door open further and pulled Dauphin through onto the floor. Dauphin collapsed and closed her eyes, only to hear the conversation above her.

Whilst Dauphin commanded armies, all he could do was plot.

Needless to say the real attackers had been mercenaries employed by him, paid also to leave clues pointing to here. Whereas Dauphin would never relinquish power willingly, if she discovered she had authorised the slaughter of thousands of innocents, her honour would not allow her to rule still. And so her successor, her brother, would gain power and the added bonus of an additional kingdom won in the war. Not bad for a day's work!

It was a perfect plan as he had always been openly against the idea of attacking the land to Dauphin's face. Now all he had to do was lead her to the conclusion that her actions had been evil....

Dauphin gave a short, curt nod of agreement at Delpheus' suggestion. She had to give her brother credit for this: though he had stated his objections to invading this kingdom prior to her launching the retaliatory attack, he had given her his unwavering support once the war was launched.

The majority of her troops Dauphin sent to subdue and secure the city. The elite core of her forces, however, she led to take over the castle proper, not knowing she was moving to bring her brother's plans to fruitions.

Dauphin carefully unrolled the paper message. The words she read sent tears streaming down her cheeks. Her head was pounding. Her heart was bursting. Could her own brother, Delpheus, have had advanced knowledge regarding the invasion of her beloved land? Was he plotting to overthrow her; to gain authority over her people, her country?

She should have seen the clues. Delpheus' top aide, Hans Ruper, had been spotted days earlier at a secret meeting with the men that were captured. Her scout told her it was no coincidence. Was Hans Ruper selling arms to the men that were now being held captive? Had her own brother been training these men to invade her country? Is that why he was away during the massive attack?

145.content:
The armies were efficent, leaving no survivors in their wake. Like a tsunami they washed away all the evil, cleansing the land. Bodies of children lay like broken dolls, their dead frames tossed into large pits like limp rags.

The resistance these savages brought was laughable. Two guards were easily killed off. An army that had no magic, nor steel. Dauphin disarmed their greatest magician with just one word. His flesh dripped off his bone like water from a gutter, leaving nothing but gray ash.

Delpheus, her twin brother, had proved to be less vital than she believed. He had saved a few of the wretches and claimed to be keeping them for questionning. Delpheus believed that it had been too easy, that these savages should have put up more of a fight.

Bah! It defied the logic of the savage. They knew nothing but blood lust. And to teach civilization was futile, to a race that wiped out Dauphin´s mother and father while she hid under the wooden cot.

Dauphin sat on the white throne, and eased her fingers over the chair. She looked around the palace, and was impressed by its beauty. Pink flower petals decoarted the concrete white wall, with green yellow vines reaching for the stars. A skylight was at the center of the roof, basking the palace in honeycomb rays.

"Well perhaps the savages stole this land from a civilized people," she thought.

Immersed in her thoughts, she did not realize a man had stepped out of the shadows. He was dressed in a black cloak, and wore a grey wool sweater, and brown birch pants.

His hands held two silver swords.

She screamed for her guard but no voice escaped her. Choking back horror, for she couldn't cast a spell without her voice, she grabbed her sword and rushed at the intruder.

His golden eyes looked at her questioninggly, and he raised his gloved hand.

She found she could not move. Her arms were frozen outwards, her legs cold as ice.

When he came closer, she found herself trembling with fear. Sweat dripped down like rain from her forehead. She was deathly afraid.

She had not been afraid since her parents´ death.

His lips went to her ear, and whispered, "You have committed great evil my lady. You have killed children, and old men and women in the name of your parents. So many have died for you mad anger."

She said nothing, for she knew it was all in the name of vengeance, regardless of what this sorcerer had to say.

He continued on, "And I could kill you right now. I could cut you down, and free your spirit to whatever hell it is destined to be in."

The killing blow did not come. But though she felt fear in the rawest form, she did not repent. How could she when the blood of her parents dripped down on her nose that fateful night, while she stifled screams of pain?

"Instead you shall understand your ways in a way no mortal has before."
