152.content:
The guards let the pair pass without incident. Pleased, the faelan could barely contain his excitement. It took a great deal of effort to keep up the act of a faithful mount. The humans' blind trust was laughable. They considered the faelan beautiful and harmless. They would never learn to see beyond surface appearances. That short-sightedness would be their downfall.

"Come, Starmane, we must hurry. The war is coming," the human muttered.

Of course, the faelan -- whose name was Khar'rith, not Starmane -- knew this. In fact, the stupid female was the one who would allow that war to come. She had just unwittedly walked these people's doom through their front gates.

She believed that she had valuable knowledge. And she did, actually.

The female was a mage of some small skill who had taken it upon herself to scout out the enemy. When she had come across Khar'rith, caught in one of Cardac's traps, she had rescued him. He had then allowed her to ride him. Under the cover of darkness, he took her into the air and to Cardac's castle. There she had discovered the lord's plan to smuggle a weapon into the city; a weapon that could collapse the magic barrier surrounding it.

What she did not know, was that the Khar'rith was that weapon. He had purposely waited, only pretending to be trapped, for her to rescue him. He then took her to the castle. The guards -- magical creatures that even Khar'rith was wary of -- had purposely ignored her as she crept through, and had informed Cardac when she was in position to overhear him. And then she, the fool that she was, had made best speed back to warn this city of their danger, bringing with her the very doom she was trying to avoid.

It was so beautifully planned, so treacherous. Khar'rith loved it.

He trailed behind the idiot female as she hurried down the street. So confident in his loyalty, it never occurred to her to watch him. As they passed an alley, Khar'rith jumped into it. Hopefully the female wouldn't notice his absence for awhile.

He hurried down the alley, wanting to put distance between him and his former companion. He cursed the rain, for it kept him earthbound.
152.title: The Weapon

choices: Dauphin heads for the palace anyway
1521.content:
Dauphin cursed herself for the thousandth time. How could she have lost Starmane only a few miles into the city? With a fantastic winged steed she looked aristocratic and impressive, without it she looked just what she was: a lowly peasant girl. Who would ever believe her story now?

"Starmane!" she called out once again, hoping desperately for some sign the faelan was near.

"Hush! It is night, people are trying to sleep," a stern voice instructed her.

Dauphin turned to see a middle aged man in a night shirt looking disapprovingly at her. Even this could not put her off her task however.

"I'm looking for Starmane... erm... she's a faelan... sort of like a horse with wings," Dauphin explained hurriedly. "You haven't seen one, have you?"

"Only faelans I've ever seen were in opposing armies, working for Cardac," the man replied dismissively. "Get along with you."
1521.title: Lost

choices: He is followed by his ex-companion
He is followed by the town guard
1522.content:
Khar'rith trotted down the alley. Hoping the rain would muffle the sounds of his hooves, he hurried on. He had some magic that would keep casual onlookers from noticing him. If they didn't expect to see him -- and humans never expected a faelan in their midst -- it was easy to use his illusionary skills to mask his presense. However, the magic could not hide any noises he made. So Khar'rith only moved as quickly as he thought he could, while still remaining relatively quiet.

As he passed through one alley and into the next, he wondered how the humans could live with their own stench. It filled his nostrils, almost choking him. He looked forward to watching all the humans die, even the great Cardac.

Oh, Cardac thought he was clever, enlisting the aid of Khar'rith's master. Cardac wanted to destroy this city. Fine, the city would perish. Then, when those humans were slaughtered and there was no one who might come to their aid, it would be Cardac's turn. If Khar'rith was lucky, perhaps he could kill Cardac. After all, the Dragon rewarded his faithful servants.

With those pleasant thoughts in his head, Khar'rith continued on. Then he realized something that caused him to slow his pace.

He was being followed.
1522.title: Khar'rith's True Agenda

choices: The faelan has other plans first
15221.content:
He had almost forgotten her. Of course, she considered it her job to see him safely to the King. Yet she was such a non-entity that he kept forgetting her existence, essential as she was to the current plan.

Sighing as only a faelan can, he slowed his pace and let her catch up with him. It would not be helpful for her to think he had a mind of his own, after all.
15221.title: Together, like it or not

choices: They take him to the stables
They search for his former rider
15222.content:
Khar'rith cursed his luck. It would do him no good to be seen as able to travel independent of his rider: he could not show that much intelligence this early on. Better for them to think he had become separated somehow and was wandering aimlessly in the dark.

He slowed his pace and allowed them to capture him. Fools! Did they honestly think mere ropes could bind him? Well yes, in their stupidity clearly they did.

The question was what would they do with him now? Faelans were expensive creatures, so he was quite a prize to be found on the empty streets at night.
15222.title: Not all is as it seems

choices: The family is waylaid by burglers
They make it safely to the house
152221.content:
Khar'rith soon found himself in a rather large stable that appeared to be inhabited by many other animals of diverse sorts. A marketeer's stable, he thought. A few costumers walked by at intermittent times. They looked upon the faelan with awestruck eyes, a look that quickly faded to disappointment as they realized they could never afford such a beautiful and mysterious creature. This, of course, brought smug satisfaction to Khar'rith.

The rhythm of awed and disappointed customers became almost predictable to the faelan. He was ready almost to destroy the ridiculous stable and run, hoping to find cover in order to conceal himself. C onceal himself with that magical Art that all faelans are taught by their parents, who in turn learned it from theirs, who learned it from theirs, and so on, back to untraceable roots. Legend had it the Art was taught to the first created faelan by one of the gods themselves. But Khar'rith hated the gods, and so did all faelans he knew. No, not a god. It must have been one of the Fallen. The great and mighty Nethergods. The first faelan must have been created by one of them as his worthy steed, Khar'rith mused. In fact, it was once said that -

"That one, Mum! He's so pretty!" Khar'rith first shuddered about being described by such a detestable term. After he gathered himself, he finally assessed his situation. He was being picked for purchase. No matter - it was a small boy, barely ten winters. His parents were about to grab his hand and lead him away, saying "Maybe something else, sweetheart." But to the faelan's surprise, they did not.

"Are you sure, son? Yes, he is beautiful!" Khar'rith shuddered again. Please not them, he prayed to whatever force moved these disgusting people. They were dressed much better than any of the other humans he had seen. And they were clean, surprisingly clean. Rich, he thought. And therefore able to afford a market-priced faelan. But the stench of righteousness oozed from their pores.

The parents made their way to the market clerk, but the boy stayed behind. Khar'rith tried his best to pretend he didn't notice the boy standing there, staring up at him with that stupid smile.

"My dad said you're a faelan." Idiot child who would talk to an animal that wasn't even paying attention, much worse that was expected to not even understand human speech. With a bite of cold irony, Khar'rith realized he was, and could. Either the boy was incredibly stupid, or staggeringly intelligent. He was human, so it must be the former.

"I've heard stories about you. Um... your kind, I mean. I want to name you, since you're going to be mine now." Great, the faelan thought. Not another confounded human name. Horsey Worsey, he thought to himself, and chuckled at his own wit.

"I'll name you Khar'rith. I read about a faelan named that once."

Khar'rith stumbled visibly backward, and almost fell to the ground. The boy giggled. Yes! Yes, his name had been taken from the steed who assisted Galfalad, the greatest of human kings. It was a common name for a faelan, however. But still, he was awestruck. His heart began to warm to this boy, who had actually called him by his real name. But he suddenly noticed this warming, and quickly hardened his heart once again. Stupid human. Yes, stupid. That's what he was.

The parents returned. They led the faelan away out of the congestion of the inner city and up to the hills.
152221.title: The Boy and the Faelan

choices: mentally struck back at the shadowy figure
resigned itself to being imprisoned...for now
153.content:
The faelan watched with equal amounts of disgust and disinterest as its rider walked back to it. Suddenly, its rider froze in place, surrounded by a cold blue fire that lit up her features even in this storm. A trap! The faelan's first instinct was to leap into flight, but it found itself surrounded by the same cold blue aura. It heard a chuckle inside its head.

*Not all of us judge by appearances, faelan.* The faelan looked around and saw a shadowy figure behind the guards. That was the source of the blue fire and thoughts. The faelan...
153.title: Not all that glitters is gold

choices: She is taken to the prison
1531.content:
With all of its powers, the faelan sent a blow back at its unknown assailant, temporarily interrupting the blue forcefield. That was enough. With just a few beats of his powerful wings, the faelan was up and out of there, rushing back to tell Cardac of this unexpected development.

The girl, on the other hand, could not fly, so was left standing in place, completely confused as to what was going on.

"Send her for interrogation," the shadowy figure decreed.

"Wait!"
1531.title: One down, one to go

choices: a mental trap set by the faelan!
the girl was an unwitting spy planted against the faelan
15311.content:
"I...I know something. I don't know what, but I was instructed that if I ever got away from the faelan, I was to look for a Seeker. One who could delve into my mind."

"Convenient enough," said the shadowy figure. "You find yourself in the presence of a member of the Society of Seekers. But how was it the faelan didn't know of your instructions? They are masters of the unseen as well."

"The instructions to find a Seeker were implanted deep into my mind, and would only come to the surface if I was separated from the faelan... as I am now. Otherwise, I would forget the instructions in his presence."

"Plausbile," muttered the seeker. "Barely so, but still..."

The Seeker reached out his mind into that of the rider, sifting through the layers of her thoughts until he discovered...
15311.title: Hidden instructions

choices: the attack on the city began!
153111.content:
The Seeker tried to mentally "backpeddle", but it was too late: he set off the trap in the girl's mind. It was if a great onrushing fire consumed the seeker's brain, leaving him an empty shell of himself.

Overhead, the other seekers in the city could hear the faint mental laugh of the faelan as...
153111.title: Sprung!

15312.content:
As the guards took the faelan's rider to the prison, the shadowy figure let his gaze follow the escaping faelan. With a barely audible sigh, the shadowy figure followed the guards and the girl. Perhaps, the shadowy figure thought, the rider might serve some use yet.

At this point, gentle reader, shall our narrative follow the shadowy figure or the fleeing faelan?
15312.title: The escape or the interrogation?

153121.content:
the shadow figure accompanied the girl down to the deepest part of the dungeon.
when they reached their destination, she looked around in horror.

many various types of torture instruments lie around the room. ones that break bones, ones that sear the flesh, ones that even specialize in destroying one's mental capacity.
" why am i here?"
" i need to know what the faelan is up to....i believe you know."

" my animal? what makes you think it's plotting something? it's a animal..a pet!"
" foolish child! Faelans are fallen creatures...they only look pure of heart! All they strive for is chaos and destruction."

"strap her in!"
Three guards strap her in the nearest device.

"this is your last chance. Tell me what i want to know....or i will make sure you regret it."
The girl remains silent.
"very well. Torture her until she talks, but make sure she doesn't die. i have no use for her dead."

"yes sir!"
as the door is closed, her agonizing screams can be heard over the nearby countryside.
153121.title: the truth

choices: it is being magically watched by the shadowy figure
is being followed by an invisible spy
153122.content: As the faelan flies back to Cardac...
153122.title: Returning to Cardac

choices: The faelon is hit by the storm bolt and dies
The faelon dodges at the very last second
1531221.content:
Up ahead the faelan saw the scantly illuminated balcony of the Dark Tower of Cardac. Swooping from the darkness, the faelan landed upon high balcony, trotting to a halt.

"What did you do with the girl?" Spoke a droning voice from the shadows. The faelan jerked its head toward the wretched voice. There, painted in the shadows, were the glowing purple eyes of Draygor, the secret puppeteer ruler of Cardac. He stalked out of the shadows, wearing a crimson cloak and wielding a shaman-staff.

"She is captured." The faelan spoke telekinetically, for it didn't have the vocal-cords to speak in human tongue.

"Good... the plan was a success then. Though that means I have no more use of you, foolish cow!" Draygor rose his shaman-staff, crested with storm jewels, and summoned from the air a purple whirling storm. With a flick of his staff, the storm bolt blazed directly at the faelan.

The faelan's eyes widened in fear.
1531221.title: Faelan meets Draygor

choices: The girl decides to rescue her steed
The girl tries to find out what is going on
1532.content:
The girl watched in confusion as her faelan was led away. As she was trapped still in the cold blue fire, there was nothing she could do to help it. Rage bubbled inside her, mainly at herself for being so helpless.

"She knows nothing. Leave her," the shadowy figure instrcuted, vanishing as quickly as it had come.

"But... but what about my faelan?" she demanded.

"They'll take it for interrogation at the central prison," a guard explained.
1532.title: Confusion

choices: Find the King and plead your case
15321.content:
"But it's innocent," she insisted, but there was no point. The guard had stopped listening, losing interest in her as a completely insignificant being. So insignificant she was being allowed inside the city gates without the slightest inquiry into her business.

Which was of course now to find her steed. And make someone pay for its disappearance.
15321.title: Inside the gates

choices: sighed and waited to be escorted into captivity.
15322.content:
"But... but you said we could enter! That is MY faelan! What are you going to do with it?"

The shadowy figure had already made the necessary arcane arrangements to prevent the faelan's escape. It may have looked like a mere exotic brute, but it was definitely one of the enemy's more dangerous minions. The shadowy figure would not be surprised if this particular faelan was one of the chief lieutenants of the forces aligned against the city and its allies.

The guards were about to escort the girl away when the shadowy figure raised a hand. "Wait. The girl is innocent of wrongdoing, yet I would not be surprised if she does not unknowingly possess information that is vital to the defense of the city. Take her along as well, but be sure to keep her well apart from the faelan."

The girl was not sure what was going on, but the pronouncements of her fate by the shadowy figure didn't sound good at all. As the guards approached her, she...
15322.title: Second thoughts

choices: a quiet room resting on a soft bed
153221.content:
The girl panicked as the guards approached her. She looked around wildly for some way out, but none presented itself easily to her mind. Finally, she just ran blindly, heading for a door she hoped would open. Before she could move two steps, however, she was again surrounded by the cold blue flames. This time, though, they were most intense. She found herself falling in a well of darkness....

When the girl came to, she found herself in...
153221.title: Nowhere to run

choices: He was met by his brother, the king
He has a vision of the faelin mind controlling the royal guards
1532212.content:
When the girl came to, shefound herself in a quiet room resting on a soft bed. The room itself was quite luxorious. Several beatiful paintings of animals and royalty adorned the walls. The girl tried to move, but was overcome with a nasty migrane.

She then saw the same hooded figure from before. The figure took off his hood and sighed. The figure was a young man around her age with jet black hair and ice blue eyes.

"You're awake. You were under that faelin's mind control," the young man said.

"Who are you?" the girl asked.

The young man walked towards her. "I am Prince Jerome and you are?"

"Theodora Navera," the girl replied.

Theodora tried to sit up, but felt too weak to move. Jerome then placed his palm on her forehead.

"Seems like you have a bit of a fever. I'll go get some medicine. Get some rest. My older brother has sent a butler to get you some soup. I'll be back in a moment."

Jerome exited the room as Theodora fell back asleep. On his way to his medical lab...
1532212.title: a quiet room resting on a soft bed

choices: Jerome finds a potion in his lab
The king checks on Theodora before meeting with the nobles
15322121.content:
On his way to his medical lab he was met by a heavily muscled young man with fiery red hair and emerald green eyes. The man was wearing armor with a lion's face painted on the crest.

"Greetings dear brother. How is the girl that you rescued?" The man asked.

Jerome bowed and sighed. "She's resting my king. I was on my way to my lab to get some medicine for her fever."

Jerome's brother looked at Jerome with concern. Fevers in these parts were among the worst. Unlike other regions, the Kingdom of Leoshire was proned to magically induced fevers. If left untreated the ill would die a silent death.

"Please cure her as soon as possible. We have to find out more about that faelin. If it's from Cardac then it would prove Natilda's visions true. The last thing we want is to be enslaved by faelins."

"As you wish, brother," Jerome said.

Jeromed bowed before his brother and continued to walk to his lab.
15322121.title: His brother, the king

153222.content:
The girl (whose name we shall eventually learn is Kaitlin) thought about attempting to elude capture, but where could she go? What could she do?

With a sigh, she followed the guards until they led her to a small, empty but clean cell. For three days, save for being given food and water, she was ignored. On the third day, however, she received a visitor: a member of the entourage of...
153222.title: Waiting patiently in prison

1532221.content:
Kaitlin looked up as the door to her cell was opened. It was the usual guard who came in to bring her food and water twice a day, as well as remove the bucket she used for her personal needs. The guard was always gruff but not unkind. When he came in today, though, he seemed very nervous. Kaitlin watched him silently, but before he left, he turned to her.

"Listen, girl, from what I understand, you're an innocent in all this, so I'll give you a word of advice. You're about to have a visitor within the hour. For your own sake, I'd advise you to give this visitor any answer they ask for as quickly as you can."

Kaitlin was a bit taken aback by this warning. Until now, her guard hadn't said more than ten words to her for the entirety of her time in this cell. "Who... who is this visitor?"

"He calls himself Captain Wynan. That's not important, though. The important thing is that this Captain Wynan works for..."
1532221.title: A visitor from...

choices: set a trap for the Enemy
15322211.content:
The way the guard had pronounced the word her caused a cold fear to settle in Kaitlin's stomach.

"Her?" Kaitlin managed to squeak.

Before the guard could answer, a large man entered the cell. With a single look, the guard went scurrying away, closing the cell door behind Kaitlin and the newcomer. The newcomer was a large man, easily six and a half feet, with shoulders that seemed almost abnormally broad. He wore a dark cloak over equally dark studded leather. His head was bare, revealing short dark hair, rough features, a closely cropped beard and dark, impenetrable eyes.

"I am Captain Wynan and my mistress has a proposal for you. It shall mean the difference between clemency and imprisonment."

Before Kaitlin could speak, the captain cut her off with a slicing gesture of his hand.

"The creature you rode into this city is called a faelan, one of the most diabolical servants of the enemy that we face. My mistress has determined that you were an unwitting dupe of this creature, and thus are innocent in the machinations it had planned to put into place if it had entered our city unchecked."

Kaitlin was set aback by this revelation. It was an unflattering description of herself, and somewhat bereft of details, but at least whatever the "powers that be" in this city were, they weren't holding her responsible for the mischief she almost helped set loose on the city. Still, it gave her a sombre pause.

"However, having captured the faelan, my mistress now needs your cooperation to..."
15322211.title: A chance to make amends

choices: a young man in dark leather
a young woman in plain but expensive traveling clothes
1532222.content:
Kaitlin looked up in resignation as the door opened. Resignation turned to surprise as two guards, wearing the garb of Royal Guardsman, stepped into the room. They walked around the room silently, examining everything, including Kaitlin. Kaitlin watched in quiet curiousity. Finally, one of the guards ducked out of the room while the other stayed by the door at parade rest.

The second guard re-entered the room, accompanied by
1532222.title: the royal family

choices: The rider decides to rest for the night
The rider makes her way towards the palace
154.content:
Many thought that Cardac was human, a common mistake. Mankind were too blind to accept that the strongest army around was commanded by anyone other than one of them, their vanity making them weak to the legions of non-human spies and informants working for Cardac. Aeldwyn, the faelan, was one of these, but his purpose was much more sinister than simple information. His job was to infiltrate the very heart of the city and kill the figure head that ruled there, the King.

Faelans were notoriously rare and unlikely to escape the King's attention. The rider had been mislead to believe she was to give the horse as a gift to the ruler, one any man would find hard to turn down. Then Aeldwyn could return to his true form and destroy the King, demoralising the people of the city and making them lambs before the slaughter. Cardac's armies were mere hours away, ready to strike on the signal for Aeldwyn and, in the confusion that followed the King's death, victory would be easy.
154.title: Dark and sinister plans

choices: She finds the inn and rests
1541.content: It was far too late for Dauphin, the rider, to even consider asking for an audience with the King. Besides which, she had never been to this city before! Sure, they had told her to take the animal straight to the King, but even her master couldn't have meant in the middle of the night when she wasn't properly cleaned up and dressed. No, what she needed was a decent inn, followed by every girl's favourite activity... shopping. She had heard the young King was still single and, like any impressionable female, had fantasies that with a decent dress, a hat and an expensive present she might just be the one to catch his eye. There must be a half decent milliners around here.
1541.title: Not quite to plan

choices: The faelan is safe and well
15411.content:
The inn was rundown, but cheap. Plus it was still serving at this time of night. Dauphin was aware that her finances were low, especially if she wanted to go on a shopping spree in the morning, so chose the cheapest room available, directly above the noisy bar. Nonetheless she slept well, exhaustion taking its toll.

In the morning, after a good breakfast, she decided to check on her faelan and head straight to the shops.
15411.title: A good night's sleep

choices: Give up and head to the shops
154111.content:
Unfortunately this did not prove as simple as she had hoped. The animal had gone!

"Where is my faelan?" she demanded of an unfortunate nearby stablehand.

"Why, your master picked him up this morning!"

"I have no master," Dauphin replied coldly. Well, she didn't have one here anyway. Someone had clearly conned the staff into believing the faelan belonged to him, and she was a mere underling.

In a city full of people, how was she ever going to find her steed again?
154111.title: Gone!

choices: Presume he is hiding something and press for more
Go out and search for anyone who might have seen the faelan
1541111.content:
"Describe this man. Have you ever seen him before?" she pressed urgently. If this fool could not give a description surely someone would have noticed the faelan, it was pretty memorable after all.

"He was tall. Well dressed."

"And...? What colour was his hair, his eyes? How tall? What exactly was he wearing?"

"Dark. Dark clothes, dark hair, dark eyes... some sort of a cloak."

It could have been almost anyone in the city!
1541111.title: The faelan thief

15411111.content:
"So let me get this right," she asserted, the frustration in her quickly boiling over into anger, "you let my faelan leave this pithy little stable with some Mr. Dark Anybody dressed in mysterious dark clothing?!"

The man looked puzzled. "W-well, young lass, I can hardly recall the specific order of things; all I can seem to remember is seeing the dark man approach me and then the next thing I knew he was gone-and so was your pretty steed!"

"Your telling me you don't have any recollection of what happened, is that it?" The story didn't fly, and yet something about the man's demeanor bothered Dauphin.

"Y-yes, my young lass. It was almost as if I had been-"

"Enchanted..." Dauphin muttered.

It was the one thing, aside from getting to the King, she had been explicitly told not to do, which was run into any of the Dark Cloaked Beings; they, she had been told, were of the Enemy, and would do anything in their mysterious and magical power-which was immense, as it was their life's force-to capture any and all faelans, and especially hers. She dreaded facing one, for they had nothing to lose but life.

"Yes, enchanted I suppose. I'm sorry, that is all I know."

"Thank you," she said, but was already racing out the stable door. She had to find the faelan!

Suddenly she heard a muffled thump behind her, and after quickly jumping beside some carts, glanced back.

There, on the floor, right where she had left him, was the stablehand... dead.

"No way..." stammered Dauphin. Fear held her stiff as she quickly thought of her next step.
15411111.title: Enchantment

choices: Dauphin makes a desperate attempt to wield the nearest torch
154111111.content:
Emerging into the cobblestone street, early morning merchants, peddlers and other busy-looking citizens were quickly bustling up and down the increasingly crowded street.

Quickly glancing around for anything suspicious and finding none, Dauphin cursed under her breath, upset at the two-fold fact that her stolen faelan had ruined her mission and her date with Prince Charming - and no shopping!

Think, Dauphin, think! Slowly walking down the street and trying not to look too out of the ordinary, her thoughts slowly started clearing up, easing her racing mind. This dark-cloaked 'master' character couldn't possibly leave the city with it... or could he? He had enchanted - and killed - the stablehand. Suddenly she froze, her blood frozen cold yet again. It wasn't any ordinary thief that stole my faelan, it was one of the Dark Cloaked Beings, and that meant she either was really clumsy in charming her way into the city, or there had been someone spying on her....

"But that would mean-"

Suddenly, something covered her eyes, then her body, and before she could cry for help something hard fell upon her head, and everything went painfully blank.

Her head ached horribly. All was dark around her, but she felt unbound, no longer covered by whatever it was that had fallen over her. Where am I?

"Hello?" she yelled, hoping for an answer.

"Well then, I am glad you have finally come around." The voice was low, crisp and... familiar.

"Zephoras... what are you doing?" She could not see him in the darkness, but his voice sounded directly behind her, and as if they were in some sort of enclosed room.

"We-" He stopped short and seemed to chuckle as he rephrased. "-I mean to say, I... am very disappointed in your failure to deliver the gift."

"I am sorry for my failure, your worthiness," she formally replied. She noticed she was held bound, immobile, by some force.

"Do you remember the terms of our... agreement?"

"I do." She swallowed hard. She had failed and now she had to pay the ultimate price.

Now his voice came directly into her ear, almost in a whisper, his hot breath brushing the skin. "It was a pleasure working with you."

"No, no, please!" she pleaded but it was too late.

To her utter amazement - and horror - he began to laugh. It was a sinister, almost inhuman laugh, more of a hysterical cackle, rising higher and higher.

"Kill her, you filth!" he suddenly ordered, and there was a loud clinking, and then everything lit up, and before Dauphin's eyes she beheld a large room, and straight ahead was a great, four-legged beast. Ooze drooled from its disfigured mouth, lined with long sharp teeth, and black, matted hair fell to the cold stone floor all around, which, near the creature, was covered in red blood - the same color as its three bulging eyes directly above the mouth.

"Goodbye," boomed Zephoras' voice, now distant and behind her, and was followed by the same strange... metallic, she realized... clicking sound she had heard earlier.

When the clicking stopped, she felt the binding force release her, and, caught unaware, she fell forward onto her hands and knees.

The creature immediately released an ugly, gurgling roar, and began to cautiously stalk its prey, crawling left and right, gauging Dauphin's weaknesses and reactions.

Dauphin had faced such a creature before, but her heart sank when upon searching her newly-freed body she realized she had been stripped of her weapons and belt.

"Just don't panic," she told herself, glancing around the room. Above there was an iron chandelier, unlit, and fixed upon the three visible walls was a single flaming torch. She sought to look behind her, but she knew all too well it would be a fatal mistake to turn away from the trynzar beast - its reflexes were formidable.

She failed to see the dark figure hiding in the shadows above the chandelier.

Just as they said she would come, she had.

And now... his time had come.

How will YOU decide their fates?
154111111.title: Zephoras and darkness

choices: Suspicious, perhaps you should get answers first.
Dream boy already saved you once!  What're you waiting for?
1541111111.content:
The dark figure could tell she was nervous, and yet skilled somehow - like a great warrioress pushed into a corner, beyond even her own power to escape. He acted quickly.

Reaching beneath his deep blue cloak he produced two long, sharp and unusually plain daggers. With deft stealth and poise he lept from his secret corner into a head-first dive.

Dauphin was exchanging quick glances between the trynzar and a nearby torch when she caught the faint whir of air above, but before she could look a hazy blackness struck the trynzar from above in a red and gory mass, as if the beast had been struck by lightning dark as night.

To her utter amazement there before her was the most handsome of men - well, pretty darn close - and he had just split her near-death experience in two.

"Dauphin," he said, "my name is Edwar, and before you speak, know this: Zephoras is an evil man, and you have been cruelly tricked." With an ugly, wet swishing sound he removed his pair of bloody blades, and then stepped down from the fallen monster.

"Your faelan is well, as my companions have captured him." He rushed behind her, where, as she turned to look, there was at the end of a short hallway a steel door chained shut. "Come with me, I can save you!" he said.
1541111111.title: Edwar's Move

1541111112.content:
It's now or never! With all her strength Dauphin leaps for the torch immediately to her left.

Suddenly an intense burning pain engulfs her entire lower body, and before she could even scream the pain shoots up the remainder of her body, consuming her, and then the chaos that had begun is suddenly no more.

A scream echoes down from above, as the dark figure above realizes he is too late.

"No!!!"
1541111112.title: Trynzar Meat

choices: Go and explain to the palace
15411112.content:
The man was clearly an idiot. Dauphin would have to look for other witnesses on her own.

Impatiently she moved out into the street. "Have you seen a horse with wings?" she asked time and time again, replies always coming back negative. The people on the street changed, they moved on about their business: those who had been here just five minutes ago were different than those around now. In many ways this made it a fruitless task which was driving Dauphin close to tears.

Where would someone take such an expensive creature?
15411112.title: Impossible

154112.content:
"Hello boy," Dauphin said warmly. She really was blessed to be looking after such a magnificent beast. "I'm just going for a... look around the town. Oh, who am I kidding, you can't understand me after all. I'm going," and here she lowered her tone significantly, "Shopping!"

With those words Dauphin skipped out of the stables, leaving her steed alone
154112.title: While the cat is away

15412.content:
Leading the reluctant faelan and lost in thought about meeting the King, she suddenly noticed a shadow fall over the silver puddles before her.

A towering cloaked man stood in front of the inn. When he moved toward her she couldn't help but step back.

"How did you procure such a fine creature?" he said, switching his gaze from the gleaming winged animal to her plain clothes.

She could never afford a beast like a faelan and was only delivering the animal to the King but it wasn't any of his business.

"He was a gift," Dauphin lied quietly, continuing towards the stables, ignoring the man's stares.
15412.title: Cloaked stranger

choices: The girl doesn't notice the royal family
The girl goes to give the faelan to the king
154121.content:
The man continued to stare Dauphin down, but soon enough walked away. He seemingly disappeared into the chilled night air.

Dauphin continued towards an inn that was up the road. A mini-castle in shape, the inn was named, "Ruby Inn." Obviously this was for rich people, as no commoner would name a place with "ruby", a gem no common inn owner could own. There was the whole policy that if you couldn't afford the item, you couldn't use the name of the item, but for our story now that doesn't matter.

Dauphin reached the inn, with her faelan trailing behind wondering what the girl was doing.

"Hello, I'd like a room for the night," Dauphin said reaching a small window where a person sat on the other side, half snoring. Gently Dauphin shook the man and again asked for a room.

"Oh a visitor ah? We don't accept 'em here. They are unwelcome 'ere."

Dauphin looked around. "But you are advertising it's an inn. Are not inns supposed to take in visitors?"

The man gave her a look over, before noticing her faelan, he responded, "Course not. Inns are for the people living 'ere." Just then the faelan squeaked at the sight of the royal family, who happened to be parading down the street.
154121.title: Ruby Inn

1542.content:
Dauphin, the rider, had been told many times by her master not to divert from the task in hand. Thinking herself good, clever and brave she set off towards the palace. Or she would have if she had any sense of direction....

Two hours later, Dauphin had to accept that it might have been useful to ask for directions first. She was in the middle of a seedy looking district and, despite all her brave talk at the gate, she had no idea how to use the sword that sat on her belt. She was a stablehand. True, she had always wanted to be a warrior, but girls just didn't become fighters in her country. The most excitement she would ever get was accompanying this wonderous creature to a foreign King... although she did think it a bit funny she hadn't been given an armed escort.

Hearing a noise behind her, Dauphin quickened the pace she was leading the faelan at.
1542.title: Women and directions

15421.content: Dauphin moved swiftly, but not quickly enough for an arrow. Silently it struck her from behind, sending pain coursing through her body, before unconsciousness took its hold.
15421.title: Ambushed

154211.content:
The faelan was not stupid. It merely stood still, looking docile and unintelligent. Then when the archer came over to capture his prize it attacked swiftly, disabling him within seconds with a well placed kick. It hadn't even needed to use its powers.

The faelan could tell from the rise and fall of her chest that the girl was still alive. This was just as well, she was central to his plan. Mind you, the wound might give the story some credibility as well.

Whinying in disgust, he threw both the girl and the archer across his back and set off.
154211.title: Meek and mild

154212.content:
The faelan watched coldly as the human walked over and roughly grabbed his reins. This was needless to say an inconvenience, but at least this human looked more spirited than the last one. She was useless now she was dead.

He would play obedient for now. Of course, if his new master did not fit the faelan's plans he would not last for long.
154212.title: A new master

1542122.content:
"Hey you. Wake up!"

Dauphin groaned in pain, feeling rough hands push at her. She had been experiencing the most terrible dream: that she had been dragged away from home, lost in a strange city and then shot by an arrow....

"Ouch!" The light burned her eyes as she forced them wearily open. It wasn't a dream. She was sitting, half-propped against a wooden trough, being shaken roughly by a man whose status seemed little higher than her own. So much for a knight in shining armour.

"Leave the girl be, Ingleby. She is conscious now."

Dauphin tried to move to look, causing pain to shoot through her right side.

"I wouldn't do that. You have an arrow in you still," the same voice replied wryly, the speaker moving in front of her as she did so. A gentleman, although shabby in attire, perhaps four or five years older than Dauphin.

"My servant will go and try and find a healer," the man added. "Although I hold little hope. There are thousands of refugees here, many with wounds more serious than yours. We have so little gold left that I can be of no great assistance to you."

The cultured tone and tattered but rich clothes made sense now: this man was a noble, but now a homeless one due to the war. Despite her fatigued, injured state, Dauphin could not help but be overjoyed that someone of such a high status was even talking to her. "I'll be fine," she gasped. "Just help me to my feet."

The look on the man's face showed little faith in her words, so Dauphin moved to do so herself.

She promptly fainted.
1542122.title: New acquaintances

choices: She agrees then tries to sneak out later
15421221.content:
Twitching, Dauphin turned onto her side, jerking her eyes open. The room around her was cast in shadow, but she could make out the rough outline of a woman's back, inches away from where she lay. Groaning, she tried to sit and, to her surprise, shakily succeeded.

"Be careful, that wound isn't fully healed yet."

Startled, she met the cool grey eyes of her saviour from earlier. He was sitting on a low stool, across from where she lay on a makeshift bed on a the floor, little more than a blanket and a some straw. Now she could focus somewhat, Dauphin could see dozens of bodies lining the floors, perhaps fourty in total.

"Where am I?" she asked.

"A refugee centre. There's nowhere else for us to go, no room at any inn unless you possess a small fortune. There are dozens of rooms like this in here."

Dauphin's fingers sought out her side, finding only a rough bandage where the arrow had been.

"Yes, they fixed that as well. They're good people, if a little stretched right now."

"I've got to get out of here," Dauphin realised, her mind flashing back to the unknown assailant and the loss of the faelan. Her master would kill her if she did not get it back.

"You're not going anywhere," the man replied simply.
15421221.title: A brief respite

choices: merely a humble servant following orders
154212211.content:
"I have no choice. The enemy are but two days south of here... less now, no doubt."

Her new found friend waved his hand dimsissively. "It is old news. There is nothing you can do."

"There is," Dauphin insisted. "Before they enter the city they plan to render us leaderless. They plan to kill the King and they have a spy in place to do just that."

"Who?"

"I don't know," Dauphin said hesitantly. "You see, I have not been entirely honest so far. I am in fact..."
154212211.title: Plots in the night

choices: He trusts Dauphin and they set out to find the faelan
He doesn't and reports her to the guard
1542122111.content:
"I am on the run from Cardac myself."

"You?" the man raised one eyebrow, as if to query she was worth the bother.

"Yes, well... I was meant to bring this faelan as a peace offering, leave it at the city gates and return home to my master."

"Your master?"

"Lord Akain."

"He is loyal to Cardac."

"I know," replied Dauphin. "But I am not. I saw this as my chance to escape and have no desire to return. I entered the city under the guise of a refugee, but still felt obliged to hand over the creature. It was not mine after all."

"And how am I meant to trust you, after all this?"

"You just must."
1542122111.title: A question of trust

choices: They go back to the site of the struggle
They go in the direction of the palace
1542122112.content:
"I am a woman of no real rank. A servant, in fact. I was tasked with delivering two things to the King: a tame faelan and a written warning from my master, which I stored in its saddlebags." Dauphin's breath caught in her throat in memory of what had occured before. "Once within the walls I was attacked and the faelan taken from me. I must find him - and the letter!"

"And just how do you expect to do that with your injuries?"

"I don't know, but if I don't find that faelan in two days I won't be alive to worry about it!"
1542122112.title: A servant on a mission

choices: The new creature offers its help
15422.content:
Unfortunately for both girl and beast, she promptly tripped over a wonky cobblestone. It had been hours since Dauphin had last slept, but all the same the faelan was getting close to killing her and trying to make his way to the palace on his own.

"Hey, are you okay?"

Dauphin looked up into clear brown eyes. She noticed the eyes first because instead of two, there was six of them. The rest of this creature's appearance was no less unusual - it was less than half her height and covered all over with thick black hair. All the same she was at a point where nothing could surprise her, and its enquiry had seemed friendly enough.

"No, not really. I'm tired, hungry and can't find the palace where I'm meant to take this bloody creature I have been leading around all day." And with that she promptly burst into tears.
15422.title: Have a nice trip

choices: Chariq leads them to the palace
Chariq leads them to his house
154221.content:
"Here, follow me," the creature replied awkwardly. "My name is Chariq, by the way. I'd offer a handkerchief but I don't have a nose so it's a bit useless for me to carry one."

As she was tired, wet and emotional, Dauphin followed without question. The faelan tried to calculate whether this new creature had more intelligence than its rider, but realised that, although stupid, at least the human had been visually attractive to strangers. Nonetheless, at least this creature was leading purposefully, instead of blubbing helplessly.
154221.title: A new friend

choices: The boy makes himself known to the giant
Chariq and Dauphin fight the giant
1542211.content:
Chariq led Dauphin and her faelan through town, spiraling through the dark alleyways until they finally reached the village square. The palace loomed over all other buildings, resting on four large pillars.

The faelan was deeply contented. Everything was going to plan. It could hardly wait to see the horror on the king's face when it shape-shifted to its true form.

Then suddenly a humming whine filled its ears. It whinnied and frothed in pain and then, suddenly, felt its own flesh vibrating. Magical disturbances coming from somewhere nearby were causing it to revert to its true form.

Abruptly, it stood up on two legs. Its hooves became long silvery claws, its velvety fur became coarse rocklike skin and its head became a large mound of steel with snapping jagged jaws. It became the thing it truly was: a razor giant in the service of Culebra, the Black Skull Colonel of Cardac's Death Brigade.

Dauphin screamed. Chariq gasped. And everyone else screamed. All except a little boy, whose magic medallion emitted a humming whine at a very high frequency.
1542211.title: Beware the Faelan!!

1542212.content:
Chariq led Dauphin to a small, squat house. It had no windows and it took several glances to distinguish that it had a door. This was because it was not normally where a door would be: it was in the roof.

"I have no high and mighty connections at the palace but I can give you a bed for the evening and some food," Chariq said humbly.

"That would be so kind of you," Dauphin replied gratefully. "But what of my steed?"

"I own no stables, for I cannot ride. I'm sure I can find some suitable food but the animal... faelan will have to sleep tied in the street. I am sorry."

Dauphin shrugged. They would have both been doing that if they had not run into Chariq anyway.
1542212.title: A place for the night

info.brief_description: A traditional fantasy story set in a land on the brink of war
info.description:
This story has no shrinking. It also had no weight gain and no sex.

I'm not saying these things can't happen. Just that they're not core parts of the story. What I set out to start here is a proper interactive story, like those "Choose Your Own Adventure" books many of us read as children.

Let your imagination roam free.
